('35', 0, 5, 9, 321) April 2, 1926
('35', 0, 6, 10, 335) DEAR FRIEND, I have your letter enclosing copies of your letters to The Hindu and to Mr. Satyamurti.
('35', 0, 6, 11, 436) I have also copies of The Hindu containing the advertisements referred to by you.
('35', 0, 6, 12, 518) I am entirely of opinion that advertisements about things injurious to the nation should not be taken by public journals at all but it is very difficult for me to interfere in such matters.
('35', 0, 6, 13, 708) I can only express my own opinion through the columns of Young India which I do from time to time.
('35', 0, 6, 14, 807) As you might have noticed, I had occasion to refer to this matter of immoral advertisements 1 only recently.

('35', 2, 1, 2, 2422) 5. LETTER TO N. S. VARADACHARI
('35', 2, 2, 3, 2453) AND S. V. PUNTAMBEKAR
('35', 2, 3, 4, 2475) ASHRAM, SABARMATI, April 2, 1926
('35', 2, 4, 5, 2508) DEAR FRIEND, Your joint production 1 is now being revised and I am sorry to observe that there are too many defects in it.
('35', 2, 4, 6, 2631) You have expected the proof reader to find out books and the references you want quoted.
('35', 2, 4, 7, 2720) How can the books be found?
('35', 2, 4, 8, 2748) Where you have not given pages, how is one to find the quotations?
('35', 2, 4, 9, 2815) Do you not think that the quotations should have been neatly copied out by yourself and references given?
('35', 2, 4, 10, 2921) Nor have you supported all your statements with references in footnotes.
('35', 2, 4, 11, 2994) Proper names have been written as if they were ordinary words.
('35', 2, 4, 12, 3057) It is very difficult to trace all the names so written.
('35', 2, 4, 13, 3113) The collection too seems to have been hastily done.
('35', 2, 4, 14, 3165) The printing is almost held up on account of these defects.
('35', 2, 4, 15, 3225) I do not know how I can cope with the difficulty that stares in the face.
('35', 2, 4, 16, 3299) Where can I find the references?
('35', 2, 4, 17, 3332) Can you suggest a way out of the difficulty?
('35', 2, 4, 18, 3377) If one of you come here and fill in the gaps, it would expedite matters.
('35', 2, 4, 19, 3450) Or if you wish, I could send a copy to one of you.
('35', 2, 4, 20, 3501) The letter is posted to both of you at your respective addresses.
('35', 2, 5, 21, 3567) Yours sincerely,
('35', 2, 6, 22, 3584) N. S. VARADACHARI ERODE SJT.
('35', 2, 6, 23, 3613) PUNTAMBEKAR HINDU UNIVERSITY BANARAS
('35', 2, 7, 24, 3650) From a microfilm : S.N. 19411
('35', 2, 8, 25, 3680) 1 Hand Spinning and Hand Weaving—An Essay by S. V. Puntambekar and N. S. Varadachari

('35', 4, 5, 11, 5221) 9. LETTER TO HERBERT ANDERSON 1
('35', 4, 6, 12, 5253) ASHRAM, SABARMATI, April 3, 1926
('35', 4, 7, 13, 5286) DEAR FRIEND,
('35', 4, 8, 14, 5299) I have your letter.
('35', 4, 8, 15, 5319) I am enquiring about Young India.
('35', 4, 8, 16, 5353) It is true that subscriptions are all reckoned from quarter to quarter or year to year.
('35', 4, 8, 17, 5441) Otherwise, book keeping becomes a most difficult thing.
('35', 4, 8, 18, 5497) The proper way therefore is to subscribe from the 1st of March and to get the previous numbers commencing with the biographical chapters.
('35', 4, 8, 19, 5635) I am sending herewith either a copy of my criticism on the Prohibition Convention or a copy of Young India containing the criticism if the latter is possible.
('35', 4, 8, 20, 5794) With reference to the last paragraph of your letter : In the prohibition campaign you refer to, picketing was the essence of that campaign.
('35', 4, 8, 21, 5934) It was done under the most adverse circumstances including opposition, both silent and open, as you will have seen from the report of enquiry conducted in Assam by Mr. Andrews.
('35', 4, 8, 22, 6111) The only lasting remedy is total prohibition because, the drunkard is a diseased man quite unable to help himself.
('35', 4, 8, 23, 6226) Many of them would gladly welcome outside help in the shape of total prohibition.
('35', 4, 8, 24, 6308) The two
('35', 4, 9, 25, 6316) 1 In reply to his letter dated 30 3 1926. Herein the addressee had request for a message for the first issue of his quarterly, Prohibition
('35', 5, 0, 1, 6455) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 6
('35', 5, 1, 2, 6495) things, therefore, have, in my opinion, to go side by side.
('35', 5, 2, 3, 6555) Yours sincerely, Encl.
('35', 5, 2, 4, 6578) HERBERT ANDERSON 59, KING’S ROAD HOWRAH

('35', 8, 5, 6, 10781) 15. LETTER TO P. GOVINDAN KUTTI MENON
('35', 8, 6, 7, 10819) ASHRAM, SABARMATI, April 3, 1926
('35', 8, 7, 8, 10852) DEAR FRIEND, I have your letter.
('35', 8, 7, 9, 10885) Here are my answers : 1. I wish to see God face to face not as I would like to see Him but exactly as He is.
('35', 8, 7, 10, 10994) 2. If the whole world becomes celibate in my sense, it will be transfigured into something infinitely superior to what it is today but there is not much chance, I fear, of the whole world taking to a life of complete self restraint all of a sudden.
('35', 8, 7, 11, 11243) There fore we thus talk of grahasthashrama, the stage next to that of complete celibacy.
('35', 8, 7, 12, 11332) 3. There is not much hope of my visiting Kerala in the near future.
('35', 8, 7, 13, 11400) You are misinformed in thinking that purity amongst the untouchables and unapproachables is not preached.
('35', 8, 7, 14, 11506) Not only is it preached but it is practised.
('35', 8, 7, 15, 11551) 4. I do not desire total abolition of English but if you will think in terms of the millions of each province, you will find that for them English can never be the medium of instruction.
('35', 8, 7, 16, 11738) Hindi should be the language of intercommunication between provinces and English should be the language of intercommunication between India and the World.
('35', 8, 7, 17, 11893) It therefore comes third in point of time as also importance.
('35', 8, 7, 18, 11955) 5. I do not think that there ever will be one religion in India or elsewhere.
('35', 8, 7, 19, 12033) But there will be and should be sincere respect and toleration for one another’s religion.
('35', 8, 7, 20, 12124) 6. If everybody spins regularly there need be no surplus self spun yarn but there will be enough for all and that with the least
('35', 9, 0, 1, 12253) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 10
('35', 9, 1, 2, 12294) possible trouble and expenditure that the world has ever conceived.
('35', 9, 1, 3, 12362) And if there was a surplus, we could automatically reduce the time spent by each on spinning.
('35', 9, 1, 4, 12456) 7. I have put nothing before the people which the most ordinary man cannot do.
('35', 9, 1, 5, 12535) For instance, what is the difficulty in every one handling a spinning wheel, or giving up foreign cloth, or giving up drink, or in believing and in promoting Hindu Muslim unity, or in regarding an untouchable as his own brother, or in learning Hindi in addition to his own language?
('35', 9, 1, 6, 12818) 8. One’s food should consist of grains, fruit, milk and the fewest condiments, if any at all.
('35', 9, 1, 7, 12912) Much fat should be avoided.
('35', 9, 1, 8, 12940) The quantity and quality should be regulated by actual and careful experiments.
('35', 9, 2, 9, 13020) Yours sincerely, SJT.
('35', 9, 2, 10, 13042) P. GOVINDAN KUTTI MENON PANDARATHIL HOUSE PUDUCODE VIA OTTAPALAM S. MALABAR
('35', 9, 3, 11, 13118) From a photostat : S.N. 19415

('35', 10, 10, 12, 14244) 18. LETTER TO MANILAL GANDHI
('35', 10, 11, 13, 14273) April 3, 1926
('35', 10, 12, 14, 14287) MANILAL,
('35', 10, 13, 15, 14296) I read your letter to Ramdas; also Fatima’s.
('35', 10, 13, 16, 14341) And of course I had anticipated this; Jalbhai did give a hint.
('35', 10, 13, 17, 14404) You are a free man; so I cannot force you to do anything.
('35', 10, 13, 18, 14462) But I write to you as a friend.
('35', 10, 13, 19, 14494) What you desire is contrary to dharma.
('35', 10, 13, 20, 14533) If you stick to Hinduism and Fatima follows Islam it will be like putting two swords in one sheath; or you both may lose your faith.
('35', 10, 13, 21, 14666) And then what should be your children’s faith?
('35', 10, 13, 22, 14713) Whose influence are they to grow under?
('35', 10, 13, 23, 14753) It is not dharma, but, only adharma if Fatima agrees to conversion just for marrying you.
('35', 10, 13, 24, 14843) Faith is not a thing like a garment which can be changed to suit our convenience.
('35', 10, 13, 25, 14925) For the sake of dharma a person shall forgo matrimony, forsake his home, why, even lay down his life; but for nothing may faith be given up.
('35', 10, 13, 26, 15066) May not Fatima have meat at her father’s?
('35', 10, 13, 27, 15108) If she does not, she has as good as changed her religion.
('35', 11, 0, 1, 15166) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 12
('35', 11, 1, 2, 15207) Nor is it in the interests of our society to form this relationship.
('35', 11, 1, 3, 15276) Your marriage will have a powerful impact on the Hindu Muslim question.
('35', 11, 1, 4, 15348) Intercommunal marriages are no solution to this problem.
('35', 11, 1, 5, 15405) You cannot forget nor will society forget that you are my son.
('35', 11, 2, 6, 15468) If you enter into this relationship, you may not be able to render any service.
('35', 11, 2, 7, 15548) I fear you may no more be the right person to run Indian Opinion.
('35', 11, 2, 8, 15614) It will be impossible for you, I think, after this to come and settle in India.
('35', 11, 2, 9, 15694) I cannot ask for Ba’s permission.
('35', 11, 2, 10, 15728) She will not give it.
('35', 11, 2, 11, 15750) Her life will be embittered for ever.
('35', 11, 2, 12, 15788) In proposing this marriage you have thought only of momentary pleasure.
('35', 11, 2, 13, 15860) You have not at all considered your ultimate happiness.
('35', 11, 2, 14, 15916) Pure love is as between brother and sister.
('35', 11, 2, 15, 15960) Whereas here the main urge is carnal pleasure.
('35', 11, 3, 16, 16007) I want you to get out of your infatuation.
('35', 11, 3, 17, 16050) As far as I understand, Ramdas and Devdas also have arrived independently at the same conclusion, as mine.
('35', 11, 3, 18, 16157) I could not embolden myself to discuss this with Ba.
('35', 11, 3, 19, 16210) May God show you the right path.
('35', 11, 4, 20, 16243) Blessings from
('35', 11, 6, 21, 16258) From the Gujarati original : C.W. 1118. Courtesy : Sushilabehn Gandhi
('35', 11, 7, 22, 16328) 19. LETTER TO MANSINGH JASRAJ

('35', 15, 9, 29, 22354) Swaraj is not to be had merely by making speeches or merely by entering Councils or writing essays on swaraj or even by
('35', 15, 10, 30, 22474) 1 The source has Chaitra Vad 6 which, however, was neither a Saturday nor the 3rd of April.

('35', 16, 1, 2, 22665) editing newspapers, though all these things may help and some of them may be considered even necessary; but what is that which everyone can do without much effort and which would increase the wealth of India, which increases the powers of combination and organization and makes us feel akin to one another?
('35', 16, 1, 3, 22972) The answer unhesitatingly is the spinning wheel.
('35', 16, 1, 4, 23021) Hence it is that I have recommended an intensive khaddar propaganda during the week.
('35', 16, 1, 5, 23106) If therefore you have not already taken up some khaddar work, it is not yet too late.
('35', 16, 1, 6, 23192) Every little thing helps.
('35', 16, 1, 7, 23218) There is unsold khaddar everywhere in the chief centres, as for instance, Tamilnadu, Bihar, the Punjab, Gujarat and Bengal, etc.
('35', 16, 1, 8, 23347) You need not think of any particular province.
('35', 16, 1, 9, 23394) Wherever you are if you are not wearing khaddar invest in some now and you help to reduce the stock all over India.
('35', 16, 1, 10, 23510) If you have enough khaddar and do not need to buy any more, but if you have money to spare send your donation to the All India Spinners’ Association and it will be used for khaddar production.
('35', 16, 1, 11, 23703) If you have any minutes to spare, (and who has not?) give them to the spinning wheel yourself and send the yarn to the Association.
('35', 16, 1, 12, 23835) If you have any friends whom you can influence, ask them to do all or any of the things I have just mentioned.
('35', 16, 1, 13, 23946) Remember that by contributing to khaddar work you associate yourself with the poor people, you assist the cause of swaraj and you take part in perpetuating Deshbandhu’s memory.

('35', 16, 2, 15, 24145) 27. ON “BRAHMACHARYA” 1
('35', 16, 3, 16, 24169) I am being inundated with letters on brahmacharya and means to its attainment.
('35', 16, 3, 17, 24248) Let me repeat in different language what I have already said or written on previous occasions.
('35', 16, 3, 18, 24343) Brahmacharya is not mere mechanical celibacy, it means complete control over all the senses and freedom from lust in thought, word and deed.
('35', 16, 3, 19, 24484) As such it is the royal road to self realization or attainment of Brahman.
('35', 16, 3, 20, 24559) The ideal brahmachari had not to struggle with sensual desire or desire for procreation; it never troubles him at all.
('35', 16, 3, 21, 24678) The whole world will be to him one vast family, he will centre all his ambition in relieving the misery of mankind and the desire for procreation will be
('35', 16, 4, 22, 24832) 1 The original Gujarati article appeared in Navajivan, 4 4 1926. The is a translation by Mahadev Desai.
('35', 17, 0, 1, 24936) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 18
('35', 17, 1, 2, 24977) to him as gall and wormwood.
('35', 17, 1, 3, 25006) He who has realized the misery of mankind in all its magnitude will never be stirred by passion.
('35', 17, 1, 4, 25103) He will instinctively know the fountain of strength in him, and he will ever persevere to keep it undefiled.
('35', 17, 1, 5, 25212) His humble strength will command respect of the world, and he will wield an influence greater than that of the sceptred monarch.
('35', 17, 1, 6, 25341) But I am told that this is an impossible ideal, that I do not take count of the natural attraction between man and women.
('35', 17, 1, 7, 25463) I refuse to believe that the sensual affinity referred to here can be at all regarded as natural; in that case the deluge would soon be over us.
('35', 17, 1, 8, 25608) The natural affinity between man and woman is the attraction between brother and sister, mother and son, or father and daughter.
('35', 17, 1, 9, 25737) It is that natural attraction that sustains the world.
('35', 17, 1, 10, 25792) I should find it impossible to live, much less carry on my work, if I did not regard the whole of womankind as sisters, daughters or mothers.
('35', 17, 1, 11, 25934) If I looked at them with lustful eyes, it would be the surest way to perdition.
('35', 17, 1, 12, 26014) Procreation is a natural phenomenon indeed, but within specific limits.
('35', 17, 1, 13, 26086) A transgression of those limits imperils womankind, emasculates the race, induces disease, puts a premium on vice, and makes the world ungodly.
('35', 17, 1, 14, 26230) A man in the grip of the sensual desire is a man without moorings.
('35', 17, 1, 15, 26297) If such a one were to guide society, to flood it with his writings and men were to be swayed by them, where would society be?
('35', 17, 1, 16, 26423) And yet we have the very thing happening today.
('35', 17, 1, 17, 26471) Supposing a moth whirling round a light were to record the moments of its fleeting joy and we were to imitate it, regarding it as an exemplar, where would we be?
('35', 17, 1, 18, 26633) No, I must declare with all the power I can command that sensual attraction even between husband and wife is unnatural.
('35', 17, 1, 19, 26753) Marriage is meant to cleanse the hearts of the couple of sordid passions and take them nearer to God.
('35', 17, 1, 20, 26855) Lustless love between husband and wife is not impossible.
('35', 17, 1, 21, 26913) Man is not a brute.
('35', 17, 1, 22, 26933) He has risen to a higher state after countless births in brute creation.
('35', 17, 1, 23, 27006) He is born to stand, not to walk on all fours or crawl.
('35', 17, 1, 24, 27062) Bestiality is as far removed from manhood, as matter from spirit.
('35', 17, 1, 25, 27128) In conclusion I shall summarize the means to its attainment.
('35', 17, 1, 26, 27189) The first step is the realization of its necessity.
('35', 17, 1, 27, 27241) The next is gradual control of the senses.
('35', 17, 1, 28, 27284) A brahmachari must needs control his palate.
('35', 17, 1, 29, 27329) He must eat to live, and not for enjoyment.
('35', 17, 1, 30, 27373) He must see only clean things and close his eyes before anything unclean.
('35', 17, 1, 31, 27447) It is thus a sign of polite breeding to walk with one’s eyes
('35', 18, 0, 1, 27508) VOL.35 : 2 APRIL, 1926 7 JULY, 1926 19
('35', 18, 1, 2, 27547) towards the goround and not wandering about from object to object.
('35', 18, 1, 3, 27614) A brahmachari will likewise hear nothing obscene or unclean, smell no strong, stimulating, things.
('35', 18, 1, 4, 27713) The smell of clean earth is far sweeter than the fragrance of artificial scents and essences.
('35', 18, 1, 5, 27807) Let the aspirant to brahmacharya also keep his hands and feet engaged in all waking hours in healthful activity.
('35', 18, 1, 6, 27920) Let him also fast occasionally.
('35', 18, 1, 7, 27952) The third step is to have clean companions—clean friends and clean books.
('35', 18, 1, 8, 28026) The last and not the least is prayer.
('35', 18, 1, 9, 28064) Let him repeat Ramanama with all his heart regularly every day, and ask for divine grace.
('35', 18, 1, 10, 28154) None of these things are difficult for an average man or woman.
('35', 18, 1, 11, 28218) they are simplicity itself.
('35', 18, 1, 12, 28246) But their very simplicity is embarrassing.
('35', 18, 1, 13, 28289) Where there is a will, the way is simple enough.
('35', 18, 1, 14, 28338) Men have not the will for it and hence vainly grope.
('35', 18, 1, 15, 28391) The fact that the world rests on the observance, more or less, of brahmacharya or restraint, means that it is necessary and practicable.
('35', 18, 1, 16, 28528) Young India, 29 4 1926
('35', 18, 2, 17, 28551) 28. SATYAGRAHA WEEK
('35', 18, 3, 18, 28571) This week is drawing near.
('35', 18, 3, 19, 28598) I suggest the best way, according to my lights, of observing it.
('35', 18, 3, 20, 28663) Satyagraha is a great religious principle, and a universal one.
('35', 18, 3, 21, 28727) It is to be found in all religions.
('35', 18, 3, 22, 28763) No religion can live long without it.
('35', 18, 3, 23, 28801) Satyagraha is the very basis of religion.
('35', 18, 3, 24, 28843) It can never be employed without a well developed religious consciousness.
('35', 18, 3, 25, 28918) Countless people now accept that we cannot get swaraj except through satyagraha, and also that we shall never win it with the help of the sword.
('35', 18, 3, 26, 29063) But only a handful know how it can be employed.
('35', 18, 3, 27, 29111) I am firmly of the view that till we have imbibed the spirit of peace exemplified by the spinning wheel, have placed our relations with the poor on a pure basis and given a place of honour to khadi we shall not be fit to employ satyagraha.
('35', 18, 3, 28, 29351) I, therefore, suggest that those who have any faith in khadi should observe the week by spending it in promoting the spread of khadi.
('35', 18, 3, 29, 29485) There are several ways to do this.
('35', 18, 3, 30, 29520) 1. One may spin, and also persuade others to spin, more yarn than at other times.
('35', 18, 3, 31, 29602) 2. One may wear khadi and persuade others to do so.
('35', 18, 3, 32, 29654) 3. Wherever stocks of khadi have accumulated, one may go
('35', 19, 0, 1, 29711) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 20
('35', 19, 1, 2, 29752) round selling it.
('35', 19, 1, 3, 29770) 4. One may help, and persuade others to help, in the production of khadi.
('35', 19, 1, 4, 29844) 5. One may contribute money, according to one’s means, for khadi work.
('35', 19, 1, 5, 29915) This week should see all the accumulated stocks of khadi cleared.
('35', 19, 1, 6, 29981) If the people cannot do even this, what else can they achieve?
('35', 19, 1, 7, 30044) Khadi work does not come in the way of other activities of public welfare, but supplements them; for the spread of khadi increases national wealth and the benefit of the increase naturally goes to the poor.
('35', 19, 1, 8, 30251) I, therefore, suggest that even those who wish to give something as charity should make a gift of khadi.
('35', 19, 1, 9, 30356) And for those who have not yet given up using foreign cloth, can we hope that during this week they will take the pledge and start wearing khadi, and thereby contribute their share in the swaraj yajna?
('35', 19, 1, 10, 30558) Those who have any doubts about khadi may put this ques tion to themselves : “If not through khadi, through what other means can we win swaraj, and can I myself join in such activity?” I have put this question to myself time and again but have been able to think of no other activity.
('35', 19, 1, 11, 30843) To those who think that khadi by itself will not bring swaraj, I may say that the question does not arise at all.
('35', 19, 1, 12, 30957) There can be no swaraj without khadi, and in any case we shall lose nothing through it.
('35', 19, 1, 13, 31045) Hence, whether we do other work or not, we should certainly help in promoting the spread of khadi.
('35', 19, 2, 14, 31144) [From Gujarati]
('35', 19, 3, 15, 31160) Navajivan, 4 4 1926

('35', 22, 1, 2, 34250) 34. LETTER TO JAMNALAL BAJAJ
('35', 22, 2, 3, 34279) AHRAM, SABARMATI, Sunday, April 4, 1926
('35', 22, 3, 4, 34319) JAMNALAL, Your letter.
('35', 22, 3, 5, 34342) I sent you a telegram saying I can start on the 22nd.

('35', 24, 7, 11, 38537) ASHRAM, SABARMATI, April 6, 1926
('35', 24, 8, 12, 38570) DEAR FRIEND, I was interested in your letter to the Secretary, All India Spinners’ Association, regarding spinning in the girls’ schools of your district.
('35', 24, 8, 13, 38725) I feel tempted to suggest to you that you can save much of the money voted for spinning if instead of the charkhas you will have taklis.
('35', 24, 8, 14, 38862) The Spinners’ Association has now published an authorized Takli Teacher prepared by two experts.
('35', 24, 8, 15, 38959) It gives fairly exhaustive information and hints on takli.
('35', 24, 8, 16, 39018) The experience of the Association is that takli spinning is the best and the most efficient for
('35', 24, 9, 17, 39114) 1 Vide “For and against Khadi”, 22 4 1926.
('35', 25, 0, 1, 39157) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 26
('35', 25, 1, 2, 39198) schools because in the schools the boys and girls can naturally give only a short time.
('35', 25, 1, 3, 39286) The collective output is therefore greater through takli spinning than through the spinning wheel for the simple reason that the takli spinning could be done by hundreds of children at the same time without requiring any extra space whatsoever.
('35', 25, 1, 4, 39531) Moreover, the cost of a takli would be [a] few annas as against a few rupees for the spinning wheel and the takli rarely goes out of order.
('35', 25, 1, 5, 39671) It may be advisable for you to spend a little of the grant made by the Board for sending your teachers to Ahmedabad to watch the takli spinning that is being done in the schools here.
('35', 25, 2, 6, 39855) Yours sincerely,
('35', 25, 3, 7, 39872) THE VICE CHAIRMAN THE DISTRICT BOARD PURI

('35', 32, 1, 2, 49785) 54. LETTER TO DEVDAS GANDHI
('35', 32, 2, 3, 49813) ASHRAM, SABARAMTI, Wednesday, April 7, 1926
('35', 32, 3, 4, 49857) DEVDAS, I have your letter.
('35', 32, 3, 5, 49885) Since you had such an illness, how well it would have been if you had informed me of it immediately.
('35', 32, 3, 6, 49986) There was no need to hide it from me.
('35', 32, 3, 7, 50024) I have often found that by this sort of false kindness people have been unkind to me.
('35', 32, 3, 8, 50110) Jaundice can be cured very easily.
('35', 32, 3, 9, 50145) For this there is no remedy like fasting.
('35', 32, 3, 10, 50187) It soon subsides with fasting and flushing by drinking plenty of water, and the appetite is restored.
('35', 32, 3, 11, 50289) I have never believed in the theory that a patient grows weaker by withstanding hunger or by fasting.
('35', 32, 3, 12, 50391) If you must take buttermilk, all butter should be removed from it.
('35', 32, 3, 13, 50458) Curds cannot be taken in any case.
('35', 32, 3, 14, 50493) Rice is an un necessary burden.
('35', 32, 3, 15, 50525) I remember in the year 1896 I had a severe attack of jaundice.
('35', 32, 3, 16, 50588) At that time I had trust in the prescriptions only of Manishankar Vaid.
('35', 32, 3, 17, 50660) He had administered to me some mixture with sodium.
('35', 32, 3, 18, 50712) 1 the main treatment was, however, a fast.
('35', 32, 3, 19, 50755) For about ten days I was allowed to have neither milk, nor buttermilk nor rice.

('35', 34, 3, 9, 53561) 58. OBJECTIONS CONSIDERED
('35', 34, 4, 10, 53587) You say that swaraj can only come to us as the result of a bloody battle in the bad old way or through spinning away for all we are worth in our village homes in the good new way of the Mahatma.
('35', 34, 4, 11, 53782) This is only another instance of hypnosis by a catchword.
('35', 34, 4, 12, 53840) What steps have been taken, by you or the others concerned, beyond mere repetition of the doctrine, to convince people that this spinning away (1) is possible, (2) is desirable, (3) will be effective?
('35', 34, 4, 13, 54041) I have yet to see a plain, intelligible, fairly well reasoned out statement, answering doubts and questions as to (1) whether it is possible, in view of the rent and revenue laws, to retain and detain the needed cotton within the country, and in the hands of the right persons; (2) whether and how far it is desirable to do so, in view of the effects of such a step, upon the other industries which have grown up; (3) whether it will be effectual, and if so directly requiring other steps, and, if so, what steps, to bring about swaraj (whatever that might mean!).
('35', 34, 4, 14, 54606) I have repeatedly tried to get leading exponents of the cult to thrash out the thing, pro and con in public print, or even private discussion, but have failed so far.
('35', 34, 4, 15, 54773) Only once I had an opportunity of questioning the fountain head of the doctrine himself, viz., Mahatmaji, and the opportunity was limited to putting only the question as to the possibility.
('35', 34, 4, 16, 54963) He contented himself with simply saying, “Yes, it is possible.” There were many other persons, and more important matters, to deal with; so my doubts and fears remained unallayed.
('35', 34, 4, 17, 55143) The preceding quotation is from an informing letter by Babu Bhagwandas to Maulana Mahomed Ali and published by him in the Comrade.
('35', 34, 4, 18, 55274) Though it is to be found in an old issue (18th December last), I regret to say I saw it only during the current week.
('35', 34, 4, 19, 55392) I may say at the outset that I do not remember the conversation referred to by Babu Bhagwandas.
('35', 34, 4, 20, 55488) For me nothing in the political world is more important than the spinning wheel.
('35', 34, 4, 21, 55569) I can recall many occasions when I have postponed other matters to make room for a discussion on the spinning wheel as central part of our economics or politics.
('35', 34, 4, 22, 55731) But whatever fate overtook Babu Bhagwandas’s question put to me when I
('35', 35, 0, 1, 55802) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 36
('35', 35, 1, 2, 55843) had the privilege of being his guest, the root questions raised by him must be answered.
('35', 35, 1, 3, 55932) That the spinning wheel is possible is being daily demonstrated with increasing force.
('35', 35, 1, 4, 56019) Amid the many seeming impossibilities, e.g., Hindu Muslim unity, the spinning wheel alone is being demonstrated as a possibility, as witness the growing organiza tions in Tamilnad, Andhra, Karnatak, the Punjab, Bihar and Bengal, etc.
('35', 35, 1, 5, 56253) If the organizations are not more numerous, it is because the workers are too few.
('35', 35, 1, 6, 56336) There is no inherent impossibility in the wheel.
('35', 35, 1, 7, 56385) It has been worked before with the greatest success.
('35', 35, 1, 8, 56438) There are millions who can work it, who have the required leisure for it and who are in need of a cottage occupation.
('35', 35, 1, 9, 56556) That it is desirable may be proved from the mere fact that it is the best adapted for this vast country of seven hundred thousand villages.
('35', 35, 1, 10, 56696) No one can say with certainty whether it will be effective.
('35', 35, 1, 11, 56756) If it is permissible to infer the experience being gained in the several provinces, it can be safely asserted that it is highly probable that it will be effective.
('35', 35, 1, 12, 56920) It can even be boldly asserted that no other industry has as yet been proved to be as effective as the spinning wheel for the purpose intended.
('35', 35, 1, 13, 57064) Babu Bhagwandas mentions the adverse effect of rent and revenue laws.
('35', 35, 1, 14, 57134) He thereby draws attention to the difficulty, not the impossibility, of revival of the one national industry that gave the peasantry its staying power one century ago.
('35', 35, 1, 15, 57302) Revenue and rent laws are not immutable.
('35', 35, 1, 16, 57343) In so far as they interfere with the growth of the spinning industry, they must be altered.“But” it will be said, “they cannot be altered without swaraj”.
('35', 35, 1, 17, 57498) The answer is that swaraj cannot be obtained without organizing spinning in spite of the laws.
('35', 35, 1, 18, 57593) For the fight for swaraj means fighting difficulties however great they may be.
('35', 35, 1, 19, 57673) Violence is the accepted, though barbarous, method of fighting.
('35', 35, 1, 20, 57737) Organizing the spinning wheel is the moral method of fighting for swaraj.
('35', 35, 1, 21, 57811) Organizing the spinning wheel is the easiest and the cheapest method of peacefully organizing the masses.
('35', 35, 1, 22, 57917) Surely, if cotton can be exported thousands of miles away, there spun, brought back in the shape of yarn for sale to the very exporters, there should be no difficulty about shifting it, in India itself, a few miles away from the seat of its cultivation.
('35', 35, 1, 23, 58171) There is no difficulty about a non rice growing province importing rice from the rice growing province.
('35', 35, 1, 24, 58275) Why should there be any in so handling cotton?
('35', 35, 1, 25, 58322) The process is going on today.
('35', 36, 0, 1, 58353) VOL.35 : 2 APRIL, 1926 7 JULY, 1926 37
('35', 36, 1, 2, 58392) Bihar has to import from Wardha or Cawnpore.
('35', 36, 1, 3, 58437) But, says Babu Bhagwandas, it may be undesirable “in view of the effects of such a step upon the other industries which have grown up”.
('35', 36, 1, 4, 58573) What other industries?
('35', 36, 1, 5, 58596) And if they are adversely affected, shouldthat interfere with the prosecution of an industry which is as necessary to the national life as either lung is to the body?
('35', 36, 1, 6, 58763) Should we be afraid to promote total prohibition because it must interfere with the established distilleries?
('35', 36, 1, 7, 58873) Ormust a reformer be deterred from advoca ting abstention from the opium habit for fear of harming the opium growers?
('35', 36, 1, 8, 58991) Babu Bhagwandas cited the Champaran ryot who could not keep enough food grains for sustenance.
('35', 36, 1, 9, 59086) That was because he had not enough for all his wants.
('35', 36, 1, 10, 59140) If he had spun or if the taxation was light, he could have kept enough for his wants.
('35', 36, 1, 11, 59226) He got partial relief by the removal of the burden of growing indigo compulsorily.
('35', 36, 1, 12, 59309) He could still further better his condition if he would utilize his idle hours (he has many) by spinning unless he found a more profitable industry.
('35', 36, 1, 13, 59458) But he will not spin, unless the educated class set the fashion and assure him that the wheel is not to be a nine days’ wonder.
('35', 36, 1, 14, 59586) Babu Bhagwandas however exclaims :
('35', 36, 2, 15, 59621) If to spin away is so easily possible, so desirable, so effective, there must after all be some reason why the three hundred millions do not take to it at once, why the Congress membership has dwindled down to nine thousand odd.
('35', 36, 2, 16, 59850) Surely he knows many things “possible, desirable, and effective,” not happening for want of will or effort.
('35', 36, 2, 17, 59958) Universal education is“possible, desirable and effective” but people do not resort to it readily.
('35', 36, 2, 18, 60056) And, it will require the energy of an army of trained workers to instil into the minds of the people the necessity of taking the trouble to be educated.
('35', 36, 2, 19, 60209) Sanitary precautions are “possible, desirable and effective”.
('35', 36, 2, 20, 60271) But why do the villagers not take to them as soon as they are brought to their notice?
('35', 36, 2, 21, 60358) The answer seems to be simple.
('35', 36, 2, 22, 60389) Progress is slow.
('35', 36, 2, 23, 60407) It is lame.
('35', 36, 2, 24, 60419) It requires effort, organization, time and expense in exact proportion to its importance.
('35', 36, 2, 25, 60509) The greatest stumbling block in the way of the more rapid progress of spinning, great as it is, is the disinclination or the inability of the cultured classes, the natural leaders of the people, to recognize the supreme place the spinning wheel has in any scheme of national regeneration.
('35', 36, 2, 26, 60798) The very simplicity of it seems to bewilder them.
('35', 36, 2, 27, 60848) Young India, 8 4 1926
('35', 37, 0, 1, 60870) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 38
('35', 37, 1, 2, 60911) 59. NEED FOR CHARTS
('35', 37, 2, 3, 60931) A correspondent writes to say that instead of giving figures, in order to impress facts on the minds of the readers, charts should be given showing fluctuations in the production and sale of khadi.
('35', 37, 2, 4, 61129) He rejects the forebodings of people who say that khadi is dying out but says that though they can be refuted by those who have read the annual report of the All India Spinners’ Association, but few have the patience to go through it.
('35', 37, 2, 5, 61364) He says :
('35', 37, 3, 6, 61374) People think that the more the khadi cap wearers, the greater the production and sale of khaddar.
('35', 37, 4, 7, 61472) The remarks of the correspondent are very true.
('35', 37, 4, 8, 61520) Arrangements are being made to prepare a chart such as the correspondent suggests.
('35', 37, 4, 9, 61603) Mean while the figures given this week in C. R.’s note on Tamilnadu are eloquent enough to demonstrate the progress of khadi.
('35', 37, 4, 10, 61729) Young India, 8 4 1926
('35', 37, 5, 11, 61751) 60. DOES INDIA WANT PROHIBITION?
('35', 37, 6, 12, 61784) Much has been made by the opponents of total prohibition in India of the speech of Mr. King, Financial Commissioner in the Punjab, who was reported to have said that the Local Option Act which was passed over a year ago in the Punjab has been a perfect failure.
('35', 37, 6, 13, 62046) The Commissioner quotes in support of his statement the following facts: That out of nearly 200 municipalities, district boards, etc., only 19 have asked to be empowered under the Act.
('35', 37, 6, 14, 62231) Of the 19, only six took further steps.
('35', 37, 6, 15, 62271) And in the six the referendum that was held had precious little support.
('35', 37, 6, 16, 62344) At Rawalpindi for instance out of 7,000 voters, only six registered their votes.
('35', 37, 6, 17, 62425) At Ludhiana out of 12,500 voters at the first referendum not one turned up.
('35', 37, 6, 18, 62501) Of the other four only in one small town, that of Tohana, out of 1,052 voters, 802 voted for total prohibition.
('35', 37, 6, 19, 62613) Mr. King argued, as he would be entitled to argue if he was a stranger to India and Indian conditions, that there was no demand for total prohibition in the Punjab.
('35', 37, 6, 20, 62778) Unfortunately for India the conditions are that people are apathetic even about things that concern them as a society.
('35', 37, 6, 21, 62897) The methods adopted for referendum are new to them.
('35', 37, 7, 22, 62949) 1 The rest of the letter is not reproduced here.
('35', 38, 0, 1, 62998) VOL.35 : 2 APRIL, 1926 7 JULY, 1926 39
('35', 38, 1, 2, 63037) Probably, the voters knew nothing of the fact that there was a refer endum being taken about total prohibition.
('35', 38, 1, 3, 63149) Mr. King must have known the fact which everyone knows who knows anything of India that the vast majority of the people of India do not drink and that drinking intoxicants is contrary to Islam and Hinduism.
('35', 38, 1, 4, 63356) The inference therefore to be drawn from the so called failure referred to by Mr. King is not that the Punjab is against total prohibition but that the Punjabis being themselves as a class teetotallers do not bother their heads about those who are ruining themselves through the drink curse.
('35', 38, 1, 5, 63648) He is also entitled to draw the inference that the Municipal commissioners and the members of the local boards have been criminally negligent of their duties to the voters in this matter of great social importance.
('35', 38, 1, 6, 63863) But to argue from the facts cited that Punjab is opposed to total prohibition is to throw dust in the eyes of strangers or ignorant people.
('35', 38, 1, 7, 64003) That unfortunately is the way of the officials.
('35', 38, 1, 8, 64051) Instead of looking at things impartially or from the popular stand point, they constitute themselves pleaders for what the Government stands or for methods which the Gov ernment may wish to defend at any cost.
('35', 38, 1, 9, 64261) It is a well known fact that the Hindus are against the slaughter of the cow and her progeny.
('35', 38, 1, 10, 64355) Supposing there was a referendum taken precisely in the manner in which it was taken in the Punjab regarding drink and the millions of Hindus fail to register their vote, will anyone who knows Indian conditions argue therefrom, for one moment, that Hindus want slaughter houses where the sacred cow is done to death?
('35', 38, 1, 11, 64672) The fact is that there is not that consciousness created amongst the people that is impatient of social wrong.
('35', 38, 1, 12, 64783) It is no doubt a deplorable thing.
('35', 38, 1, 13, 64818) It is being gradually mended.
('35', 38, 1, 14, 64848) But it is a wicked thing to suppress facts which would warrant an inference totally different from the one that may, in the absence of those facts, be drawn from another set of facts.
('35', 38, 1, 15, 65032) As the Manchester Guardian has mildly put it, the case against total prohibition in India is much weaker than the case against it in America or England where respectable people see nothing wrong or harmful in moderate drinking.
('35', 38, 1, 16, 65260) Young India, 8 4 1926

('35', 42, 4, 8, 69717) 68. LETTER TO SARAT CHANDRA BOSE 3
('35', 42, 5, 9, 69752) ASHRAM, SABARMATI, April 9, 1926
('35', 42, 6, 10, 69785) DEAR SARAT BABU, Manilal Kothari has given your massage.
('35', 42, 6, 11, 69842) I wish I could send you something stirring, something decisive and rapid in reply but I have no such thing in the present state of the country.
('35', 42, 6, 12, 69986) Meetings and resolution of protests in the Councils have been overdone.
('35', 42, 6, 13, 70058) We must do something tangible so that we can feel our power.
('35', 42, 6, 14, 70119) I can think of nothing else therefore but boycott of foreign cloth which in its turn is impossible without khaddar and therefore for the ills including these wretched imprisonments, I have nothing but the charkha.
('35', 42, 6, 15, 70333) But how can I convince the people that it is a sovereign remedy.
('35', 42, 6, 16, 70398) My faith however in it remains undiminished.
('35', 42, 6, 17, 70443) Day by day it increases.
('35', 42, 6, 18, 70468) And therefore during the National Week we have some spinning wheels going on the whole of the week, night and day at the Ashram.
('35', 42, 6, 19, 70597) We are doing it with the implict faith that some day through it will rise a power that will enable us to realize our cherished desire.
('35', 42, 6, 20, 70732) I know that there is an alternative to the charkha and that is rowdyism.
('35', 42, 6, 21, 70805) But I am useless at it and what is more, I have no faith in it.
('35', 42, 6, 22, 70869) And as a practical man I know that our rowdyism is nothing compared to the rowdyism of the Government.
('35', 42, 6, 23, 70972) I have therefore burnt my boats and staked my all on the charkha.
('35', 42, 6, 24, 71038) I invite all who are troubled by this knowledge of the many woes of the nation to join me in the effort.
('35', 42, 6, 25, 71143) Believe me it requires all the skill, all the discipline, all the organizing power that we can summon to its aid.

('35', 43, 5, 6, 71544) 69. LETTER TO V. N. S. CHARY
('35', 43, 6, 7, 71573) ASHRAM, SABARMATI, April 9, 1926
('35', 43, 7, 8, 71606) DEAR FRIEND, I have your letter.
('35', 43, 7, 9, 71639) I too have seen many a lizard going for cockroaches and have watched cockroaches going for lasser forms but I have not felt called upon to prevent the operation of the law of the larger living on the smaller.
('35', 43, 7, 10, 71848) I do not claim to penetrate into the awful mystery but from watching these very oprations, I learn that the law of the beast is not the law of the Man; that Man has by painful striving to surmount and survive the animal in him and from the tragedy of the himsa which is being acted around him he has to learn the supreme lesson of ahimsa for himself.
('35', 43, 7, 11, 72199) Man must, therefore, if he is to realize his dignity and his own mission, cease to take part in the destruction and refuse to prey upon his weaker fellow creatures.
('35', 43, 7, 12, 72364) He can only keep that as an ideal for himself and endeavour day after day to reach it.
('35', 43, 7, 13, 72451) Complete success is possible only when he has attained moksha, a state in which the spirit becomes and remains independent of physical existence.
('35', 43, 7, 14, 72597) Yours sincerely, SH.
('35', 43, 7, 15, 72618) V. N. S. CHARY 7, HIGH ROAD EGMORE

('35', 49, 1, 2, 81808) to hear the word mans 1 .
('35', 49, 1, 3, 81834) To such persons, an unafamiliar word would be more acceptable.
('35', 49, 1, 4, 81897) As people shrink from uttering the very name of a thing which repels them, so they shrink form the word mans and, therefore, use the word paramati 2 instead.
('35', 49, 1, 5, 82055) The phrase zade javin 3 sounds indecent, whereas jungle javun 4 sounds a little less offensive.
('35', 49, 1, 6, 82151) Recently, the word shauch 5 has come into use in place of either.

('35', 49, 1, 11, 82499) This word does not cover milk.
('35', 49, 1, 12, 82530) Strictly speaking, it does not cover even fruits.
('35', 49, 1, 13, 82580) From another point of view, however, food includes milk and fruits.
('35', 49, 1, 14, 82648) In the last resort, if we define the meaning which we attach to a word and, after a little use, can get that meaning accepted by others, we become entitled to use the word in the sense we have attached to it.
('35', 49, 1, 15, 82857) Exercising that right, Navajivan will hencforth use the word annahar in place of niramishahar and to convey the meaning that that word does.

('35', 51, 5, 14, 87737) 1 This was Gandhiji’s reply to the addressee who had written to him about an article “The Change of Viceroys” in the Indian Social Reformer of April 3, which had stated; “Lord Reading hands over charge of the Viceroyalty to Lord Irwin today.
('35', 51, 5, 15, 87979) The political situation today is quite calm, whereas when Lord Reading arrived in the country, it was highly charged with distrubance.
('35', 51, 5, 16, 88114) The Non co operation mov ement was moving rapidly towards its zenith.
('35', 51, 5, 17, 88184) Lord Reading, for several months after assuming charge of his high office, tried to come to an understanding with Mahatma Gandhi, but the latter was in an uncompromising mood.
('35', 51, 5, 18, 88360) The prosecution of the Ali Brothers made conciliation impossible.
('35', 51, 5, 19, 88426) The Prince of Wales was due to visit the country in a few months and the Viceroy strained every nerve to reach at least a tem porary settlement in order to allow His Royal Highness’ visit to pass off quietly.

('35', 61, 1, 2, 104555) 96. LETTER TO BHAGAWANDAS BRAHMACHARI
('35', 61, 2, 3, 104593) ASHRAM, SABARMATI, Tuesday, April 13, 1926
('35', 61, 3, 4, 104636) BHAI BHAGAWANDAS BRAHMACHARI,
('35', 61, 4, 5, 104666) I have your letter.
('35', 61, 4, 6, 104686) I follow [what you say] regarding Sanskrit.
('35', 61, 4, 7, 104730) I can think of nothing to say in the matter.
('35', 61, 4, 8, 104775) “Vegetarian” is an imperfect expression because the ordinary Western vegetarians take milk and eggs; they do not take fish.
('35', 61, 4, 9, 104899) They have therefore already coined a neologism, viz., VEM diet, i.e., vegetables, eggs and milk.
('35', 61, 4, 10, 104996) Ordinary vegetarians do not take fish; they take onion.
('35', 61, 4, 11, 105052) They do not make it a point to give up garlic.
('35', 61, 4, 12, 105099) The expression “sattvik” 1 die will not do.
('35', 61, 4, 13, 105143) Because those who take chillies cannot be regarded as sattvik eaters and many meat eaters will take meat claiming it as sattvik.
('35', 61, 4, 14, 105272) I have selected the expression annahar keeping in mind the special meaning of the word anna, which includes all that we eat barring meat, etc.
('35', 61, 4, 15, 105415) Of course this definition too is rather wide, but I have found annahar better than all expressions I have come across till now.

('35', 66, 1, 2, 111995) 106. “THE TAKLI TEACHER”
('35', 66, 2, 3, 112020) This is the title of a booklet covering 80 pages issued by the All India Spinners’ Association, Ahmedabad, and prepared at its instance by Messrs Richard B. Gregg and Maganlal K. Gandhi.
('35', 66, 2, 4, 112207) It contains 23 clear, well thought out illustrations showing the different forms of takli and the various positions in handling this simple little instrument of household use and national importance.
('35', 66, 2, 5, 112407) It gives accurate hints on spinning by the takli, so that anybody who will read the booklet carefully can master the art of spinning by the takli.
('35', 66, 2, 6, 112554) It also dwells upon the different uses to which the takli can be put and compares the advantages of the takli over the charkha in some instances.
('35', 66, 2, 7, 112700) It also teaches how to make a takli and winds up with historical information about this instrument which enabled the spinners of Dacca to spin the finest yarn, the like of which no machine has yet been able to produce.
('35', 66, 2, 8, 112919) There are valuable hints which are useful to the spinner both on the takli and on the charkha.
('35', 66, 2, 9, 113014) Of the educational value of the takli, the writers explain that it develops in the spinner patience, persistence, concentration, self control, calmness, realization of importance and value of detail, ability to do more than one thing at a time, making one of them so habitual that its control and operation are almost unconscious, sensitiveness, sureness and delicacy of touch and of muscular control and co ordination, realization of value of cumulative and sustained individual effort even though separate efforts be of short duration; thus a realization of the value of co operative work, self respect and self reliance arising from recognition of one’s ability to create something of economic value useful to oneself, to one’s family, to the school and to the village, province or nation.
('35', 66, 2, 10, 113807) There are several other values mentioned in this short chapter which the reader interested in the national spinning movement may see for himself in the book.
('35', 66, 2, 11, 113965) The publishers invite criticism of the book from those who are versed in the art of spinning on the takli, and they would welcome any suggestion, advice or information that may be sent to them so as to enable them to incorporate them in a future edition.
('35', 66, 2, 12, 114220) The book is being simultaneously published in Hindi with the same illustrations and the same get up.
('35', 66, 2, 13, 114321) Whether in Hindi or English, the book can be had at the Ashram, Sabarmati, on payment of Rs. 7 including postage.
('35', 66, 2, 14, 114435) I hope that every takli teacher in municipal and national schools
('35', 67, 0, 1, 114501) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 68
('35', 67, 1, 2, 114542) where takli has been introduced will procure the book for his own guidance and that of his pupils.
('35', 67, 1, 3, 114641) Young India, 15 4 1926
('35', 67, 2, 4, 114664) 107. PANDIT NEHRU AND KHADDAR
('35', 67, 3, 5, 114694) Pandit Motilalji has never been persona grata with The Times of India.
('35', 67, 3, 6, 114765) The latest offence committed by him is that of hawking khaddar in Allahabad where only a few years ago he could hardly be seen going anywhere except in his grand motor car.
('35', 67, 3, 7, 114938) But in the elegant language of the writer: “Even in India it must be recognized that Pandit Nehru is mak ing an ass of himself.” It is to be wished that many leaders will follow Panditji and earn the title that has been so courteously bestowed upon Panditji by The Times of India.
('35', 67, 3, 8, 115219) It is generally time to rejoice when one receives a curse from opponents.
('35', 67, 3, 9, 115293) Their praises should make one cautious.
('35', 67, 3, 10, 115333) The Romans feared the Greeks especially when they brought gifts.
('35', 67, 3, 11, 115398) The Times’ writer has out done himself in showing his contempt for the Congress, khaddar and Congressmen.
('35', 67, 3, 12, 115504) I must let the reader judge for himself.
('35', 67, 3, 13, 115545) The writer says :
('35', 67, 4, 14, 115563) The completeness of the Congress collapse, the utter futility of the so called Congress creed, and the total absence among Congress supporters of a single reasonable political idea are illustrated by a telegram despatched in all earnestness from Allahabad.
('35', 67, 4, 15, 115820) The Writer then proceeds :
('35', 67, 5, 16, 115847) If the British public learnt that Lord Birkenhead, wearing a Union Jack waistcoat, had been selling true blue Tory rosettes beneath the lions in Trafalgar Square, that Mr. Baldwin had been promoting Empire industries by hawking trays of British toys in Piccadilly, that Mr. Ramsay Macdonald, attired in corduroys and a muffler, had been disposing of red flags among the workers in Limehouse, or that the Clydeside Bolshevists had set up a stall on Clydeside for the sale of miniature sickles and hammers, the unanimous conclusion of all classes would be that their leaders had gone mad.
('35', 67, 5, 17, 116434) The inference naturally is that the distinguished hawkers of khaddar such as Pandit Nehru and Mr. Rangaswami Iyengar who accompanied him in his hawking have gone mad.
('35', 67, 5, 18, 116601) The language used by the writer is not only insulting but it is also highly misleading.
('35', 67, 5, 19, 116689) What possible comparison can there be between “true blue Tory rosettes” hawked by a British Tory and khaddar which, rightly or
('35', 68, 0, 1, 116816) VOL.35 : 2 APRIL, 1926 7 JULY, 1926 69
('35', 68, 1, 2, 116855) wrongly, represents to thousands of Indians an emblem of a real bond between the classes and the masses?
('35', 68, 1, 3, 116960) For only by khaddar the classes, through whom the British Government holds sway over the toiling dumb millions, could make some little return to the masses, for the bleeding process which the latter have to undergo in order to feed the British Government.
('35', 68, 1, 4, 117216) The insult has been possible only because the fashion has been set by the Liberal politicians to belittle khadi and all it means.
('35', 68, 1, 5, 117346) Who does not remember that at the time the War broke out, young and old, men and women, great and small, in fact all who were not enlisted or could not be enlisted as soldiers, were expected to sew, as a matter of fact did sew, garments for the wounded soldiers who were received in the various hospitals?
('35', 68, 1, 6, 117652) People at that time vied with one another in doing this little service and those who did not know how to stitch were thankful if they received preliminary training from their neighbours.
('35', 68, 1, 7, 117839) All distinctions were erased in the face of the awful calamity that had overtaken the British people.
('35', 68, 1, 8, 117941) I make bold to say that if it was patriotic and necessary for everyone to do the sewing and hundreds of other odd jobs which in ordinary life they never did, it is a thousand times necessary and patriotic for every Indian to wear khaddar to the exclusion of all foreign cloth and thus find the only occupation, that is, of hand spinning, which is possible for the millions of India to undertake.
('35', 68, 1, 9, 118337) We read in English books that when a movement is ridiculed by its opponents, it may be said to be making headway and when it excites the anger of their opponents, it is said to be producing the desired effect.
('35', 68, 1, 10, 118547) If The Times of India at all represents British public opinion, khaddar is evidently producing the desired effect.
('35', 68, 1, 11, 118662) The writer of the article in question assures the readers that “the Allahabad public does not want the Congress grave clothes”, as he has called khaddar, “any more than they are wanted in any other part of India”.
('35', 68, 1, 12, 118876) If so it is difficult to understand all the contempt poured upon khaddar.
('35', 68, 1, 13, 118950) But it is for the Congress leaders to prove that khaddar is not the “grave clothes” of the Congress but that it establishes an unbreakable link between the Congress and the masses and thus makes the former more representative than it ever has been.
('35', 68, 1, 14, 119199) In fairness, however, to Europeans, let me say that in the venomous abuse of khaddar, The Times of India writer by no means represents the general European opinion.
('35', 68, 1, 15, 119364) I know several Europeans in India who believe in the message of khaddar and some who use it themselves.
('35', 68, 1, 16, 119468) Its message has even reached Europe.
('35', 68, 1, 17, 119505) Here is a letter from
('35', 69, 0, 1, 119527) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 70
('35', 69, 1, 2, 119568) a professor from far off Poland regarding khaddar :
('35', 69, 2, 3, 119620) Do you not think it would be a good thing if an attempt were made to sell Indian tissues in Europe to friends of India?
('35', 69, 2, 4, 119740) I might try on a small scale here if you send me tissues of your cloth with indication of prices in English currency and an English address to which the money could be sent.
('35', 69, 2, 5, 119914) I think that even if the amount of sales would not be very great, it would be useful for propaganda and I hope that many people at least in Poland would be proud and happy to wear Indian cloth in order to show their sympathy with your work.
('35', 69, 2, 6, 120155) This is perhaps the most efficient way to gain universal sympathy for the emancipation of India.
('35', 69, 2, 7, 120252) I could not easily undertake to spin myself but I can undertake to go from house to house and encourage the buying of Indian cloth even if it is more expensive than our own products.
('35', 69, 2, 8, 120435) Young India, 15 4 1926
('35', 69, 3, 9, 120458) 108. WHAT IS IT LIKE?
('35', 69, 4, 10, 120480) An Englishman writing to his relatives in London thus gives vent to his feelings after having been in New York for 48 hours:
('35', 69, 5, 11, 120605) It is all quite true—skyscrapers, iced water, elevators express to the 25th floor, subways, Negroes; I never quite believed it before.
('35', 69, 5, 12, 120740) But that’s all I know.
('35', 69, 5, 13, 120763) I have been here 48 hours—never such a 48 hours before —Ican’t last much longer.
('35', 69, 5, 14, 120844) I’ve been walked about, talked at, dined, lunched, theatred; I’m so tired, I can hardly see.
('35', 69, 5, 15, 120937) Incredible, inconceivable.
('35', 69, 5, 16, 120964) My timetable is arranged to the minute—I am telephoned to wherever I am to see that I am moving on the next engagement.
('35', 69, 5, 17, 121084) By a subterfuge I have escaped.
('35', 69, 5, 18, 121116) I am to go out to dinner in an hour or so.
('35', 69, 5, 19, 121159) You must not expect anything more than postcards.
('35', 69, 5, 20, 121209) It’s very cold out freezing while it boils within.
('35', 69, 5, 21, 121260) My head goes into solution in these temperatures.
('35', 69, 5, 22, 121310) Englishmen will sympathize with me when I say that I felt about as uncomfortable reaching London for the first time as the writer of the foregoing did on reaching New York.
('35', 69, 5, 23, 121483) And I know that a villager going to Bombay feels similarly bewildered and lost in finding himself in the midst of the hubbub and bustle of Bombay.

('35', 70, 1, 2, 121692) 109. NOTES
('35', 70, 2, 3, 121703) ‘THE MORALS OF MACHINERY’ 1
('35', 70, 3, 4, 121731) The Current Thought for February has reproduced Mr. Richard B. Gregg’s letter to a friend on the “Morals of Machinery” Mr. Gregg is an ex American lawyer with a wide experience of his own country.
('35', 70, 3, 5, 121928) He has lived in the midst of the very things he describes in his letter and has at one time in his life contributed to their growth.
('35', 70, 3, 6, 122061) He therefore writes with authority.
('35', 70, 3, 7, 122097) He says :
('35', 70, 4, 8, 122107) Most people accept mechanism for its immediatey results and are quite blind to the secondary results of slower growth.
('35', 70, 4, 9, 122226) But these latter are the most important.
('35', 70, 4, 10, 122267) He then recounts in detail the evils of multiplication of mach inery.
('35', 70, 4, 11, 122337) He puts ‘enormous concentration of material power and wealth in the hands of the few’ first in the list.
('35', 70, 4, 12, 122442) Mr. Gregg truly says :
('35', 70, 5, 13, 122465) Machinery and modern industry have taken the money of millions of people and concentrated its management and control into relatively few hands and modern developments of banking and credit have concentrated the control of all the materials and factories and mills into still fewer hands.
('35', 70, 5, 14, 122753) Do we not see this process going on even in our own country at the cost of the millions who are being bled white in order to support huge industries thousands of miles away from their cottages?
('35', 70, 5, 15, 122947) Mr. Gregg says :
('35', 70, 6, 16, 122964) Probably the real, ultimate control of industry in Europe, America and most of Asia and Africa is concentrated in the hands of not over 1,500 men, perhaps fewer still.
('35', 70, 7, 17, 123132) Such tremendous power is a temptation which human nature cannot withstand.
('35', 70, 7, 18, 123207) It involves tyranny, vanity, pride, greed, selfishness, ruthless competition on the one side, loss of liberty, insecurity, fears, loss of self reliance and of independence, degradation, poverty, loss of dignity and self respect on the other.
('35', 70, 8, 19, 123449) Deaths, maiming and crippling by industrial accidents far exceed corresponding injuries by war.
('35', 70, 8, 20, 123545) Diseases and physical deterioration caused directly and indirectly by modern industry are appalling.
('35', 70, 8, 21, 123646) For, it is industry that has caused the development of large cities with their smoke, dirt, noise, bad air, lack of sunshine and out door life, slums, disease, prostitution, and
('35', 70, 9, 22, 123824) 1 Dictated on 11 4 1926; vide “Letter to Richard B. Gregg”, 11 4 1926.
('35', 71, 0, 1, 123895) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 72
('35', 71, 1, 2, 123936) unnatural living.
('35', 71, 1, 3, 123954) The waste in advertisements is truly “appalling”.
('35', 71, 2, 4, 124004) The President of the British Incorporated Society of Advertisement Consultants recently estimated that the annual expenditure on advertisements for the British Isles alone is £ 175, 000, 000. !
('35', 71, 2, 5, 124198) Another striking feature is “parasitism”
('35', 71, 3, 6, 124239) Man is made to obey the machine.
('35', 71, 3, 7, 124272) The wealthy and middle classes become helpless and parasitic upon the working classes.
('35', 71, 3, 8, 124359) And the latter become so specialized that they also become helpless.
('35', 71, 3, 9, 124428) The ordinary city dweller cannot make his own clothing or produce or prepare his own food.
('35', 71, 3, 10, 124519) The cities become parasitic upon the country.
('35', 71, 3, 11, 124565) Industrial nations upon agricultural nations.
('35', 71, 3, 12, 124611) Those who live in temperate climates are increasingly parasitic upon tropical peoples.
('35', 71, 3, 13, 124698) Governments upon the peoples they govern.
('35', 71, 3, 14, 124740) Armies upon civilians.
('35', 71, 3, 15, 124763) People even become parasitic and passive in regard to their recreation and amusements.
('35', 71, 3, 16, 124850) They want to be amused, insted of amusing
('35', 71, 4, 17, 124892) themselves.
('35', 71, 4, 18, 124904) They throng the cinemas and theatres and music halls.
('35', 71, 4, 19, 124958) They watch others play cricket, etc.
('35', 71, 5, 20, 124995) Along with this parasitism has come widespread irresponsibility.
('35', 71, 5, 21, 125060) The industrial “magnate” or banker issues an order in Europe which affects vitally the lives of Negroes in Central Africa.
('35', 71, 5, 22, 125183) The consumers, too, fare no better.
('35', 71, 5, 23, 125219) They too cease to feel the responsibility.
('35', 71, 5, 24, 125262) Mr. Gregg exclaims :
('35', 71, 6, 25, 125283) When I, seated in a restaurant in France, put some pepper in my soup, do I stop to think what poor coolie in Java, perchance, endured the hard ship of gathering it, while subject to a fever, and perhaps to the indignities and brutality of harsh plantation supervision?
('35', 71, 6, 26, 125552) I must however resist the temptation to quote more from this instructive letter.
('35', 71, 6, 27, 125633) I must ask the reader to see the original if the samples I have put before him have whetted his appetite for more.
('35', 71, 6, 28, 125748) The reader must not think that Mr. Gregg is against all machinery.
('35', 71, 6, 29, 125815) He is against its uncontrolled multiplication.
('35', 71, 6, 30, 125862) He would regulate and restrain its use as we regulate or ought to regulate and curb our passions.
('35', 71, 6, 31, 125960) That use of machinery is lawful which subserves the interests of all.
('35', 71, 6, 32, 126030) HOW TO HELP?
('35', 71, 7, 33, 126043) An Indian correspondent living in London writes :
('35', 71, 8, 34, 126093) Every person asks me how people who live in America, Germany, France, Italy, as well as England can help the Indian cause?
('35', 71, 8, 35, 126216) What can they do
('35', 72, 0, 1, 126233) VOL.35 : 2 APRIL, 1926 7 JULY, 1926 73
('35', 72, 1, 2, 126272) to help us in our fight for swaraj?
('35', 72, 1, 3, 126308) They ask further what can India teach the world?
('35', 72, 1, 4, 126357) Has she any message to the people who are fighting?
('35', 72, 1, 5, 126409) And, if so, what can she contribute towards creating world peace?
('35', 72, 1, 6, 126475) The first question is easily answered.
('35', 72, 1, 7, 126514) If even God only helps those who help themselves, how would people, imperfect as they are, help one another unless they are prepared to help themselves?
('35', 72, 1, 8, 126667) But after all there is something in creating a sane world opinion.
('35', 72, 1, 9, 126734) There is no doubt that that opinion is daily growing in influence.
('35', 72, 1, 10, 126801) The chapters, which I am reproducing 1 in a somewhat condensed form from Mr. Page’s pamphlet, show clearly how people were led into error by mis education.
('35', 72, 1, 11, 126957) They were fed during the War on diabolical lies by their respective governments.
('35', 72, 1, 12, 127038) I have therefore suggested to every European friend who has been good enough to visit the Ashram to study our movement, not from newspaper reports, which are ill informed where they are not interested, but from original writings.
('35', 72, 1, 13, 127268) It grieves me to have to say that the British Government agency, both public and secret, is spreading a wholly incorrect view of the situation.
('35', 72, 1, 14, 127412) No Indian patriotic agency can possibly overtake the lies spread by this highly organized and lavishly paid secret service from whose attention even the great Poet 2 of Asia, indeed of the world, has not been free.
('35', 72, 1, 15, 127627) It is only impartial and sober representatives of the respective European countries and America who can, if at all, controvert the statements that are being braoadcast on behalf of the British Government.
('35', 72, 1, 16, 127832) The second question is more difficult to answer.
('35', 72, 2, 17, 127881) If the question had been, what has India taught to the world, I could have referred the questioner to Max Muller’s book What Can India Teach Us?.
('35', 72, 2, 18, 128027) But the question here put is not in terms of the past of India but in terms of her present.
('35', 72, 2, 19, 128119) I must then frankly confess that at the present moment India can teach the world little.
('35', 72, 2, 20, 128208) She is trying to develop ability to vindicate her liberty by means strictly non violent and truthful.
('35', 72, 2, 21, 128310) Some of us who are in movement have an undying faith in those means, but it is not possible in an instant to transmit that faith to people outside India.
('35', 72, 2, 22, 128464) It is not possible to say that that faith is even the common property of educated India.
('35', 72, 2, 23, 128553) But there is no doubt that if India succeeds in regaining her liberty through non violent means, she would have delivered her message to the others who are fighting
('35', 72, 3, 24, 128718) 1 Vide “Notes”, 26 11 1925.
('35', 72, 4, 25, 128746) 2 Rabindranath Tagore
('35', 73, 0, 1, 128768) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 74
('35', 73, 1, 2, 128809) for it, and what is perhaps more, she would have made the largest contribution yet known to world peace.

('35', 77, 8, 27, 136394) 118. LETTER TO G. D. BIRLA
('35', 77, 9, 28, 136421) ASHRAM, SABARMATI, Friday, April 16, 1926
('35', 77, 10, 29, 136463) BHAISHRI GHANSHYAMDAS, I have your letter and the cheque for Rs. 26,000. I shall answer your questions regarding the Hindu Muslim riots, but the replies are not for the Press.
('35', 77, 10, 30, 136639) I have told you that I have no influence at all now
('35', 78, 0, 1, 136691) VOL.35 : 2 APRIL, 1926 7 JULY, 1926 79
('35', 78, 1, 2, 136730) over the Hindus, at any rate over that class among them which interests itself in these disturbances.
('35', 78, 1, 3, 136832) My views, therefore, are misunderstood.
('35', 78, 1, 4, 136872) Hence I believe that it is best for me to say nothing.
('35', 78, 1, 5, 136927) If the Government has banned processions and it is neces sary to take out one on some religious occasion, I would think it right to do so despite the Government ban.
('35', 78, 1, 6, 137093) But before starting the procession, I would apologize to the Muslims.
('35', 78, 1, 7, 137163) If they do not respond even to such a courteous gesture, I should go ahead with the procession and submit to any violence on their part.
('35', 78, 1, 8, 137300) If I do not have the strength for such non violence, I should provide myself with means for fighting before taking out the procession.
('35', 78, 1, 9, 137435) I would not dismiss grooms and other Muslim servants merely because they are Muslims.
('35', 78, 1, 10, 137521) But I would not retain a Muslim who was not sincere in his work or behaved rudely to me.
('35', 78, 1, 11, 137610) I do not believe that the Muslims are more markedly ungrateful than members of any other community, but I have observed that they lose temper more quickly.
('35', 78, 1, 12, 137766) It seems to me altogether wrong not to have a Muslim simply because he is a Muslim.
('35', 78, 1, 13, 137850) Those Hindus who do not approve of the non violent way or are not equipped to follow it should acquire the strength to fight it out physically.
('35', 78, 1, 14, 137994) If the Government takes sides with the Muslims, Hindus need not worry on that account.
('35', 78, 1, 15, 138081) They should not care for the Government.
('35', 78, 1, 16, 138122) They should fend for themselves, relying on their own strength without seeking its favour.
('35', 78, 1, 17, 138213) When the Hindus have cultivated sufficient courage for this, the Government will on its own maintain an impartial attitude, and the Muslims will not then look for its support.
('35', 78, 1, 18, 138389) In seeking the Government’s help, we neither serve our dharma nor give evid ence of manhood.
('35', 78, 1, 19, 138482) I would advise you to look at the matter dispa ssionately and go on with your work.
('35', 78, 1, 20, 138566) That is in the best interests of the Hindus, the only way of serving Hinduism, as I can say from my long experience of not less than thiry five years.
('35', 78, 1, 21, 138717) I was very pleased with your calm and brave attitude during the riots.
('35', 78, 1, 22, 138788) You should keep up that attitude and do what you think the situation calls for.
('35', 78, 1, 23, 138868) If there is anything in my reply which is not clear to you, please do write to me again.
('35', 78, 1, 24, 138957) I propose to accept a part of the loan you have promised for the All India Spinners’ Association against the stocks in Bombay.
('35', 78, 1, 25, 139084) The Association has two godowns in Bombay.
('35', 78, 1, 26, 139127) If you wish, you may take possession of one of them and acquire sufficient stocks to cover the loan to be kept there.
('35', 78, 1, 27, 139245) If you agree, we should like you to keep even
('35', 79, 0, 1, 139291) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 80
('35', 79, 1, 2, 139332) more so that we may be saved rent on one godown.
('35', 79, 1, 3, 139381) In that case, it should be so arranged that we can draw from those stocks whenever we want to.
('35', 79, 1, 4, 139476) There will be frequent additions to or withdrawal from the stocks which the Spinners’ Association will maintain besides what is required by way of security, so that you will have to permit easy access to them.
('35', 79, 1, 5, 139686) Yours, MOHANDAS
