('35', 87, 0, 1, 152725) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 88
('35', 87, 1, 2, 152766) 134. MY “KAMADHENU” 1
('35', 87, 2, 3, 152788) I know that I have been ridiculed by some people for calling the spinning wheel a gateway to my salvation.
('35', 87, 2, 4, 152895) But even so may, a person who makes himself a little ball of clay, gives to it the imposing name of Parthiweshwar Chintamani and concentrates on it all the faculties of his being in the hope of “seeing God face to face” by that means, be sneered at those who do not share his faith in the life giving power of his image.
('35', 87, 2, 5, 153216) But would he, madly bent as he is on attaining self realization, give up his worship on this account?
('35', 87, 2, 6, 153318) On the contrary he will strive on without flagging till success crowns his efforts, as in the end it must, while his detractors will only be the worse off for their gibes.
('35', 87, 2, 7, 153490) Similarly, if my conception of the spinning wheel comes from a pure heart, it will become to me the means of my salvation.
('35', 87, 2, 8, 153613) A faithful Hindu’s ears will automatically turn to the direction where Ramanama is being repeated, and for the time being all the evil passions will subside in him.
('35', 87, 2, 9, 153778) What does it matter if the repetition of that divine name fails to produce any impression on others?
('35', 87, 2, 10, 153879) A Hindu may not be in the least affected by the cry of Allah o Akbar, but a Mussalman is roused by it.
('35', 87, 2, 11, 153982) Similarly, a pious Englishman, the moment he is reminded of the presence within him of God, will be able to restrain his passions and compose him self for the time being.
('35', 87, 2, 12, 154153) As is the spirit behind worship, so is the fruit thereof.
('35', 87, 2, 13, 154211) It follows then that even if the spinning wheel be in itself nothing, and the virtues that I have attributed to it exist only in my imagination, it will still prove at least to me my Kamadhenu, i.e., Cow of Plenty.
('35', 87, 2, 14, 154426) I think of the poor of India every time that I draw a thread on the wheel.
('35', 87, 2, 15, 154501) The poor of India today have lost faith in God, more so in the middle classes or the rich.
('35', 87, 2, 16, 154592) For a person suffering from the pangs of hunger, and desiring nothing but to fill his belly, his belly is his God.
('35', 87, 2, 17, 154707) To him anyone who gives him bread is his Master.
('35', 87, 2, 18, 154756) Through him he may even see God.
('35', 87, 2, 19, 154789) To give alms to such persons, who are sound in all their limbs, is to debase oneself and them.
('35', 87, 2, 20, 154884) What they need is some kind of occupation, and the occupation that will give employment to millions can only be hand spinning.
('35', 87, 2, 21, 155011) But I can instill my faith in the potency of hand spinning in the minds of the toilers of India not by making speeches but only by spinning myself.
('35', 87, 2, 22, 155159) Therefore, I have described my spinning as a penance or sacrament.
('35', 87, 3, 23, 155226) 1 The Gujarati original of this appeared in Navajivan, 18 4 1926. This is an translation by Mahadev Desai.
('35', 88, 0, 1, 155333) VOL.35 : 2 April, 1926 7 July, 1926 89
('35', 88, 1, 2, 155372) And, since I believe that where there is pure and active love for the poor there is God also, I see God in every thread that I draw on the spinning wheel.
('35', 88, 1, 3, 155527) WHY SHOULD YOU SPIN?
('35', 88, 1, 4, 155548) So much for my conception of the spinning wheel.
('35', 88, 1, 5, 155597) If you can accept my viewpoint, then nothing more remains to be desired.
('35', 88, 1, 6, 155670) But it is likely that it may not be acceptable to you.
('35', 88, 1, 7, 155725) Even then there is a host of reasons why you should spin.
('35', 88, 1, 8, 155783) I give below only a few of them : 1. You can make others spin only if you spin yourself.
('35', 88, 1, 9, 155872) 2. You can, by yourself spinning and giving your yarn to the All India Spinners’ Association, in the end help to make possible a reduction in the prices of khadi.
('35', 88, 1, 10, 156035) 3. By learning to spin, you can now or at any future time, whenever you may wish, help the propaganda of spinning.
('35', 88, 1, 11, 156150) Experience has shown that those who are ignorant even of the alpha and omega of the art of spinning are of no use for such work.
('35', 88, 1, 12, 156279) 4. If you will yourself spin, the quality of spinning will improve.
('35', 88, 1, 13, 156347) Those who spin for wages must naturally be impatient.
('35', 88, 1, 14, 156401) They will continue to spin the count that they are accustomed to.
('35', 88, 1, 15, 156467) The task of imroving the count of yarn essentially belongs to the research worker, the lover of spinning.
('35', 88, 1, 16, 156573) This has been proved by experience.
('35', 88, 1, 17, 156609) If there had not arisen a class of spinners, including both men and women, who spin purely out of a spirit of service the amazing progress that has been achieved in the quality of yarn would not have been possible.
('35', 88, 1, 18, 156824) 5. If you spin, your talents can be utilized in effecting improvements in the mechanism of the spinning wheel.
('35', 88, 1, 19, 156935) All the improvements that have been made in the mechanism of the spinning wheel and the speed of spinning up till now are solely due to the efforts of those devoted workers who spin for sacrifice.
('35', 88, 1, 20, 157132) 6. The ancient art of India is today gradually suffering extinction.
('35', 88, 1, 21, 157201) Its revival to a very large extent depends on the revival of hand spinning.
('35', 88, 1, 22, 157277) That there is art in spinning, those who have practised it as a sacrament know well enough.
('35', 88, 1, 23, 157369) During the Satyagraha Week, the spinners would not tire of spinning at all.
('35', 88, 1, 24, 157445) Of course, one of the reasons why they did not feel any weariness was certainly the spirit in which they had undertaken it.
('35', 88, 1, 25, 157569) But, if there were no art in spinning, if there were no music in it, it would have become impossible for those young men who span for twenty two and a half hours out of twenty 
('35', 89, 0, 1, 157746) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 90
('35', 89, 1, 2, 157787) It should be borne in mind in this connection that these spinners were not induced to the effort by hope of gaining any prize.
('35', 89, 1, 3, 157914) The spinning was its own reward.
('35', 89, 1, 4, 157947) 7. In our country manual labour is regarded as a low occupation.
('35', 89, 1, 5, 158012) Our poets have gone so far as to describe the happy rich as never having to touch mother earth at all, so much so that hair begins to grow on the soles of their feet!
('35', 89, 1, 6, 158179) Thus the highest function (body labour) to which a man is born and with which, the sages tell us, Brahma created him, we have in fact looked down upon as something mean and degrading.
('35', 89, 1, 7, 158363) We should spin therefore if only to guard against the pernicious tendency of regarding the toilers as being low in the social scale.
('35', 89, 1, 8, 158496) Spinning is therefore as obligatory on the prince as on the peasant.
('35', 89, 1, 9, 158565) TO THE JUVENILES All the foregoing reasons apply to you irrespective of the sex to which you belong.
('35', 89, 1, 10, 158666) But there are some additional reasons why you in particular should spin.
('35', 89, 1, 11, 158739) It is to these that I now want to draw your attention : 1. How nice it would be for you to labour for the poor from your childhood : spinning will nourish your sense of philanthropy in the right way.
('35', 89, 1, 12, 158939) 2. If you do your spinning at a fixed time every day you will develop in you the sense of regularity.
('35', 89, 1, 13, 159041) For, if you are regu lar in spinning, you will try to be regular in other things also, and it is the universal experience that a boy with regular habits does twice the amount of work that a boy does who works irregu larly.
('35', 89, 1, 14, 159264) 3. It will develop your sense of tidiness; for, without tidiness, good yarn cannot be spun at all.
('35', 89, 1, 15, 159363) You will have to keep your slivers clean, your hands likewise clean and free from perspiration.
('35', 89, 1, 16, 159459) You will have to see also that the place around you is free from dust, etc.
('35', 89, 1, 17, 159535) After spinning you will have to wind your yarn tidily on the winding frame, then carefully spray it and finally make it into a neat fine hank.
('35', 89, 1, 18, 159678) 4. It will enable you to learn how to effect repairs in a simple machine.
('35', 89, 1, 19, 159752) Ordinarily boys and girls of India are not given this training.
('35', 89, 1, 20, 159816) If you are lazy and get your servant or some older relative to clean your wheel for you, you will miss this training; but I have taken it for granted that every child who sends or will send his yarn to the All India Spinners’ Association is fond of his wheel.
('35', 89, 1, 21, 160076) Besides, a boy who does his spinning with interest will master all the details about the
('35', 90, 0, 1, 160165) VOL.35 : 2 April, 1926 7 July, 1926 91
('35', 90, 1, 2, 160204) various parts of his spinning wheel.
('35', 90, 1, 3, 160241) A carpenter always cleans his own tools.
('35', 90, 1, 4, 160282) And, just as a carpenter who does not know how to clean his own tools can hardly be ranked as a carpenter, similarly, a boy who cannot prepare his own mal (winding string), make his own sari (composition applied to the spindle where the mal touches it) or prepare his spindle holders, can hardly be called a spinner; he is only the travesty of a spinner.
('35', 90, 1, 5, 160637) Young India, 20 5 1926
('35', 90, 2, 6, 160660) 135. NOTES
('35', 90, 3, 7, 160671) “P RANA PRATISHTHA” INTO THE BHILS Shri Amritlal proposes once again to hold a fair for the Bhils 1
('35', 90, 4, 8, 160771) on the forthcoming Rama navami 2 day.
('35', 90, 4, 9, 160809) On that occasion a temple to Ramachandra is to be declared open, that is, there will be prana pratishtha 3 into the idol of Rama.
('35', 90, 4, 10, 160939) Why may we not call it prana pratishtha into the Bhils?
('35', 90, 4, 11, 160995) Shri Amritlal has shown us our duty towards them.
('35', 90, 4, 12, 161045) We hardly ever accept them as human beings.
('35', 90, 4, 13, 161089) The Government has also classified them as a scheduled tribe.
('35', 90, 4, 14, 161151) Thus neither society nor the Government takes interest in them.
('35', 90, 4, 15, 161215) These so called uncivilized communities are bound to attract the attention of the missionaries, for it is the latter’s duty to get recruits for the Christian Army.

('35', 95, 2, 3, 171200) USE QUININE REGULARLY!
('35', 95, 3, 4, 171223) I do not take quinine now.

('35', 95, 5, 14, 171857) This too I took dissolved in lemon juice, soda and water.
('35', 95, 5, 15, 171915) I certainly did not take more than thirty grains in the course of five days.
('35', 95, 5, 16, 171992) On four days I took only five grains a day.
('35', 95, 5, 17, 172036) After taking this much of quinine, I experienced no bad effects and, what is more, I was able to please many friends and doctors who urged me to take doses of fifteen grains.

('35', 113, 11, 22, 208675) 156. WARNING TO YARN COLLECTORS
('35', 113, 12, 23, 208707) Much of the yarn that is delivered to the All India Spinners’ Association as subscription is collected by local volunteer collectors.
('35', 113, 12, 24, 208841) Thereby much time, energy and expense are saved.
('35', 113, 12, 25, 208890) But the collectors should be good spinners themselves.
('35', 113, 12, 26, 208945) They must be able to distinguish good yarn from bad and know the different counts.
('35', 113, 12, 27, 209028) For the value of the yarn can be immediately increased if the collectors know how to judge yarn and take the trouble of examining it before accepting it from subscribers.
('35', 113, 12, 28, 209199) They have to take only such yarn as is evenly spun and made into standard strands, i.e., 4 ft.
('35', 113, 12, 29, 209294) in length.
('35', 113, 12, 30, 209305) The greater the
('35', 114, 0, 1, 209321) VOL.35 : 2 April, 1926 7 July, 1926 115
('35', 114, 1, 2, 209361) attention paid to these details, the greater the chance of producing stronger khadi at cheaper rates.
('35', 114, 1, 3, 209463) The spinners should bear in mind that the better they spin, the larger is their subscription to the Association.
('35', 114, 1, 4, 209576) That is the beauty of having subscriptions in yarn.
('35', 114, 1, 5, 209628) If collectors and subscribing spinners do their work carefully, they can double the value of subscription whilst it will mean no more work for the collectors or the spinners and certainly no more expense.
('35', 114, 1, 6, 209833) Whereas, if the yarn is spun anyhow or packed anyhow, it throws a useless burden upon the Spinners’ Association and means avoidable waste of national energy and capital.
('35', 114, 1, 7, 210003) Young India, 22 4 1926

('35', 114, 4, 18, 210782) 158. DRUGS, DRINK AND DEVIL
('35', 114, 5, 19, 210810) Drugs and drink are the two arms of the devil with which he strikes his helpless slaves into stupefaction and intoxication.
('35', 114, 5, 20, 210934) And according to an illuminating article 2 in The Survey on the two Opium Conferences at Geneva, opium, the chief among the drugs, “won”.
('35', 114, 5, 21, 211072) The writer says :
('35', 114, 6, 22, 211090) Out of all the marching and counter marching, the drawing of swords and putting up them again, the rumours of defeats and famous victories, the traffic
('35', 114, 7, 23, 211242) 1 Vide “Letter to Sarat Chandra Bose”, 9 4 1926 and “Assorted Questions [—V]”, 18 4 1926, sub title, “What then Shall We Do?”.
('35', 114, 7, 24, 211369) 2 Of which only excerpts are reproduced here
('35', 115, 0, 1, 211414) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 116
('35', 115, 1, 2, 211456) in opium and other narcotic drugs has gained a new lease of life.
('35', 115, 1, 3, 211522) In the midst of confusion and chaos caused by the bewildering reports on behalf of the different nations, the writer says :
('35', 115, 2, 4, 211646) The only people concerned who knew precisely what they wanted and did not want, and who were quite clear about and content with what they got, were those who in one way or another make profit out of the traffic in narcotics.
('35', 115, 2, 5, 211871) The writer adds :
('35', 115, 3, 6, 211889) Especially during the World War, the campaign has been going almost by default.
('35', 115, 3, 7, 211969) Indeed, the War itself materially aggravated the evil.
('35', 115, 3, 8, 212024) The widespread use of morphine and cocaine in the armies as anodynes against human agony, and to some extent as a means of mental relief from the deadly despairs and fears, disgusts and monotonies of war, turned loose at the end in many countries a considerable army of uncured and more or less incurable addicts to continue and spread their addiction.
('35', 115, 3, 9, 212377) For, one of the awful concomitants of this vice is a kind of perverted missionary impulse to propagate itself by making new addicts.
('35', 115, 3, 10, 212510) This is one of the most deadly by products of the late War.
('35', 115, 3, 11, 212570) If it has destroyed millions of lives, it has also hastened the soul deadening process.
('35', 115, 3, 12, 212658) But Mr. Gavit, the writer, shows that during the thirteen years since the international agreement was registered in the Hague Convention “the character of the problem has changed greatly”.
('35', 115, 3, 13, 212847) Mr. Gavit can only speak from the European standpoint.
('35', 115, 3, 14, 212902) Therefore, he says :
('35', 115, 4, 15, 212923) The evil is no longer an exotic affair of the Far East, of the eating, drinking and smoking of the raw and prepared opium after the time entrenched fashions of India, China and other oriental regions.
('35', 115, 4, 16, 213124) It has now resolved itself into the use
('35', 115, 5, 17, 213164) of the more concentrated and far more injurious forms in the highpower drugs,
('35', 115, 6, 18, 213242) manufactured in the expensively equipped and scientifically operated pharmaceutical laboratories of the lands which call themselves “civilized”.
('35', 115, 6, 19, 213387) Whereas in the former time the opium and the opium habits of the Far East were creeping out into the West, now the flow is the other way.
('35', 115, 6, 20, 213525) And that is not all : These drugs are equally deadly, and spreading ominously, in the countries where they are made, and across their borders to their neighbours.
('35', 115, 6, 21, 213688) The threat is against the welfare of all mankind.
('35', 115, 6, 22, 213738) To this devil a white addict is as useful as a black or yellow; .
('35', 115, 6, 23, 213804) His is a domain upon which the sun never sets.
('35', 115, 6, 24, 213851) The writer then touches “the heart of the evil” which is in “the excess of production” beyond the very legitimate needs of medicine and science.
('35', 116, 0, 1, 213996) VOL.35 : 2 April, 1926 7 July, 1926 117
('35', 116, 1, 2, 214036) Thus the world’s production of narcotics is more than ten times the most extravagant estimate of the world’s legitimate needs.
('35', 116, 1, 3, 214163) The writer shows that none of the great powers including America and Great Britain has seriously tackled the problem.
('35', 116, 1, 4, 214281) He charges them with having broken the promise made under Article 9 of the Hague Convention—“to limit the manufacture of these substances to the bona fide needs of medicine and science.” He deplores that these civilized nations have failed not merely to check the over production of raw and prepared opium but have failed to check even the manufacture of the deadly drugs in the huge laboratories which are subject to licence and inspection and whose control is the easiest thing possible if there is only the will.
('35', 116, 1, 5, 214797) The readers who have studied the Assam Opium Report prepared at the instance of the Congress by Mr. Andrews’ labours know the evil wrought by the opium habit.
('35', 116, 1, 6, 214956) They also know how the Government has failed egregiously to deal with the growing evil and how they have thwarted the efforts of reformers who tried to deal with it.
('35', 116, 1, 7, 215122) It therefore did one’s soul good to find that during the National Week, speakers at public meetings insisted upon the total prohibition of intoxicating drinks and drugs.
('35', 116, 1, 8, 215292) It is a reform that is overdue.
('35', 116, 1, 9, 215324) And, if it is at all worth going to the Councils, this total prohibition must be made a prominent plank in the electroral compaign.
('35', 116, 1, 10, 215456) Every member must be pledged not merely to support but to initiate and pursue the total prohibition campaign, the only way to bring about total prohibition being to cut out from the military expenditure a portion equivalent to the revenue derived from this immoral source.
('35', 116, 1, 11, 215729) The demand therefore for total prohibition must go hand in hand with the demand for reduction in the military expenditure.
('35', 116, 1, 12, 215852) Nor must the solution be delayed by plans of taking referendums.
('35', 116, 1, 13, 215917) In India there can be no reason for any referendum because drink and drug habits are universally recognized as a vice.
('35', 116, 1, 14, 216036) Drink is not a fashion in India as it is in the West.
('35', 116, 1, 15, 216090) To talk therefore of a referendum in India is to trifle with the problem.

('35', 119, 2, 4, 221195) 160. FOR AND AGAINST KHADI
('35', 119, 3, 5, 221222) AGAINST KHADI
('35', 119, 4, 6, 221236) A correspondent writes a Gujarati letter of which the following is a free rendering : I am a stenographer.
('35', 119, 4, 7, 221343) I applied in reply to an advertisement by a well known European firm for the post of a stenographer at its office and I received a reply asking me to report myself at their office.
('35', 119, 4, 8, 221524) As soon as I was ushered into the presence of the manager, he scanned my dress and seeing that it was all pure khadi said, ‘You are no use.
('35', 119, 4, 9, 221664) Don’t you know that those who wear khadi dress need not expect any employment in European firms?’ And with this he dismissed me leaving me to wonder what connection my dress had with my ability to take down correct notes.
('35', 119, 4, 10, 221886) I returned home feeling thankful that I had the courage to withstand the temptation of giving up my khadi dress for the sake of a comfortable employment.
('35', 119, 4, 11, 222040) I hope that God will sustain that courage and that even when I am sorely tried, I shall not give up khadi which I know binds me to the poor of the land.
('35', 119, 4, 12, 222193) I send you this information in order that it may serve as a warning to others against relying upon getting employment in European firms except on humiliating terms.
('35', 119, 4, 13, 222358) I congratulate the young stenographer upon his self sacrifice and join my hope with his that God will sustain his courage even though he might have a series of disappointments when he tries to get employed as a stenographer.
('35', 119, 5, 14, 222583) FOR KHADI But all European employers are not cast in the same mould.
('35', 119, 5, 15, 222652) When I was in Calcutta last year, I came in touch with many European mer chants and some of the leading ones amongst them not only had no ob jection to their employees wearing khadi dress but they avowed sympathy with the khadi movement and appreciated the sentiment that requires Indians and, indeed, those who make fortunes in India, to use cloth spun and woven by the toiling millions.
('35', 119, 5, 16, 223041) Here is a letter from an Indian employee which the readers of Young India will read with
('35', 120, 0, 1, 223130) VOL.35 : 2 April, 1926 7 July, 1926 121
('35', 120, 1, 2, 223170) pleasure : 1
('35', 120, 2, 3, 223183) I congratulate the European firm upon their breadth of vision for it was no doubt something for them not to be carried away by prejudice when Non co operation was at its height and when khadi dress was mixed up by so many Europeans with violent intentions.
('35', 120, 2, 4, 223440) Young India, 22 4 1926

('35', 129, 3, 9, 237148) 176. STATEMENT ON SOUTH AFRICAN INDIAN PROBLEM
('35', 129, 4, 10, 237195) AHMEDABAD, April 24, 1926
('35', 129, 5, 11, 237221) Mr. Gandhi has issued the following statement to the Associated Press on the latest announcement regarding acceptance by the Union Government of the offer of the Government of India for a conference to arrive at an amicable solution of the Indian Problem : The news from South Africa is certainly welcome.
('35', 129, 5, 12, 237527) It enables Indian settlers to have a breathing time and upon this happy result all parties, the Union Government, the Government of India and the settlers, may congratulate themselves.
('35', 129, 5, 13, 237712) In my opinion the real credit belongs to Mr. C.F. Andrews without whose incessant energy, prayerful watchfulness and detailed study of the situation, combined with rare faith in the cause he was espousing, this happy result could not have been obtained.
('35', 129, 5, 14, 237966) If the Union Government’s proviso is honestly meant, its ac ceptance by the Government of India does not much matter.
('35', 129, 5, 15, 238084) The Union Government is undoubtedly entitled to safeguard what they call Western standard of life by just and legitimate means and the only just and legitimate means that can be accepted are sanitary and economic laws.
('35', 129, 5, 16, 238303) Thus, for instance, Indian lawyers must compete with European lawyers on equal terms and so far as I am aware no Indian lawyer does otherwise.
('35', 129, 5, 17, 238446) But I have discovered that there is discrimination used even against them.
('35', 129, 5, 18, 238521) I believe the Paddison Deputation, which, in spite of my non co operation I am free to confess, has deserved well, made the discovery that even in the Supreme Court clerks who appear before the Registrar on business must not be wearers of any but white skin.
('35', 130, 0, 1, 238780) VOL.35 : 2 April, 1926 7 July, 1926 131
('35', 130, 1, 2, 238820) that is called safeguarding Western standards of life by just and legitimate means the proviso is dangerous.
('35', 130, 1, 3, 238929) But I am an optimist.
('35', 130, 1, 4, 238951) I shall take the proviso at its face value and if the Government of India will insist upon its being strictly interpreted all will be well.
('35', 130, 1, 5, 239091) I hope that neither the Government of India nor the public will relax their watchfulness if a final and honourable settlement is to be secured.
('35', 130, 1, 6, 239235) Now that there is to be a conference, India has the right to hope that all questions that arise out of the Bill will be examined and dealt with in a just manner.
('35', 130, 1, 7, 239397) The Indian settlers have nothing to fear from a most searching enquiry into the question and I make bold to say that at the end of the enquiry it will be found that the only crime that can be proved against them is that they are Asiatics and have a skin which has all shades of colour.
('35', 130, 1, 8, 239683) The economic question was laid at rest when in 1914 all fear of unrestricted emigration from India to South Africa was absolutely laid at rest.
('35', 130, 1, 9, 239827) The figures produced before the Select Committee have conclusively proved that the numerical strength of Indian settlers is on the decrease whereas that of the white settlers is on the increase.
('35', 130, 1, 10, 240022) There is no comparison between the insignificant value of Indian holdings and the extraordinary increase in the value of European holdings.
('35', 130, 1, 11, 240162) Indian trade licences every where are also dwindling.
('35', 130, 1, 12, 240216) If only South African statesmen will face facts squarely it will be found that there is no case against the Indian settlers.
('35', 130, 1, 13, 240341) But at the present moment I want neither to anticipate nor to criticize.
('35', 130, 1, 14, 240414) I have nothing but a feeling of relief and thankfulness.
('35', 130, 1, 15, 240471) I tender my congratulations to General Hertzog and Dr. Malan upon their having risen to the occasion.

('35', 135, 9, 16, 248198) I am myself totally against vaccination.
('35', 135, 9, 17, 248239) But this is a matter in which everybody must decide for himself and not merely copy the views of others; for, after all it may sometimes become a question of life and death.
('35', 135, 9, 18, 248413) It is impossible to assert positively that no one has been saved from an attack of small pox or worse by being vaccinated.
('35', 135, 9, 19, 248536) He, therefore, who refrains from vannination, does so with the full knowledge that he runs the risk of himself and his children being disfigured by small pox and even meeting death.
('35', 135, 9, 20, 248718) At the same time, this is true that vaccination does not afford an absolute gurantee against small pox.
('35', 135, 9, 21, 248822) Therefore those only will not be vaccinated who hold the body subservient to the soul and have an inner conviction that vaccination is hurtful for the soul.

('35', 136, 9, 22, 250546) The process through which the soul has been passing is an effort of the heart.
('35', 136, 9, 23, 250625) The intellect has been hooked to its service by prayer, meditation and constant watchfulness which are essentially matters of the heart and which have been the predominant factors that have contributed to the growing revelation of truth.
('35', 136, 9, 24, 250863) I have never felt that whatever knowledge has been gained was imposed from without
('35', 137, 0, 1, 250946) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 138

('35', 137, 11, 18, 251770) BHAISHRI PURUSHOTTAM, The present state of Hindu society makes one feel sad, but, being an optimist, I have hopes for the future.

('35', 140, 1, 8, 256439) If we resolve to do all we can to end that suffering and firmly refuse to take up any other task, we shall have carried the load of the entire hill.

('35', 142, 1, 4, 260522) HOW A “S ANATANI” MAY ACT A learned and orthodox Hindu, who subscribes himself as “A Santani Hindu”, writes : 1
('35', 142, 2, 5, 260634) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 25 4 1926
('35', 142, 3, 6, 260671) 195. ABOLISH MARRIAGE !
('35', 142, 4, 7, 260695) A correspondent, whom I know well, raises an issue, I take it, for purely academic interest, because I know the views he has set out are not his.
('35', 142, 4, 8, 260841) ‘Is not our present day morality unnatural?’ he asks.
('35', 142, 4, 9, 260895) If it was natural it should have been the same everywhere in all ages, but every race and community seems to have its own peculiar marriage laws and in enforcing them men have made themselves worse than beasts.
('35', 142, 4, 10, 261106) For diseases which are unknown amongst animals are quite common amongst men; infanticide, abortions, child marriages, which are impossible in the brute creation, are the curse of the society that holds up marriage as a sacrament, and no end of evil results have sprung from what we uphold as laws of morality.
('35', 142, 4, 11, 261416) And the miserable condition of Hindu widows—what is it due to, but to the existing marriage laws?
('35', 142, 4, 12, 261514) Why not go back to nature, and take a leaf out of the book of the brute creation?
('35', 142, 4, 13, 261596) I do not know whether the advocates of free love in the West resort to the argument summarized above or have any stronger reasons to put forth, but I am sure that the tendency to regard the marriage bond as barbarous is distinctly Western.
('35', 142, 4, 14, 261836) If the argument is also borrowed from the West, there is no difficulty about meeting it.
('35', 142, 5, 15, 261925) 1 The letter is not translated here.
('35', 142, 5, 16, 261962) The correspondent had quoted, in connection with the temple entry movement in the South, a Sanskrit stanza which said that one need not take a bath after touching a Chandala waiting outside a temple to have a glimpse of the deity’s image.
('35', 142, 5, 17, 262201) 2 The Gujarati original of this appeared in Navajivan, 25 4 1926. This is a condensed translation by Mahadev Desai.
('35', 143, 0, 1, 262317) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 144
('35', 143, 1, 2, 262359) It is a mistake to institute a comparison between man and the brute and it is this comparison that vitiates the whole argument.
('35', 143, 1, 3, 262487) For man is higher than the brute in his moral instincts and moral institutions.
('35', 143, 1, 4, 262567) The law of nature as applied to the one is different from the law of nature as applied to the other.
('35', 143, 1, 5, 262668) Man has reason, discrimination, and free will such as it is.
('35', 143, 1, 6, 262729) The brute has no such thing.
('35', 143, 1, 7, 262758) It is not a free agent, and knows no distinction between virtue and vice, good and evil.
('35', 143, 1, 8, 262847) Man, being a free agent, knows these distinctions, and when he follows his higher nature shows himself far superior to the brute, but when he folows his baser nature, can show himself lower than the brute.
('35', 143, 1, 9, 263053) Even the races regarded as the most uncivilized on earth accept some restriction on sexual relations.
('35', 143, 1, 10, 263155) If it be said that the restriction is itself barbarous, then freedom from all restraints should be the law of man.
('35', 143, 1, 11, 263270) If all men were to act according to this lawless law, there would be perfect chaos within twenty four hours.
('35', 143, 1, 12, 263379) Man being by nature more passionate than the brute, the moment all restraint is withdrawn, the lava of unbridled passion would overspread the whole earth and destroy mankind.
('35', 143, 1, 13, 263554) Man is superior to the brute inasmuch as he is capable of self restraint and sacrifice, of which the brute is incapable.
('35', 143, 1, 14, 263675) Some of the diseases that are so common at the present day are the result of infringement of marriage laws.
('35', 143, 1, 15, 263783) I should like to know a single instance of a man strictly observing the restraint of the marriage bond having suffered from the diseases the correspondent has in mind.
('35', 143, 1, 16, 263951) Infanticide, child marriage and the like are also the result of the breach of marriage laws.
('35', 143, 1, 17, 264044) For the law lays down that a man or woman shall choose a mate only when he or she has come of age, is healthy, and capable of restraint, and desires to have progeny.
('35', 143, 1, 18, 264210) Those who strictly obey this law, and regard the marriage bond as a sacrament, have never an occasion to be unhappy or miserable.
('35', 143, 1, 19, 264340) Where marriage is a sacrament, the union is not the union of bodies but the union of souls indissoluble even by the death of either party.
('35', 143, 1, 20, 264479) Where there is a true union of souls, the remarriage of a widow or widower is unthinkable, improper and wrong.
('35', 143, 1, 21, 264590) Marriages, where the true law of marriage is ignored, do not deserve the name.
('35', 143, 1, 22, 264669) If we have very few true marriages nowadays, it is not the institution of marriage that is to blame, but the prevailing form of it, which should be reformed.
('35', 143, 1, 23, 264827) The correspondent contends that marriage is no moral or religious bond but a custom, and a custom which is opposed to religion and mora lity, and hence deserves to be abolished.
('35', 143, 1, 24, 265005) I submit
('35', 144, 0, 1, 265014) VOL.35 : 2 APRIL, 1926 7 JULY, 1926 145
('35', 144, 1, 2, 265054) that marriage is a fence that protects religion.
('35', 144, 1, 3, 265103) If the fence were to be destroyed religion would go to pieces.
('35', 144, 1, 4, 265166) The foundation of religion is restraint and marriage is nothing but restraint.
('35', 144, 1, 5, 265245) The man who knows no restraint has no hope of self realization.
('35', 144, 1, 6, 265309) I confess it may be dificult to prove the necessity of restraint to an atheist or a materialist.
('35', 144, 1, 7, 265406) But he who knows the perishable nature of flesh from the imperishable nature of the spirit instinctively knows that self realization is impossible without self discipline and self restraint.
('35', 144, 1, 8, 265597) The body may either be a play ground of passion or a temple of self realization.
('35', 144, 1, 9, 265678) If it is the latter, there is no room there for liberatinism.
('35', 144, 1, 10, 265740) The spirit needs must curb the flesh every moment.
('35', 144, 1, 11, 265791) Woman will be the apple of discord where the marriage bond is loose, where there is no observance of the law of restraint.
('35', 144, 1, 12, 265914) If men were as unrestrained as the brutes they would straightway take the road to destruction.
('35', 144, 1, 13, 266009) I am firmly of opinion that all the evils that the correspondent complains of can be eradicated not by abolishing marriage but by a systematic understanding and observance of the law of marriage.
('35', 144, 1, 14, 266205) I agree that whereas amongst some communities marriage is permitted amongst very near relations, it is prohibited among other communities, that whereas some communities forbid polygamy some permit it.
('35', 144, 1, 15, 266406) Whilst one would wish that there was a uniform moral law accepted by all communities, the diversity does not point to the necessity of abolishing all restraint.
('35', 144, 1, 16, 266567) As we grow wise in experience our morality will gain in uniformity.
('35', 144, 1, 17, 266635) Even today the moral sense of the world holds up monogamy as the highest ideal and no religion makes polygamy obligatory.
('35', 144, 1, 18, 266757) The ideal remains unaffected by the relaxation of practice according to time and place.
('35', 144, 1, 19, 266845) I need not reiterate my views regarding remarriage of widows, as I consider remarriage of virgin widows not only desirable but the bounden duty of all parents who happen to have such widowed daughters.

('35', 154, 6, 19, 282836) 211. SOUTH AFRICA
('35', 154, 7, 20, 282854) The Government of India has every reason to congratulate itself upon the diplomatic victory it has gained in South Africa.
('35', 154, 7, 21, 282977) I have shown elsewhere 2 that nothing could have been done in South Africa but for the extraordinary faith and labours of C. F. Andrews.
('35', 154, 7, 22, 283114) Nevertheless had the Government of India been at all remiss in its prosecution of the Indian claim, the Areas Reservation Bill would certainly have been passed by the Union Parliament.
('35', 154, 7, 23, 283299) It is a great gain that the Bill has been postponed and a conference agreed upon.
('35', 154, 7, 24, 283381) But there is a fly in the ointment.
('35', 154, 7, 25, 283417) The Union Government’s condition and its acceptance by the Government of India that the resolution must “safeguard Western standards of life by just and legitimate means” may make an equitable solution impossible.
('35', 154, 8, 26, 283631) 1 From the postmark 2 Vide “Statement on South African Indian Problem”, 24 4 1926.
('35', 155, 0, 1, 283714) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 156
('35', 155, 1, 2, 283756) is the meaning of “safeguarding Western standards of life” or of “just and legitimate means”?
('35', 155, 1, 3, 283850) The safeguard may mean, for instance, that the indentured Indian working on the plantations and getting perhaps 30 shillings per month should live like the European artisan in a five roomed brick built cottage and wear the European costume from top to toe and eat European food; and “just and legitimate means” may be compulsory deportation of those indentured Indians who do not conform to the impossible safeguard; or “safeguarding by just and legitimate means” may mean reasonable sanitary and economic laws of common applicability ensuring on the part of all a standard of life in keeping with sanitary and hygienic requirements and regulation of all business in conformity to the European standard.
('35', 155, 1, 4, 284554) Indians would have and should have no objection to the latter interpretation.
('35', 155, 1, 5, 284632) Never have objections been raised to general sanitary or economic requirements.
('35', 155, 1, 6, 284712) But the correspondence just published enables me to under stand what the Union Government will want.
('35', 155, 1, 7, 284813) That Government wants repatriation, not reformation.
('35', 155, 1, 8, 284866) It would not be party to the holding of a conference if the Government of India would not consent to that question being favourably considered at the Con ference.
('35', 155, 1, 9, 285029) Lord Reading cleverly got out of the difficulty by saying he had no objection to voluntary repatriation as limited by the Indian Relief Act being discussed.
('35', 155, 1, 10, 285186) The Union Government could not very well insist upon the precise terms of repatriation being previously accepted.
('35', 155, 1, 11, 285300) They therefore discovered the new formula of conformity to “Western standards of life”.
('35', 155, 1, 12, 285388) On the face of it, the condition is harmless enough.
('35', 155, 1, 13, 285441) But it can be made to cover, as I have shown, impossibilities.
('35', 155, 1, 14, 285504) Much will therefore depend upon what mentalities both parties bring to the Conference and what strength the Government of India shows.
('35', 155, 1, 15, 285639) Hitherto it has surrendered the Indian claim every time there has been a tussle and has claimed it as a virtue that it has not yielded all the Union Government has aimed at.
('35', 155, 1, 16, 285813) This is as much as to say that the judge in a cause did not permit the thief to retain all he had stolen.
('35', 155, 1, 17, 285919) It must never be forgotten that every time the South African Government has admittedly without just cause sought to deprive the Indian settler of his just rights as a peaceful citizen of South Africa.
('35', 155, 1, 18, 286120) The Government of India to be true to its trust should therefore have been able to show a record at each tussle of recovery of lost ground.
('35', 155, 1, 19, 286260) The fact however is that had not the settlers in 1907 taken the law, as it were, into their own hands, they would have lost all, the
('35', 156, 0, 1, 286393) VOL.35 : 2 APRIL, 1926 7 JULY, 1926 157
('35', 156, 1, 2, 286433) Government of India being privy to it.
('35', 156, 1, 3, 286472) For the Indian and the Imperial Governments had already consented in 1907 to the brutal Asiatic Act—the same that was in 1906 vetoed by Lord Elgin, the then Secretary of State for the Colonies.
('35', 156, 1, 4, 286666) Though, therefore, the postponement of the Bill and the Conference is a tremendous step gained in the present campaign, if the Government of India weaken in the final heat, the present advantage will be counted as a wasted effort.
('35', 156, 1, 5, 286897) The public has thus as great need to be watchful as ever if the advantage is not to be lost.
('35', 156, 1, 6, 286990) The breathing time must be fully utilized for a close study of the problem and for elucidating the fact that the only crime provable against the Indian settler is his Asiatic birth and the possession of a coloured pigment.
('35', 156, 1, 7, 287213) It is statutory crime.
('35', 156, 1, 8, 287236) For, the South African constitution in effect says : “There shall be no equality between whites on the one hand, and coloured and asiatic races on the other.” South Africa believes as much in hereditary caste as we do in India.
('35', 156, 1, 9, 287464) Lastly, I must not omit to reiterate the opinion given in these columns that the salvation of the settlers lies finally in their own hands.
('35', 156, 1, 10, 287604) The Government of India, public opinion, and even the Union Government and the white people of South Africa will help them if they will help themselves.
('35', 156, 1, 11, 287757) Let them remove the slightest cause of complaint against them whether on grounds of hygience or economics.
('35', 156, 1, 12, 287864) In all things not immoral let them do “in Rome as Romans do”.
('35', 156, 1, 13, 287926) Let them be and remain absolutely united.
('35', 156, 1, 14, 287968) And above all let them be resolute in suffering for the common good.
('35', 156, 1, 15, 288037) Young India, 29 4 1926

('35', 157, 3, 6, 288982) 213. NOT QUANTITY BUT QUALITY
('35', 157, 4, 7, 289012) Times without number have I been asked : “What can be done if we are so few.
('35', 157, 4, 8, 289089) See how few spinners we have in the Spinners’ Association?
('35', 157, 4, 9, 289148) how few civil resisters?
('35', 157, 4, 10, 289173) How few pucka non co operators?
('35', 157, 4, 11, 289205) How few prohibitionists?” All this is, alas, too true.
('35', 157, 4, 12, 289260) But when we come to think of it, what is there in numbers?
('35', 157, 4, 13, 289319) The more relevant question is, how many true spinners, true civil resisters, true non co operators, true prohibitionists are there in the country?
('35', 157, 4, 14, 289466) It is character, determination, and courage that will count in the end.
('35', 157, 4, 15, 289538) And I wish I could say that we have 4,000 true spinners.
('35', 157, 4, 16, 289595) What is a true spinner?
('35', 157, 4, 17, 289619) A true spinner is not one who merely spins.
('35', 157, 4, 18, 289663) In that case we have not four thousand but probably four hundred thousand spinners.
('35', 157, 4, 19, 289747) It is not enough to spin.
('35', 157, 4, 20, 289773) It is necessary to spin even a strong yarn regularly for the sake of India’s paupers.
('35', 157, 4, 21, 289859) Spinning, therefore, must not be a task but it must be a pleasure.
('35', 157, 4, 22, 289926) It is not enough to belong to the Association but it is necessary to invite others to do likewise.
('35', 157, 4, 23, 290025) And a true spinner revolutionizes his life.
('35', 157, 4, 24, 290069) He therefore understands the gospel of simplicity, appreciates the dignity of body labour, recognizes that the greatest need of India is self reliance and therefore work for the millions in their own homes which they can do with the simplest tools.
('35', 157, 4, 25, 290318) One is told that the revolution in Japan was brought about not through thousands of men but at the head of it were only 12 men who fired the zeal of fifty five.
('35', 157, 4, 26, 290479) And, probably, amongst these 12 was only one man who was the author of the whole plan.
('35', 157, 4, 27, 290566) If a true beginning is made the rest is simple.
('35', 157, 4, 28, 290614) We therefore arrive at the astonishing conclusion, which is none the less true, that one true man is enough for any reform no matter how impossible it may appear in the beginning.
('35', 157, 4, 29, 290794) Ridicule, contempt and death may be and often is the
('35', 157, 5, 30, 290847) 1 Not reproduced here
('35', 158, 0, 1, 290869) VOL.35 : 2 APRIL, 1926 7 JULY, 1926 159
('35', 158, 1, 2, 290909) reward of such a man.
('35', 158, 1, 3, 290931) But though he may die, the reforms survive and prosper.
('35', 158, 1, 4, 290987) He ensures their stability with his blood.
('35', 158, 1, 5, 291030) I wish, therefore, that workers will think less of numbers irrespective of strength but more of the strength of the few.
('35', 158, 1, 6, 291151) It is depth more than the width that is wanted.
('35', 158, 1, 7, 291199) If we lay a stable foundation, posterity will be able to erect a solid structure upon it, whereas, if the foundation is built of sand, there will be no work for posterity except to dig out the sand to lay the foundation anew.
('35', 158, 1, 8, 291425) Young India, 29 4 1926
('35', 158, 2, 9, 291448) 214. NOTES
('35', 158, 3, 10, 291459) THE GOOD SAMARITAN I received the following cablegram from the Secretary, South African Indian Congress, Durban, before the decision of the South African Government was known :
('35', 158, 4, 11, 291636) Congress meeting assembled tender you grateful thanks for sending Mr. Andrews to South Africa, who nobly and strenuously worked bringing great change feeling both communities.
('35', 158, 4, 12, 291812) May he enjoy long life, continue his noble work cause of humanity.
('35', 158, 4, 13, 291879) I have withheld from the public similar cablegrams received during Mr. Andrews’ strenuous tour in South Africa but I felt I could no longer withhold the foregoing especially in view of the results attained.
('35', 158, 4, 14, 292086) I am aware that the services of this selfless Englishman have not been always properly understood.
('35', 158, 4, 15, 292185) He is no diplomat and therefore he sends cablegrams faithfully recording opinion and feelings from day to day.
('35', 158, 4, 16, 292296) He is therefore at times despondent, at times optimistic, but if one were patiently to collect all the cablegrams that he has been sending during the past few months, one would trace in them all a never to be missed ring of hope when to the sceptic there was no ground for hope.
('35', 158, 4, 17, 292575) His last cable to me on the eve of his departure from South Africa told me not to lose hope because he was hopeful.
('35', 158, 4, 18, 292691) If he had faith in the righteousness of the Indian cause, he had faith also in the South African statesmen.
('35', 158, 4, 19, 292799) Andrews is a humanitarian, pure and simple, and therefore he trusts everybody.
('35', 158, 4, 20, 292878) The whole world is free to deceive him and he would still say “Humanity!
('35', 158, 4, 21, 292951) With all thy faults I love thee still”.
('35', 158, 4, 22, 292991) And this love of his enables him to surmount all barriers and cut his way straight to the hearts of people.
('35', 158, 4, 23, 293099) He made himself heard in South Africa where, perhaps, others would have been hissed.
('35', 158, 4, 24, 293184) He paved the way for the Paddison deputation.
('35', 159, 0, 1, 293230) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 160
('35', 159, 1, 2, 293272) The mention of the Paddison deputation enables me to add the testimony I have received from South Africa to the one that Sjt.
('35', 159, 1, 3, 293398) C Rajagopalachariar gave in favour of Mr. Paddison when the deputation left.
('35', 159, 1, 4, 293475) This is what a correspondent has written from South Africa :
('35', 159, 2, 5, 293536) He is an Englishman by birth and an Indian in outlook.
('35', 159, 2, 6, 293591) In fact, I see no difference between him and Mr. Andrews.
('35', 159, 2, 7, 293649) It is a surprise that man of his talents should have risen no higher than the Labour Commissionership of Madras.
('35', 159, 2, 8, 293762) Whether his strong Indian sympathies are responsible for this is more than I know at present.
('35', 159, 2, 9, 293856) All accounts received by me show that the members of the deputation discharged their trust faithfully and well.
('35', 159, 2, 10, 293968) But even this deputation could not have done half as well as they did, without the spade work that was done by Andrews and the incessant toil put by him into it.
('35', 159, 2, 11, 294130) IN THE GRIP OF UNTOUCHABILITY We have heard much about untouchability and unapproachability of Travancore because there was satyagraha there.
('35', 159, 2, 12, 294272) The lamp of suffering brought the Travancore dirt to light but it seems that there is much more of it in Cochin than in Tranvancore.
('35', 159, 2, 13, 294405) There the repeated attempts to bring even a resolution before the Cochin Legislative Assembly asking the Cochin state to remove the ban on the use of public roads by untouchables was disallowed.
('35', 159, 2, 14, 294600) An assiduous member enquired in the Cochin Legislative Assembly : “How many tanks and wells maintained by Government or Municipal funds were closed to untouchables?” The reply was that 61 tanks and 123 wells were so closed.
('35', 159, 2, 15, 294824) It would have been interesting if a supplementary question had been asked to elicit how many wells and tanks were accessible to untouchables.
('35', 159, 2, 16, 294966) Another question asked was : “On what ground was the use of certain roads constructed and maintained by the Public Works Department prohibited to untouchables,” euphemistically called by the questioner “non Hindus”?
('35', 159, 2, 17, 295182) Reasons given without any sense of shame on behalf of the Cochin Government were : “The roads are in close proximity to temples and palace.
('35', 159, 2, 18, 295322) There cannot be a sudden break with the past.
('35', 159, 2, 19, 295368) Long standing customs have to be respected”.
('35', 159, 2, 20, 295413) The reader must note the word “palace”.
('35', 159, 2, 21, 295453) One may suppose, therefore, that the Panchama has no right of personal petition, for, he cannot traverse roads near the palace, much less can he enter them.
('35', 159, 2, 22, 295610) The officials who gave the heartless answer are able, educated and
('35', 160, 0, 1, 295677) VOL.35 : 2 APRIL, 1926 7 JULY, 1926 161
('35', 160, 1, 2, 295717) cultured men, in other walks of life even liberal minded; but they justify a cruel, heartless and irreligious custom on the grounds of antiquity.
('35', 160, 1, 3, 295863) One learns in law books that crimes and immoralities do not enjoy the benefit of prescription.
('35', 160, 1, 4, 295958) Their antiquity cannot make them respectable.
('35', 160, 1, 5, 296004) But it is evidently otherwise in the Cochin State.
('35', 160, 1, 6, 296055) Who can deny that the custom of untouchability is immoral, barbarous and cruel?
('35', 160, 1, 7, 296135) Thus the laws of Chohin State are in a way much worse than those of South Africa.
('35', 160, 1, 8, 296217) The common law of South Africa refuses to admit equality between white and Coloured races.
('35', 160, 1, 9, 296308) The common law of Cochin bases inequality on birth in a particular group.
('35', 160, 1, 10, 296382) But the incidence of inequality in Cochin is infinitely more inhuman than in South Africa for, an untouchable in Cochin is deprived of more human rights than the Coloured man in South Africa.
('35', 160, 1, 11, 296574) There is no such thing as unapproachability or invisibility in South Africa.
('35', 160, 1, 12, 296651) I have no desire to single out Cochin for its disgraceful treatment of untouchables; for, it is still unfortunately common to Hindus all over India more or less.
('35', 160, 1, 13, 296813) But, in Cochin, besides the so called sanction of religion, untouchability has the sanction of the State.
('35', 160, 1, 14, 296919) Mere levelling up of public opinion, therefore, can be of no avail in Cochin unless it becomes so strong as to compel the state to abolish the barbarous custom.

('35', 166, 1, 2, 306281) 223. LETTER TO NAGARDAS LALLUBHAI
('35', 166, 2, 3, 306315) ASHRAM, SABARMATI, April 30, 1926
('35', 166, 3, 4, 306349) BHAISHRI NAGARDAS, I had your letter.
('35', 166, 3, 5, 306387) In Wadhwan we offer far higher rates than those prevailing in Kathiawar and Gariyadhar.
('35', 166, 3, 6, 306475) This makes the khadi expensive.
('35', 166, 3, 7, 306507) From your report and from my talk with Fulchand, I see that the women who have been spinning are not without any means of living or without occupation.
('35', 166, 3, 8, 306659) Perhaps they spin in response to our appeal and because they realize that it is for the good of the country.
('35', 166, 3, 9, 306768) The charkha movement was not conceived with such people in view.
('35', 166, 3, 10, 306833) The assumption underlying it was that in India millions of men and women are half starved and, though able bodied, are idle for want of work.
('35', 166, 3, 11, 306975) The central idea of the spinning movement is to get such people to spin and then sell the khadi made from the yarn produced by them.
('35', 166, 3, 12, 307108) The khadi produced in Wadhwan does not serve this aim.
('35', 166, 3, 13, 307163) That is what I feel.
('35', 166, 3, 14, 307184) If I am right, I think we should stop our work in Wadhwan.
('35', 166, 3, 15, 307243) In case we have to do this the khadi that is stocked there can be disposed of.
('35', 166, 3, 16, 307322) We may continue it provided we get women who will spin for a little amount at the end of the day, carders who will do the carding at the rate of two and a half rupees and weavers who will accept wages at rates prevailing elsewhere.
('35', 166, 3, 17, 307554) Otherwise we should stop it.
('35', 166, 3, 18, 307583) Discuss this suggestion with other workers and let me know what you think.

('35', 166, 5, 20, 307705) 224. LETTER TO HASAM HIRJI
('35', 166, 6, 21, 307732) ASHRAM, SABARMATI, Friday, April 30, 1926
('35', 166, 7, 22, 307774) BHAISHRI HASAM HIRJI, Now I have another letter from you before I could reply to your first.
('35', 166, 7, 23, 307867) I will answer the main question in your first letter through Navajivan when I get time.
('35', 166, 7, 24, 307955) I will reply to your second letter here.
('35', 166, 7, 25, 307996) Aparigraha is an ideal condition.
('35', 166, 7, 26, 308030) It can be said that an ideal is never realized perfectly.
('35', 166, 7, 27, 308088) But we should not lower our ideal on this account.
('35', 166, 7, 28, 308139) No one has ever been able to draw the ideal straight line of geometry but we may not, for that reason, change its definition.
('35', 166, 7, 29, 308265) If we draw a straight line, keeping the ideal one in our view, we shall
('35', 167, 0, 1, 308337) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 168
('35', 167, 1, 2, 308379) succeed in drawing a line which will serve our purpose.
('35', 167, 1, 3, 308435) But if we modify the definition, we will be like a boat without the rudder.
('35', 167, 1, 4, 308511) There is nothing wrong with money as a piece of metal; evil comes through its use.
('35', 167, 1, 5, 308594) Keeping this in mind, we should sincerely try to realize the ideal of aparigraha as best as we can.
('35', 167, 1, 6, 308694) Let us now examine the instances which you have imagined.
('35', 167, 1, 7, 308752) The world will lose nothing if the rich give up their wealth voluntarily; on the contrary, it will benefit by their action, because a new and powerful force is generated as a result of a sincere act of aparigraha.
('35', 167, 1, 8, 308966) No one can act in such matters mechanically.
('35', 167, 1, 9, 309011) He alone who feels a spontaneous urge in his heart will act, and will deserve credit for his action.
('35', 167, 1, 10, 309112) There is no danger or possibility of the entire world acting upon the ideal of aparigraha.
('35', 167, 1, 11, 309203) But assuming that it does, I have no doubt that it will find no difficulty in maintaining itself.
('35', 167, 1, 12, 309301) There are people in this world who do not stock anything to meet their needs even for one day.
('35', 167, 1, 13, 309396) You need not believe that such persons would starve if there were not in the world other people whe stored things.
('35', 167, 1, 14, 309511) Just as in the law enforced by governments a crime does not cease to be a crime for being committed unintentionally, so also a violation of divine law committted in ignorance does not cease to be a violation.
('35', 167, 1, 15, 309720) Adultery committed under the influence of alcohol is none the less the same.
('35', 167, 1, 16, 309797) “To ask for forgiveness” and “to receive forgiveness” are beautiful ideas.
('35', 167, 1, 17, 309872) I act on both the principles.
('35', 167, 1, 18, 309902) But I have always believed that forgiveness in this sense does not mean what is commonly understood by it.
('35', 167, 1, 19, 310009) A sincere desire to be forgiven increases our humility; we are able to see our weakness, and this knowledge gives us the strength to be good.
('35', 167, 1, 20, 310151) Hindus, Muslims, Christians, and others have employed innumerable epithets to describe God but they are all products of our own imagination.
('35', 167, 1, 21, 310292) God is without attributes and beyond all qualification.
('35', 167, 1, 22, 310348) But again I am speaking about the ideal; if, however, we do not understand the ideal and seriously believe that God is subject to all the epithets with which we describe Him, He would be like us, an embodiment of errors.
('35', 167, 1, 23, 310569) We should, therefore, know Him as stainless and without form, and then we may heap on Him as many epithets as we choose, for that is the only language which He has given us.
('35', 167, 1, 24, 310743) Apart from this, we cannot escape the fruits of our action.
('35', 167, 1, 25, 310803) This is the universal law and therein lies His mercy.
('35', 167, 1, 26, 310857) This world would not endure even for one moment if He were to keep amending His laws and commandments, as we do either to favour some or correct an error which might have been noticed.
('35', 168, 0, 1, 311042) VOL.35 : 2 APRIL, 1926 7 JULY, 1926 169
('35', 168, 1, 2, 311082) Reality which we call God is a mysterious, indescribable and unique power.
('35', 168, 1, 3, 311157) If we cannot comprehend Him with our mind, how can our poor speech describe Him ?
('35', 168, 2, 4, 311239) From a photostat of the Gujarati : S. N. 10902

('35', 169, 7, 20, 313507) 229. MESSAGE FOR “FREEDOM”
('35', 169, 8, 21, 313534) May 1, 1926 ‘Freedom’ is an attractive name to give to a newspaper.
('35', 169, 8, 22, 313602) But it is a much abused term.
('35', 169, 8, 23, 313632) When a slave holder talks of freedom, we know that it means freedom to use his slave as he chooses without let or hindrance.
('35', 169, 8, 24, 313757) A drunkard’s freedom means ability to drink on till he is bereft of his sense and a long time after.
('35', 169, 8, 25, 313858) Whose and what freedom will this paper stand for is a relevant question.
('35', 169, 8, 26, 313931) The fact that it is Pandit Motilalji’s creation itself is one assurance that freedom means the freedom of the masses.
('35', 169, 8, 27, 314049) And freedom of the masses means their ability to cope and do away with the condition of semi starvation in which millions of them are living.
('35', 169, 8, 28, 314191) This aspect of freedom appeals to me the most at the present moment; because freedom of the masses
('35', 169, 9, 29, 314290) 1 From the contents; vide “Letter to Vasumati Pandit”, 9 5 1926.
('35', 169, 10, 30, 314355) 2 Jaisukhlal Gandhi
('35', 170, 0, 1, 314375) VOL.35 : 2 APRIL, 1926 7 JULY, 1926 171
('35', 170, 1, 2, 314415) automatically involves freedom of the untouchables and freedom of people belonging to different religions to follow out their religious convictions without let or hindrance from anybody.
('35', 170, 1, 3, 314602) And, freedom of the masses in the manner I have explained is an utter impossibility without the revival of hand spinning and therefore intensive khaddar propaganda as a central fact.
('35', 170, 1, 4, 314785) Let me hope that Freedom will in season and out of season impress upon its readers the national importance of this central fact of the life of the masses with whom, if we want swaraj, we must identify ourselves.
('35', 170, 2, 5, 314997) M. K. GANDHI

('35', 171, 5, 6, 315979) DEAR SATIS BABU, Chhotalalji is coming to you.
('35', 171, 5, 7, 316026) His nerves are high strung through excessive work and he has made drastic experiments in reducing food to its simplest and most economic terms.
('35', 171, 5, 8, 316170) The result is that his health is much impaired.
('35', 171, 5, 9, 316218) He is in love with you.
('35', 171, 5, 10, 316242) He wants to study your organization and wants to do some easy work which can almost be termed recreation.
('35', 171, 5, 11, 316348) He has an idea that he will be more useful for my personal service if he learns shorthand and typewriting.
('35', 171, 5, 12, 316455) I have told him I do not think so especially now that I have Subbiah with me.
('35', 171, 5, 13, 316533) I would not think of using Chhotalalji as a shorthand reporter and typist when I know that he is a khadi expert in many of its branches.
('35', 171, 5, 14, 316670) But he is an absolutely free agent.
('35', 171, 5, 15, 316706) To learn shorthand is no sin and if he wants to learn it and typing, he shall do so.
('35', 171, 5, 16, 316791) You will therefore discuss with him freely the manner in which he should pass two or three months there and do the needful.

('35', 171, 5, 18, 316950) Therefore you will have to draw him out and cheer him up.

('35', 171, 5, 20, 317087) Give me your impressions of this horrible rioting in Calcutta.

('35', 172, 1, 3, 317817) The loan shall bear interest at one per cent per annum payable quarterly at the above office or any other office that may be appointed by you from time to time.
('35', 172, 1, 4, 317978) The receipt of the principal or the interest by your agent, Sjt.
('35', 172, 1, 5, 318043) Satis Chandra Das Gupta of the said Khadi Pratishthan, or any other person appointed by you in writing from time to time shall be sufficient proof of payment of principal or interest.
('35', 172, 1, 6, 318227) The conditions of the said loan are : (1) That the money received shall be used for the production of hand spun and hand woven khaddar in Bengal.
('35', 172, 1, 7, 318373) (2) The selling prices of khaddar shall be not more than the cost price up to weaving plus 61 2 % for the expenses of management.
('35', 172, 2, 8, 318503) (3) The Pravartak Sangh shall not directly or indirectly deal in what is known as half khadi, that is, cloth in which mill spun yarn has been used or which is machine woven or cloth manufactured in Indian or foreign mills.
('35', 172, 2, 9, 318726) (4) The Pravartak Sangh shall not raise any other loan on mortgage of the scheduled property without the previous written consent of the Association.
('35', 172, 2, 10, 318876) (5) The Pravartak Sangh shall keep a proper account of all the hand spinning and khaddar transactions and its central and branch depots in connection with khaddar production shall be open to inspection by the nominee or nominees of the Association during office hours and the Pravartak Sangh shall render to the Secretary, All India Spinners’ Association, Ahmedabad, quarterly accounts of all its khaddar transactions.
('35', 172, 2, 11, 319295) (6) In the event of a breach by the Pravartak Sangh of any of the foregoing conditions, it shall be open to the All India Association to declare the loan payable on demand.
('35', 172, 2, 12, 319468) The Association shall be the sole judge of the breach of the said conditions.

('35', 179, 0, 1, 329430) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 180
('35', 179, 1, 2, 329472) 244. NOTES
('35', 179, 2, 3, 329483) ONCE BITTEN TWICE SHY
('35', 179, 3, 4, 329505) The public have had such bitter experience of the bureaucracy that if they hear of anyone, who has shown a spirit of independence till now, calling on any member of the bureaucracy, they fear the worst or feel suspicious about him.
('35', 179, 3, 5, 329737) Ever since it appeared in the papers that the Governor of Bombay intended to invite me for a discussion about the Agriculture Commission which has been appointed, I have been flooded with letters of all kinds, including letters of warning.
('35', 179, 3, 6, 329977) One correspondent asks what I hoped to gain by meeting the Governor, and cautions me saying that the latter would try to throw dust into my eyes, would lay a trap for me and deceive me.
('35', 179, 3, 7, 330163) If, however, we aspire to win swaraj, it will not help to be afraid or be suspicious in this manner.
('35', 179, 3, 8, 330264) We are perfectly right in refusing to accept any favours from an official, to be obliged by any of them or to accept service under them.
('35', 179, 3, 9, 330401) That is part of non co operation.
('35', 179, 3, 10, 330435) But it would not be right to be afraid of meeting any of them.
('35', 179, 3, 11, 330498) Why should a man who knows his duty be afraid of anything?
('35', 179, 3, 12, 330557) Again, what reason for fear has one who seeks no personal gain, who has, in other words, unshakable faith in non co operation?
('35', 179, 3, 13, 330684) Moreover, anyone who wishes to achieve his end through non violence would never miss any opportunity of meeting an official in an open and proper manner.
('35', 179, 3, 14, 330838) My non co operation is not with individuals, it is with their actions.
('35', 179, 3, 15, 330909) The way of non violence means the way of love.
('35', 179, 3, 16, 330956) If I wish to follow it, I should welcome every opportunity of meeting my opponent, for it is my duty to change his manner of acting, and that too not through force but by persuasion, by pleading with him or by self suffering, that is, by resorting to satyagraha.
('35', 179, 3, 17, 331219) Should, therefore, His Excellency invite me, I would regard it as my duty to meet him and, being quite clear about my principles and knowing my duty, I would have no fear of yielding to any temptation or walking into a trap.
('35', 179, 3, 18, 331444) Even at the time when I met Lord Reading, some friends had expressed the same fear that my correspon dent has done on this occasion.
('35', 179, 3, 19, 331577) But I believe that I did right to meet him, and that my meeting did no harm to the national cause.
('35', 179, 3, 20, 331676) To me, personally, it brought nothing but gain since I could form a correct estimate of him, and can now say that I let go no real opportunity, through pride or weakness, of arriving at a settlement.
('35', 179, 3, 21, 331876) On this occasion, too, I expect nothing but gain from a meeting with the Governor.
('35', 179, 3, 22, 331959) I shall be able to place my views before
('35', 180, 0, 1, 332000) VOL.35 : 2 APRIL, 1926 7 JULY, 1926 181
('35', 180, 1, 2, 332040) him, will see and correct any error there may be in my line of reasoning and will know his views about agriculture.
('35', 180, 1, 3, 332156) His Excellency certainly knows that I am a non co operator, that I have no faith in commissions and can take no part in their work.
('35', 180, 1, 4, 332288) All this is public knowledge.
('35', 180, 1, 5, 332318) If, therefore, I am invited to meet the Governor, no one need have any fears on my account.
('35', 180, 2, 6, 332410) TO WORKERS IN THE CAUSE OF COW PROTECTION
('35', 180, 3, 7, 332452) As there are some who entertain fears about the possible consequences of my meeting the Governor, there are others, too, who hanker after some gain from it.
('35', 180, 3, 8, 332609) I have received a letter and a telegram suggesting that I should tell the Governor about the loss to agriculture through the export and slaughter of cattle.
('35', 180, 3, 9, 332766) I wish to tell those workers in the cause of cow protection that, even if I had an opportunity to discuss this subject with the Governor, I would most certainly not do what they wish me to do.
('35', 180, 3, 10, 332959) I see one great weakness in these workers, namely, that they do not make a patient and scientific study of this problem.
('35', 180, 3, 11, 333080) Shri Valji Desai has undertaken a careful study of the reasons for the destruction of the cattle wealth of the country.
('35', 180, 3, 12, 333200) His articles on the subject have been appearing regularly in Young India and Navajivan.
('35', 180, 3, 13, 333288) One will understand the causes of the miserable condition of the cattle even from these articles.
('35', 180, 3, 14, 333386) Though I believe that the Government can do a great deal in this field, there is much which the people, too, can do.
('35', 180, 3, 15, 333503) And so long as the people have not become alive to their responsibility in this matter and public opinion has not been educated, the cattle wealth cannot be saved from destruction, no matter what laws the Government makes.
('35', 180, 3, 16, 333726) The problem involves difficult economic and ethical issues.
('35', 180, 3, 17, 333786) But one would think that we could spare no time to reflect even for a moment on what economics and ethics have to tell us about cattle, such is our pathetic condition.
('35', 180, 3, 18, 333954) Thanks to fanaticism, we have lost the true sense of dharma and we are too lethargic to study economics.
('35', 180, 3, 19, 334059) Merely telling beads to the name of Mother Cow will help us to serve neither her nor Mother India.
('35', 180, 3, 20, 334158) We can serve her and her progeny and, by protecting her, serve ourselves only by understanding the meaning of cow worship and taking measures accordingly.
('35', 180, 3, 21, 334313) I suggest to my correspondents to reflect over the articles on this subject which appear in this paper from time to time.
('35', 180, 3, 22, 334435) They may point out any error of logic or facts, which they may see; if they see none, they should follow the suggestions made in them.

('35', 181, 1, 2, 334612) SURAT VINAY MANDIR
('35', 181, 2, 3, 334631) A friend has written to me making some complaints against the Rashtriya Vinay Mandir 1, at Surat, the reason for writing to me being that he has heard a rumour to the effect that the control and management of the Mandir are to be handed over to me.
('35', 181, 2, 4, 334880) Instead of discussing the complaints, let me state the existing position.
('35', 181, 2, 5, 334954) I have known Shri Dayalji and Shri Kalyanji for the past ten years.
('35', 181, 2, 6, 335022) When they told me on behalf of the Committee that the only way to bring order in the affairs of the Mandir was to hand over control to me, I thought it necessary that I should accept the responsibility.
('35', 181, 2, 7, 335225) My correspondent suggests that control has been handed over to me at a time when the Mandir is on its last legs, so that the responsibility for its death may be mine.
('35', 181, 2, 8, 335392) Even if that be so, how can I refuse to share, wherever I can, the responsibility of co workers?
('35', 181, 2, 9, 335489) When agreeing to take over control of the Mandir, I made it plain that I shall do nothing without Vallabhbhai’s advice and take no step which would not be subject to the general supervision of the Vidyapith.
('35', 181, 2, 10, 335697) This condition was accepted by the two friends, Dayalji and Kalyanji.
('35', 181, 2, 11, 335767) I now intend to discuss with Vallabhbhai the question of seeting up a Trust for the Mandir.
('35', 181, 2, 12, 335859) Meanwhile, with the consent of Shri Nrisinhprasad, Kulanayaka of the Mandir, I have provisionally appointed Shri Narahari Parikh as its Acharya, and given him the authority to introduce any changes in the running of the institution which he may find necessary and increase or reduce the teaching staff.
('35', 181, 2, 13, 336162) The Mandir which was run in the Patidar Ashram has been merged with the school in Gopipura.
('35', 181, 2, 14, 336254) This step, it is hoped, will enable the authorities to retrench six posts of teachers.
('35', 181, 2, 15, 336341) Any changes in the curriculum which are found necessary will also be introduced.
('35', 181, 2, 16, 336422) When the Mandir reopens after the holidays, Shri Nrisinhprasad intends to visit it and observe the conditions.
('35', 181, 2, 17, 336533) Moreover, though it is true that control has been handed over to me, this does not mean that Shri Dayalji and Shri Kalyanji will cease to take further interest in the Mandir.
('35', 181, 2, 18, 336708) Not only will they not do this, but on the contrary they will be my hands and feet in the task entrusted to me.
('35', 181, 2, 19, 336820) I, therefore, hope that the merchants who have been contri buting towards the expenses of the school will continue their
('35', 181, 3, 20, 336941) 1 National Primary School
('35', 182, 0, 1, 336967) VOL.35 : 2 APRIL, 1926 7 JULY, 1926 183
('35', 182, 1, 2, 337007) contributions according to their promise.
('35', 182, 1, 3, 337049) The accounts of the school will be published regularly with the necessary audit reports.
('35', 182, 1, 4, 337138) TO N. A. P. To me your question itself seems to spring from morbidity.
('35', 182, 1, 5, 337209) The instances from British life which I mentioned had no connection with the point whether or not the people there live a luxurious life; it is all a matter of custom.
('35', 182, 1, 6, 337377) When a person living in a hot country goes to a cold country, he has to exercise greater care to protect himself against the cold than the residents of the country need do; in the same way I believe it very necessary for Indian youths to exercise special care [when they go to England].
('35', 182, 1, 7, 337664) It was not my intention to suggest that all or most young men in England remain perfectly pure; all that I wished to suggest was that some of the freedom which people take in England may be harmless.
('35', 182, 1, 8, 337864) If we take that freedom, we would sully our purity.
('35', 182, 1, 9, 337916) The moral laxity which we find among the young in England is the effect, not of the limited freedom which I have described, but of other factors which are easy to appreciate.
('35', 182, 1, 10, 338091) A person who keeps away from drinks because he understands the evil of drinking is not a coward but a wise man, that is, a man of discrimination.
('35', 182, 1, 11, 338237) Evil desires spring from inner darkness, from lack of discrimination and ignorance of the true end of human life.
('35', 182, 1, 12, 338351) The suggestions which I have made for being able to observe brahmacharya are not copy book maxims or the result of ingenious guesswork; they represent my own experience, and that of others too, over a long period of time.
('35', 182, 1, 13, 338573) I would, therefore, advise you not to dismiss Chapter XIX of An Autobiography without trying to understand it properly.
('35', 182, 1, 14, 338693) I know lustful persons who are vegetarians on principle, who wear only a khadi shirt and cap and live an outwardly simple life but dwell in their minds on pleasures and luxuries, and I also know real brahmacharis who, following the practice in their country, eat meat and have always dressed themselves in coat and trousers.
('35', 182, 1, 15, 339018) The main thing is to be simple in one’s thoughts.
('35', 182, 1, 16, 339068) If a man harbours the violence of meat eating in his thoughts and his mind dwells on the pleasures of a grand palace, do not believe, merely because his body lives on fruits and is covered merely with a bit of blanket, that he lives or can live a blameless life.
('35', 182, 1, 17, 339331) Anyone who wants to live a life untroubled by impure desires or to acquire such purity must always remain vigilant.
('35', 182, 1, 18, 339447) You seem to confuse the caution of a vigilant person with cowardice.
('35', 182, 1, 19, 339516) If so, you are in the grip of a terrible error.
('35', 182, 1, 20, 339564) Please wake up.

('35', 183, 1, 2, 339622) A CAUTION A newspaper correspondent informs me from Aden that a woman known by the name of Benibai has arrived there and has been cheating credulous people by posing as my daughter.
('35', 183, 1, 3, 339804) A similar thing had happened in Rangoon and Mombasa, and it seems this same woman had gone to those places.
('35', 183, 1, 4, 339912) I cautioned people some time ago that I have no daughter, and that I have not authorized anyone to collect money in my name.

('35', 183, 2, 9, 340401) Just now I only wish to draw attention to Shri Lakshmidas’s Report.
('35', 183, 2, 10, 340469) The reader will observe that it is only in place where famine conditions prevail that khadi is produced by paying spinners.
('35', 183, 2, 11, 340593) We shall not discuss at the moment whether the khadi so produced turns out to be cheaper or dearer [than that manufactured from yarn spun by amateurs].
('35', 183, 2, 12, 340745) It will suffice to admit at present that, though the quality of khadi is very much better than what it used to be, it will not prove as strong as mill khadi of the same count.
('35', 183, 2, 13, 340921) Even so, no one should feel any doubt, after reading this Report that residents of Kathiawar should always prefer khadi produced in Kathiawar.
('35', 183, 2, 14, 341064) If what is stated in the Report is true, people who wear such khadi are helping victims of famine.
('35', 183, 2, 15, 341163) It is very much better to make them self supporting than to help them with free doles.
('35', 183, 2, 16, 341250) There can be no argument about this.
('35', 183, 2, 17, 341287) Moreover, everyone cannot afford to contribute money for free doles, but certainly every person of ordinary means can afford to help by purchasing khadi, which costs more than other cloth, and making up for the loss by economizing in other matters.
('35', 183, 2, 18, 341536) I, therefore, hope that the people of Kathiawar will welcome the present sale tour of Abbas Saheb among them.
('35', 183, 2, 19, 341646) From a report which I have received from Wadhwan, I see that he was enthusiastically welcomed by the residents of the place, and that there was no one who did not show him due respect.
