('35', 184, 1, 5, 342107) Workers will be able to inspire faith in others only in the measure that they themselves have it, and the strength which they lack in themselves they will not be able to draw from others.
('35', 184, 1, 6, 342295) If the women who spin also learn carding, they will earn twice as much and the public will get better yarn.
('35', 184, 1, 7, 342403) They can earn money by carding, which they do not at present.
('35', 184, 1, 8, 342465) As long as the workers themselves are not proficient in carding, they cannot inspire enthusiasm for carding among the women who spin, let alone being able to teach them the art.
('35', 184, 1, 9, 342643) The suggestion about testing the strength of yarn deserves the same attention as that about carding.
('35', 184, 1, 10, 342744) This is necessary to ensure the strength of the yarn.
('35', 184, 1, 11, 342798) If the quality of yarn is carefully maintained, khadi will become cheaper.
('35', 184, 1, 12, 342873) That is, with the same rates of payment as at present, there will be improvement in regard to quality and price.
('35', 184, 1, 13, 342986) In big factories, they are able to increase the profits, without raising the prices of the products, merely by skilful management.
('35', 184, 1, 14, 343117) In our innumerable factories—for every hut is a spinning mill—let the workers increase their earnings through improved efficiency and also reduce the burden on the people.
('35', 184, 1, 15, 343289) In those big factories, what with the innumerable financial manipulations and changes in the exchange rate which they resort to and which result in crores of rupees changing hands, the workers are always exploited.
('35', 184, 1, 16, 343504) In our factories, improved efficiency will not mean large sums changing hands in this manner but will generate, rather, a spirit of equality and promote the welfare of the workers in corresponding measure.
('35', 184, 1, 17, 343710) These happy results depend on the spirit of self sacrifice, efficiency, perseverance, humility and energy which khadi workers may be able to display.
('35', 184, 1, 18, 343860) Let nobody draw the conclusion from my observations or Shri Lakshmidas’s Report that the work done so far has been wasted or that it was not done properly.
('35', 184, 1, 19, 344016) What we both mean is that our work is so well organized now that we are in a position to take a step forward.
('35', 184, 1, 20, 344126) It is our duty to see that, with experience, our work goes on improving.
('35', 184, 1, 21, 344199) There is no doubt that, relatively speaking, khadi has made excellent progress.
('35', 184, 1, 22, 344279) Now the consumers need to satisfy themselves only whether 1 khadi workers are honest and hard working; 2 the money which they pay for khadi goes into the pockets
('35', 185, 0, 1, 344441) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 186
('35', 185, 1, 2, 344483) of the poor; 3 the women who spin are really helped; 4 it is a fact that they would not be able to make both ends meet if they did not get spinning work; and 5 it is a fact that they have no other more remunerative work.
('35', 185, 1, 3, 344704) If the replies to these questions are in the affirmative, the people of Kathiawar should, without considering whether khadi is cheap or costly, see that the khadi produced in Kathiawar does not remain unsold.

('35', 185, 2, 5, 344949) 246. ABOUT MILL WORKERS
('35', 185, 3, 6, 344973) The movement among the mill workers in Ahmedabad against the drink evil is proceeding very well at present.
('35', 185, 3, 7, 345081) All people may not know that in America, where only a few years ago every worker used to drink, they have stopped drinking for some years now.
('35', 185, 3, 8, 345224) Their paper has published the following information.
('35', 185, 3, 9, 345277) Millions of rail road workers have, in their Union meetings, welcomed prohibition and recounted their experience that drinking turns good citizens and workers into bad ones and good husbands into cruel ones.
('35', 185, 3, 10, 345485) They have also declared that, had the workers continued to drink, the hundreds of workers’ banks which have been formed and in which millions of their dollars are deposited would never have come into existence.
('35', 185, 3, 11, 345696) The Secretary of their Union has stated that during the last four years Labour Unions in America have been rapidly throwing up honest and able leaders.
('35', 185, 3, 12, 345848) If the mill workers in Ahmedabad also realize the sin of drinking and understand that liquor is a poison and give it up, one can easily imagine the improvement in their condition which will follow.

('35', 189, 3, 5, 351320) We may not despise in our heart persons whom we regard as bad men, but we need not seek their acquaintance either, unless there is some reason.
('35', 189, 3, 6, 351464) That is, we may have contact with them only if we get an opportunity to do them good.

('35', 189, 3, 11, 351914) Moreover, since children are quick to imitate what others do, we should show in our conduct all those virtues which we want them to cultivate.
('35', 189, 3, 12, 352057) From this point of view, a guardian should particularly observe brahmacharya, follow truth and non violence and display fearlessness, courage, magnanimity, humility and so on.

('35', 190, 9, 14, 353947) PROHIBITION AND MADRAS GOVERNMENT Sjt.
('35', 190, 9, 15, 353986) C. Rajagopalachari has unearthed a Government order which is simplicity itself but which conveys a world of meaning.
('35', 190, 9, 16, 354103) In a note accompanying a copy of the order Sjt.
('35', 190, 9, 17, 354151) Rajagopalachari writes to the press :

('35', 202, 1, 2, 376348) 268. LETTER TO D. B. KALELKAR
('35', 202, 2, 3, 376378) ASHRAM, SABARMATI, Saturday, May 8, 1926
('35', 202, 3, 4, 376419) BHAI KAKA, I have to further postpone the writing of the book for you, because, if I do not write a letter to you under the excuse that I am to write a book for you, I am afraid I may write neither.
('35', 202, 3, 5, 376618) I had thought that I would write out the book soon so that I need not write the letter.
('35', 202, 3, 6, 376706) But the Congress Committee took up practically my three full days, with the result that the Girnar of work has now become the Himalayas.
('35', 202, 3, 7, 376843) On top of this, I see from today’s mail that I shall have to go to Mahabaleshwar.
('35', 202, 3, 8, 376925) Nothing is likely to come out of the visit, but courtesy requires that I should go; let the outcome be what it will.
('35', 202, 4, 9, 377042) I have never felt that the inmates of the Ashram are indifferent to Dr. Talwalkar, but it may be that my indifference, if it can be called so, has been reflected in their attitude.
('35', 202, 5, 10, 377223) If you have been using olive oil as a substitute for cod liver oil, [by all means] go on with it.
('35', 202, 5, 11, 377321) Some regard it as superior to cod liver oil.
('35', 202, 5, 12, 377366) Shri Bhansali had used this same thing in jail.
('35', 202, 5, 13, 377414) My habit of drawing lots has absolutely no relation with your “examination as of a bride’s qualities”.
('35', 202, 5, 14, 377517) The poor little piece of paper cannot bear all that burden.
('35', 202, 5, 15, 377577) There is no attempt in it to win over the gods; on the contrary, there is a sort of indifference about lots.
('35', 202, 5, 16, 377686) In cases in which we need not tax our reason, in which we are indifferent to either of the alternative courses and yet must adopt one of them, and none of our good friends is prepared to take a decision for us, I think it is an excellent practice to seek the good offices our friend, the lot.
('35', 202, 5, 17, 377979) This saves time and also spares us the burden on our mind.
('35', 202, 5, 18, 378038) In matters of principle, drawing lots is an immoral solution.
('35', 202, 5, 19, 378100) You cannot draw lots whether or not you should steal.
('35', 202, 5, 20, 378154) But is it not better to draw lots rather than go on debating whether or not to go out for a walk with A, citing reasons from Vedas and other holy books for and against?
('35', 202, 5, 21, 378323) If we try to consult the inner voice in such matters, the latter would lose all its value; a child like Rasik might excuse himself from doing any work by pleading his inner voice!
('35', 202, 5, 22, 378503) Have we not known instances of such abuse of the plea of inner voice during the non co operation movement?
('35', 202, 5, 23, 378610) Suppose tandaljo and methi are both permissible items of diet, both are easily available but only one of them
('35', 203, 0, 1, 378720) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 204
('35', 203, 1, 2, 378762) is to be purchased, and suppose further that we cannot make up our mind immediately, would it not, in such circumstances, be better to draw lots and be indifferent to the result, rather than make it a matter of conscience?
('35', 203, 1, 3, 378985) I shall see about Shri Harihar when he comes here.
('35', 203, 1, 4, 379036) Shri Narahari had thought of getting Harihar to open a nursery school in Surat.
('35', 203, 1, 5, 379116) If the people of Surat are ready to have such a school and collect a big amount they are certainly welcome to start it, but we cannot try the experiment on behalf of the Vidyapith.
('35', 203, 1, 6, 379297) I remember having been told by Shri.
('35', 203, 1, 7, 379334) 1 as early as when I was in jail that Shri .
('35', 203, 1, 8, 379379) .2 had gone romantic.
('35', 203, 1, 9, 379401) He had shown me an indecent poem signed .
('35', 203, 1, 10, 379443) .3, when I asked who this .
('35', 203, 1, 11, 379471) .4 was, I think he said it was .
('35', 203, 1, 12, 379504) .5 of the Ashram.
('35', 203, 1, 13, 379522) But may be, I am mistaken.
('35', 203, 1, 14, 379549) It may not have been .
('35', 203, 1, 15, 379572) .6 but someone else who told me this.
('35', 203, 1, 16, 379610) We shall have to think about the matter when .
('35', 203, 1, 17, 379657) .7 is here.
('35', 203, 1, 18, 379669) Nothing has yet been decided about [my visit to] Europe.
('35', 203, 1, 19, 379726) Yes, Swami too had expressed to me his disagreement.
('35', 203, 1, 20, 379779) The Ame rican tour would have only meant addressing thousands of people; going to Finland means attending a convention of student delegates from all over the world.
('35', 203, 1, 21, 379944) There is a great difference between the two propositions.
('35', 203, 1, 22, 380002) Moreover, in America I was supposed to give to the people India’s message; though there was no message to give.
('35', 203, 1, 23, 380114) In this case the idea is that I should establish a spiritual bond with students.
('35', 203, 1, 24, 380195) There is no question of delivering a message.
('35', 203, 1, 25, 380241) These are the reasons why the idea of going to Finland is tempting me, though, of course, there are some misgivings in my mind.
('35', 203, 1, 26, 380369) That is why I have thrown on K. T. Paul the responsibility of arranging my visit after telling them of my conditions.
('35', 203, 1, 27, 380487) He, too, instead of accepting the responsibility, has passed on my letter to Geneva.
('35', 203, 1, 28, 380572) If they will keep the invitation open, can we say it is God’s wish that I should go?

('35', 204, 0, 1, 380945) VOL.35 : 2 APRIL, 1926 7 JULY, 1926 205
('35', 204, 1, 2, 380985) 269. SERVICE OF THE CITY
('35', 204, 2, 3, 381010) To everyone who wishes to serve his city I would recommend a perusal of Dr. Hariprasad’s account 1 of the seven month long efforts to keep the city of Ahmedabad clean and bright.
('35', 204, 2, 4, 381189) Those who do not know how to serve their own city can never serve their country.
('35', 204, 2, 5, 381270) The good work done in these seven months by people who believed that selfless service is its own reward could not have been done by the municipality of the city even at a cost of thousands of rupees.
('35', 204, 2, 6, 381470) This effort to keep the city clean is an example of co operation between a municipality and the citizens, and if the rich do not co operate, what has been already achieved is likely to be wasted.
('35', 204, 2, 7, 381666) It is possible to raise the necessary funds to make Ahmedabad a model of cleanliness.
('35', 204, 2, 8, 381752) Most of the suggestions made by Dr. Hariprasad cannot be carried out without the help of the wealthy citizens.
('35', 204, 2, 9, 381863) The money given for this work will bring a handsome return, for if the city has a sufficient number of open gounds with trees in them, if the old ruins and dirty sights are removed and stinking lavatories are seen no more, the health of the citizens will improve considerably and the price of the land will also appreciate.
('35', 204, 2, 10, 382187) The citizens can insist that the expenditure should be incurred under their own supervision.
('35', 204, 2, 11, 382280) Hence the money given for this work will not be a gift but will be an instance of economic foresight.
('35', 204, 3, 12, 382382) [From Gujarati]
('35', 204, 4, 13, 382398) Navajivan, 9 5 1926

('35', 204, 7, 17, 382753) We can see from the work done by Bhai Ravishankar that for this purpose a love for the people, a well trained body and fearlessness are far more necessary than knowledge of

('35', 211, 5, 18, 393916) 280. LETTER TO K. SANTANAM
('35', 211, 6, 19, 393943) THE ASHRAM, SABARMATI, May 11, 1926
('35', 211, 7, 20, 393979) MY DEAR SANTANAM, Rajagopalachari discussed with me your difficulties when he was at the Ashram.
('35', 211, 7, 21, 394076) I sympathize with you.
('35', 211, 7, 22, 394099) But it is difficult to conform to an absolute rule of conduct.
('35', 211, 7, 23, 394162) Whilst it is proper to exact the uttermost from oneself, to refuse to serve till one had attained the ideal height would be to cut off the possibility of reaching that height.
('35', 211, 7, 24, 394338) We rise only by actual service and by taking the risk of making mistakes whilst we are serving.
('35', 211, 7, 25, 394434) Not one of us is perfect.
('35', 211, 7, 26, 394460) Not one of us is able to realize the whole of our spiritual ambition.
('35', 211, 7, 27, 394530) All the same, in the humblest manner possible we have to continue to serve and hope that through that service we may some day realize that ambition.
('35', 211, 7, 28, 394679) If we all refuse to serve, until we attain perfection, there will be no service.
('35', 211, 7, 29, 394760) The fact is that perfection is attained through service.
('35', 211, 7, 30, 394817) If you were to say we must not take or accept power till we are perfect, I should entirely agree with you.
('35', 211, 7, 31, 394924) And, therefore, it is best never to take any power, and, when it is thrust upon us to use it for service only.
('35', 211, 7, 32, 395035) I hope therefore that, in spite of the weaknesses that you may detect in yourself, you will not refuse to render khadi service so long as the weaknesses do not interfere with that
('35', 211, 8, 33, 395215) 1 Gandhiji finally declined the invitation.
('35', 212, 0, 1, 395259) VOL.35 : 2 APRIL, 1926 7 JULY, 1926 213
('35', 212, 1, 2, 395299) service.
('35', 212, 1, 3, 395308) Thus a man who has the weakness of dishonesty or drunknesses or the like is naturally unfit for that service.
('35', 212, 1, 4, 395418) But a man who in spite of strenuous effort is unable (say) to regulate himself with his wife as if he was her brother is not unfit for service.
('35', 212, 1, 5, 395562) I hope I have made myself quite clear and that you will return to the khadi work you love and do so well.
('35', 212, 2, 6, 395668) Yours sincerely
('35', 212, 3, 7, 395684) K. SANTANAM KUMMUTTI THIDAL TANJORE DT.
('35', 212, 4, 8, 395724) From a microfilm : S.N. 19545

('35', 219, 2, 3, 407254) THE ASHRAM, SABARMATI, May 12, 1926
('35', 219, 3, 4, 407290) DEAR FRIEND, I have your letter.
('35', 219, 3, 5, 407323) It is difficult for me at the present moment to find time to read literature with which friends overwhelm me.
('35', 219, 3, 6, 407433) You ask me to differentiate between Advaitism and Dwaitism.
('35', 219, 3, 7, 407493) The former derived evidence from God who alone exists and therefore, contemplates identity between God and His creation.
('35', 219, 3, 8, 407614) The latter attempts to show that the two can be never one.
('35', 219, 4, 9, 407673) Yours sincerely,
('35', 219, 5, 10, 407690) E. H. JAMES, ESQ.
('35', 219, 5, 11, 407708) CONCORD MASS, U.S.A.

('35', 221, 7, 20, 411283) 297. A DIEHARD
('35', 221, 8, 21, 411298) Prejudices die hard.
('35', 221, 8, 22, 411319) Though the atrocious injustice done by the Hindus to the suppressed classes is admitted generally by even the orthodox Hindu society, there are men, otherwise liberal minded, so blinded by prejudice that they see no injustice in the treatment meted out to our suppressed countrymen.
('35', 221, 8, 23, 411602) Thus a correspondent writes : 2
('35', 221, 9, 24, 411634) I do not agree with people who say that the untouchables are oppressed and suppressed.
('35', 221, 9, 25, 411721) I am afraid that your mission to elevate them, to place them on an equal footing with other communities of the country, is doomed to failure.
('35', 221, 9, 26, 411863) Personally, though I feel that much should be done to elevate them
('35', 221, 10, 27, 411930) 1 From the postmark 2 Only excerpts are reproduced here.
('35', 222, 0, 1, 411987) VOL.35 : 2 APRIL, 1926 7 JULY, 1926 223
('35', 222, 1, 2, 412027) socially, it cannot be done as if by magic in a single day.
('35', 222, 1, 3, 412087) Millions of money will have to be spent to educate them, to free them from economic distress, to persuade them to abandon the vices of drinking and killing cows and eating dead animals.
('35', 222, 1, 4, 412273) Degradation lies in not touching the “untouchable”.
('35', 222, 1, 5, 412325) What though a man drinks, kills cows and eats carrion?
('35', 222, 1, 6, 412380) He is no doubt an evil doer, though no greater than the one who commits secret and more deadly sins.
('35', 222, 1, 7, 412481) But he is not to be treated as an untouchable even as society does not treat the secret sinner as one.
('35', 222, 1, 8, 412584) Sinners are not to be despised, but pitied and helped to rid themselves of their sinfulness.
('35', 222, 1, 9, 412677) The existence of untouchability among Hindus is a denial of the doctrine of ahimsa on which we pride ourselves.
('35', 222, 1, 10, 412789) We are responsible for the evils among the “untouchables”, of which the writer complains.
('35', 222, 1, 11, 412879) What have we done to wean them from their ways?
('35', 222, 1, 12, 412927) Do we not spend a fortune to reform members of our own families?
('35', 222, 1, 13, 412992) Are the untouchables not members of the great Hindu family ?
('35', 222, 1, 14, 413053) Indeed, Hinduism teaches us to regard the whole of humanity as one indivisible and undivided family and holds each one of us responsible for the misdeeds of all.
('35', 222, 1, 15, 413215) But if it is not possible to act up to the grand doctrine for its vastness, let us at least understand the unity of the “untouchables” with us since we regard them as Hindus.
('35', 222, 1, 16, 413390) And what is worse, eating carrion or thinking carrion?
('35', 222, 1, 17, 413445) We daily create, harbour and nourish millions of untouchable thoughts.
('35', 222, 1, 18, 413516) Let us shed them, for they are the true untouchables deserving to be hated and cast out.
('35', 222, 1, 19, 413605) And let us do penance for our past in justice towards the “untouchable” brothers by lovingly embracing them.
('35', 222, 1, 20, 413714) The correspondent does not question the duty of serving the untouchables.
('35', 222, 1, 21, 413788) How are we to serve them if their very sight offends and pollutes us?
('35', 222, 1, 22, 413858) Young India, 13 5 1926

('35', 223, 3, 10, 415161) 299. THE CATTLE PROBLEM
('35', 223, 4, 11, 415185) Some months ago the Collector of Ganjam Mr. A. Galletti sent me a sheet, being a reprint of his notes contibuted to The Statesman, in which he gave his opinion based on his Italian expe riences, (1) that the agriculture of India depended upon good cattle, (2) that the cattle of India were ill kept and therefore worse than elsewhere, (3) that they could be improved only by India growing cattle crop instead of merely depending on common pastures, and (4) that by the system of rotation cattle crop could be grown side by side with food grains without diminishing the returns of the latter.
('35', 223, 4, 12, 415777) I had difficulty in applying the Italian conditions to the Indian inasmuch as we have small holidings even as little as two acres and sometimes even less.
('35', 223, 4, 13, 415932) To my objection which I conveyed to him, Mr. Galletti sent me the following reply 2 :
('35', 223, 5, 14, 416018) Many thanks for yours of the 26th February, received today in my camp in my Agency hills.
('35', 223, 5, 15, 416108) I will reply 3 to your objection from experience.
('35', 223, 5, 16, 416158) The appeal of the crores of India’s cattle lies not to me alone, but to every Indian who can think for himself, more especially perhaps to
('35', 223, 6, 17, 416297) 1 Not reproduced here 2 Only an extract is reproduced here.
('35', 223, 6, 18, 416357) 3 Not reproduced here
('35', 224, 0, 1, 416379) VOL.35 : 2 APRIL, 1926 7 JULY, 1926 225
('35', 224, 1, 2, 416419) every Hindu who prides himself on being the special protector of the cow.
('35', 224, 1, 3, 416493) I hope that the readers have been perusing the carefully prepared notes by Sjt.
('35', 224, 1, 4, 416573) V. G. Desai on the slaughter of India’s cattle.
('35', 224, 1, 5, 416621) They give a graphic description of the condition of the cattle in the cities of India.
('35', 224, 1, 6, 416708) Mr. Galletti paints the condition of farm cattle and prescribes in detail the remedy for improving them.
('35', 224, 1, 7, 416813) The question of improving the breed of cattle and preserving them is a question as well of first rate economics as of religion.
('35', 224, 1, 8, 416941) How far Mr. Galletti’s remedy is applicable to Indian conditions, I do not know.
('35', 224, 1, 9, 417022) Practical farmers alone can give an authoritative opinion.
('35', 224, 1, 10, 417081) But one difficulty is obvious.
('35', 224, 1, 11, 417112) Millions of farmers are too ignorant to adopt new and revolutionary methods.
('35', 224, 1, 12, 417189) Assuming the truth of Mr. Galletti’s prescription, its application depends upon the agricultural education of the large mass of Indian humanity.
('35', 224, 1, 13, 417334) But those who know anything of agriculture and who have a patch of land under cultivation should try Mr. Galletti’s remedy and publish results.

('35', 227, 3, 20, 424099) Both the rolls and the strips should be numbered, so that whenever a strip is rejected the corresponding roll can be promptly identified.

('35', 228, 3, 10, 425291) 304. STATEMENT ON COLOUR BAR BILL
('35', 228, 4, 11, 425325) May 14, 1926
('35', 228, 5, 12, 425338) Mahatma Gandhi who arrived in Bombay on Friday morning was met on the train by an Associated Press representative who showed him a message from Cape Town that the Colour Bar Bill has been passed.
('35', 228, 5, 13, 425534) Gandhiji received the news with pain [and said]: I am sorry to learn the news that the Bill has been passed by the joint session of the two Houses of the Union Parliament.
('35', 228, 5, 14, 425706) I had hoped with Mr. Andrews that better counsels would prevail and that the Bill would be rejected.
('35', 228, 5, 15, 425807) Theoretically speaking, this Colour Bar Bill is worse than the Class Areas Reservation Bill over which there is to be a round table conference.
('35', 228, 5, 16, 425951) One had wished that the spirrit of justice that actuated the Union Government to postpone the passing of one bill would induce them not to force the passage of the other.
('35', 228, 5, 17, 426122) The acrimonious debate that took place over the passage of the Colour Bar Bill makes one suspicious as to the fate of Class Areas Reservation Bill.
('35', 228, 5, 18, 426270) The duty of the Governor General of South Africa, in my opinion, is quite clear.
('35', 228, 5, 19, 426351) His assent to this cruel Bill should be refused especially in view of the fact that General Smuts backed, as he was, by many other South African leaders put up such a strong opposition against it.
('35', 228, 5, 20, 426548) The Colour Bar Bill, if it becomes a law of the Union, will set up the whole of the native population of South Africa against the white settlers.
('35', 228, 5, 21, 426694) I regard it as an act of suicide on their part.

('35', 231, 4, 14, 430172) 310. COBWEBS OF IGNORANCE 2
('35', 231, 5, 15, 430200) An English writer has observed that in vindicating truth there is far more labour in disentangling the knots of ignorance than in propounding the truth itself.
('35', 231, 5, 16, 430360) Truth is by nature self evident.
('35', 231, 5, 17, 430393) As soon as you remove the cobwebs of ignorance that surround it, it shines clear.
('35', 231, 5, 18, 430475) That is just the sort of handicap under which the simple and straight movement of the spinning wheel is labouring today.
('35', 231, 5, 19, 430596) It is expected to fulfil conditions which no one ever claimed it to fulfil, and when it fails to do so, the blame is laid at its door rather than at the critic’s!
('35', 231, 5, 20, 430759) A capital illustration of this is afforded by some paragraphs sent by a lover of khadi, the substance of which is :
('35', 231, 6, 21, 430875) (1) Now that you have begun to claim the spinning wheel as a universal provider, it has simply filled us with disgust.
('35', 231, 6, 22, 430994) And, so, today, we, the intelligentsia, repudiate you and your spinning wheel alike.
('35', 231, 7, 23, 431079) (2) It may be possible to introduce hand spinning in small villages and if you confined yourself simply to that, nobody would criticize you and you might even get some sympathy.
('35', 231, 8, 24, 431257) (3) But when you try to make out that even spiritual salvation
('35', 231, 9, 25, 431320) 1 From the reference to Gandhiji’s visit to Mahabaleshwar 2 The Gujarati original of this appeared in Navajivan, 16 5 1926. This is a translation by Pyarelal.
('35', 232, 0, 1, 431479) VOL.35 : 2 APRIL, 1926 7 JULY, 1926 233
('35', 232, 1, 2, 431519) can come through the spinning wheel you make yourself ridiculous.
('35', 232, 1, 3, 431585) But you being a ‘great’ man, it is just possible that some simple minded people may swallow whatever you say.
('35', 232, 1, 4, 431695) The educated are not going to stand your nonsense any more; because you have now cast all moderation to the winds, and particularly since your voluntary retirement, you have not hesitated to prescribe the spinning wheel to everybody and for every conceivable object under heaven.
('35', 232, 1, 5, 431975) Does one want to observe brahmacharya ?
('35', 232, 1, 6, 432015) Let him take to the spinning wheel.
('35', 232, 1, 7, 432051) Do you want to secure the release of the innocent Bengal patriots who are in jail ?—Ply the wheel.
('35', 232, 1, 8, 432150) Do you want to ameliorate the economic condition of India?
('35', 232, 1, 9, 432209) Why then,—the wheel again !
('35', 232, 1, 10, 432237) Not only this, you have even offered the spinning wheel to veteran soldiers fit to wield the sword and the spear.
('35', 232, 1, 11, 432351) The wonder is that you do not perceive the utter madness of all this.
('35', 232, 1, 12, 432421) (4) What would it matter to Britain if India ceased to purchase sixty crore rupees worth of cloth from her?
('35', 232, 1, 13, 432529) Do you suppose that would make her abdicate her political power in India?
('35', 232, 1, 14, 432603) See, how woefully mistaken you are in declaring that there is no political programme more valuable than hand spinning.
('35', 232, 1, 15, 432722) (5) You have yet to prove that the spinning wheel can solve even the bread problem for the masses.
('35', 232, 1, 16, 432821) The harm that has resulted from it, on the other hand, is quite apparent.
('35', 232, 1, 17, 432895) Just think of the khadi shops that have come to grief already!
('35', 232, 2, 18, 432958) (6) You even seem to suggest that other industrial activities should be dropped for the sake of hand spinning.
('35', 232, 2, 19, 433069) I have condensed the objections in my own words.
('35', 232, 2, 20, 433118) I do not think that I have thereby done the writer any injustice.
('35', 232, 2, 21, 433184) On the contrary, I have erred, if at all, in removing or toning down the bitterness of his writing.
('35', 232, 2, 22, 433284) An embittered patriot has a right to employ harsh language towards a person who has come to be dubbed a ‘Mahatma’.
('35', 232, 2, 23, 433399) For it enables him to mollify, to some extent at least, his rising anger over the spectacle of destitution that his country presents on the one hand and its utter helplessness to remedy it on the other.
('35', 232, 2, 24, 433602) My duty is not to advertise his anger but to try, if it is at all possible, to remove the confusion engendered by that anger.
('35', 232, 2, 25, 433728) To proceed now to the examination of the six points of the correspondent :
('35', 233, 0, 1, 433803) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 234
('35', 233, 1, 2, 433845) (1) A UNIVERSAL PROVIDER ?—I have never tried to make anyone regard the spinning wheel as his kamadhenu 1 or universal provider; I have certainly regarded it as my kamadhenu and in this I have done nothing more than what crores of Hindus in India are today doing, when they take up a little bit of clay, mould it into a small oval ball, mentally invest it with the Divine presenece and make it their kamadhenu by offering up their entire being to it.
('35', 233, 1, 3, 434296) They do not ask their neigh bours to worship it; on the contrary after their worship is over, they consign that sacred ball of clay to the waters.
('35', 233, 1, 4, 434443) Why should then the intelligentsia feel disgusted if, with crores of my fellows, I lose my head and make the spinning wheel my kamadhenu ?
('35', 233, 1, 5, 434582) May I not expect a measure of toleration from them ?
('35', 233, 1, 6, 434635) But as a matter of fact the intelligentsia as a body have not given me the go by yet.
('35', 233, 1, 7, 434721) To believe or give others to believe, therefore, that all the intelligentsia are disgusted because a few are, is hardly proper.
('35', 233, 1, 8, 434849) But supposing, for the time being, that all of them do actually abandon me altogether, then, if my faith is inviolate, as all true faith must be, it will simply blaze forth and burn all the brighter for that reason.
('35', 233, 1, 9, 435065) When in 1908 2, on board the Kildonan Castle, I declared my faith in the spinning wheel in the pages of the Hind Swaraj (Indian Home Rule), I stood absolutely alone.
('35', 233, 1, 10, 435231) Will, then, my God who guided my pen into making that declaration of faith at that time, abandon me, when it is put on its trial?
('35', 233, 1, 11, 435361) (2) SPIN FOR SACRIFICE—It is in the villages only that the spinning wheel is largely meant to be introduced, and it is just there that it is at present going on.
('35', 233, 1, 12, 435523) And if today I beg for sympathy and support, it is for its revival in our villages.
('35', 233, 1, 13, 435607) Again it is just for this that I have to canvass the sympathy of the educated class.
('35', 233, 1, 14, 435692) For, just as if we want to teach our villagers who are ignorant how to protect themselves against the ravages of malaria and such other diseases, some people from the educated and middle class will first have to become adepts in the knowledge of the sanitary measures necessary to extirpate these diseases and to observe the rules themselves, similarly it is only when some of us learn spinning and practise it ceaselessly ourselves that we shall be able to teach it to our villagers and overcome their apathy by our personal example.
('35', 233, 1, 15, 436227) And it goes without saying that unless we use the khadi that they produce the spinning wheel cannot live.
('35', 233, 1, 16, 436333) My appeal to the people who live in the cities, therefore, is to spin for sacrifice, while their
('35', 233, 2, 17, 436430) 1 A mythical cow that gave whatever one asked for 2 Actually 1909; Vide “Hind Swaraj”, after 25 12 1909.
('35', 234, 0, 1, 436535) VOL.35 : 2 APRIL, 1926 7 JULY, 1926 235
('35', 234, 1, 2, 436575) brethren in the villages do it for reward.
('35', 234, 1, 3, 436618) The thing is simplicity itself.
('35', 234, 1, 4, 436650) If only we get at the heart of it, we will find that it hardly affords any room for criticism.
('35', 234, 1, 5, 436745) (3) I SPEAK FROM EXPERIENCE—I do regard the spinning wheel as a gateway to my spiritual salvation, but I recommend it to others only as a powerful weapon for the attainment of swaraj and the amelioration of the economic condition of the country.
('35', 234, 1, 6, 436991) To those also who aspire to observe brahmacharya, I do present the spinning wheel.
('35', 234, 1, 7, 437074) It is not a thing to be despised, for it is experience here that speaks.
('35', 234, 1, 8, 437147) A person who wants to subdue his passions has need to be calm.
('35', 234, 1, 9, 437210) All commotion within him ought to cease; and so quiet and gentle is the motion of the spinning wheel, that it has been known to still the passions of those who have turned it in the fulness of faith.
('35', 234, 1, 10, 437410) I have been able to compose my anger by turning it, and I can adduce similar testimony of several other brahmacharis.
('35', 234, 1, 11, 437528) Of course it would be quite easy to laugh down all such persons as fools and nincompoops, but it would not be found to be cheap in the end.
('35', 234, 1, 12, 437668) For the scoffer in a fit of anger loses a beautiful means wherewith to compose his passions and attain vigour and strength.
('35', 234, 1, 13, 437792) I therefore particularly recommend to every young man and young woman who reads these lines to give the spinning wheel a trial.
('35', 234, 1, 14, 437920) They will find that shortly after they sit down to spin, their passions begin to subside.
('35', 234, 1, 15, 438010) I do not mean to say that they would remain calm for all the rest of the day even after the spinning is discontinued; for, human passions are fleeter even than the wind and to subdue them completely requires no end of patience.
('35', 234, 1, 16, 438238) All that I claim is that in the spinning wheel they will find a powerful means of cultivating steadiness.
('35', 234, 1, 17, 438344) But then, someone will ask, why do not I recommend the far more poetical rosary, if that is the purpose which it is intended to subserve?
('35', 234, 1, 18, 438482) My reply to this is that the spinning wheel possesses some virtues in addition to those it has in common with the rosary.
('35', 234, 1, 19, 438604) I have not prescribed it for a recluse living in a state of nature in a cave of the Himalayas and subsisting on the herbs and roots of the forest.
('35', 234, 1, 20, 438751) I have placed it only before such countless persons like myself who, while living in the work a day world, are anxious to serve the country and to practise brahmacharya simultaneously.
('35', 234, 1, 21, 438936) And as for ridiculing my suggestion to ply the spinning wheel for securing the release of the Bengal prisoners, it only comes to this
('35', 235, 0, 1, 439070) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 236
('35', 235, 1, 2, 439112) that we are not prepared to stir ourselves a single inch to secure their release.
('35', 235, 1, 3, 439194) For the spinning wheel here means the boycott of all foreign cloth.
('35', 235, 1, 4, 439262) And what a compelling force that has and how we are at present unable to develop any other kind of force, we shall presently see as we proceed with our examination of the other points that follow.
('35', 235, 1, 5, 439459) My presenting the spinning wheel even to veteran soldiers fit to wield the lance and the sword, therefore, is not a sign of madness but a hall mark of knowledge—a knowledge not derived merely from book learning but from the plenitude of experience.
('35', 235, 1, 6, 439708) (4) WHY IT IS THE ONLY POLITICAL PROGRAMME—The question as to what loss would the British suffer if India stopped purchasing her sixty crore rupees worth of cloth from them is quite out of place.
('35', 235, 1, 7, 439904) Our duty is simply to see whether and if so, how far it would profit us.
('35', 235, 1, 8, 439977) The stopping of the purchase of sixty crores worth of foreign cloth would, in the first place, mean the saving of so much money to the crores of Indian homes.
('35', 235, 1, 9, 440136) In ohter words it would mean so much addition to their income.
('35', 235, 1, 10, 440199) Then, it would spell the creation of so much fresh industry, the organization of crores into a joint co operative effort, the conservation and utilization of the energy of the millions and the dedication of crores of lives to the service of the motherland.
('35', 235, 1, 11, 440456) The carrying out of such a gigantic task would, further, give us a realization of our own strength.
('35', 235, 1, 12, 440556) It would mean our acquiring a thorough mastery of the details and innumerable knotty problems which it presents, e.g., learning to keep account of every pie, learning to live in the villages in sanitary and healthy conditions, remov ing the difficulties that block the way and so on.
('35', 235, 1, 13, 440840) For, unless we learn all this, we would not be able to accomplish this task.
('35', 235, 1, 14, 440917) The spinning wheel, then, provides us with a means for generating this capacity in us.
('35', 235, 1, 15, 441004) So long, therefore, as one has not grasped the inner meaning of the wheel, one may ridicule it, but when once the grand meaning is understood it would become simply impossible to tear oneself away from it.
('35', 235, 1, 16, 441210) Again, the British are an intelligent people.
('35', 235, 1, 17, 441256) The officials are a wise and shrewd lot.
('35', 235, 1, 18, 441297) I know this.
('35', 235, 1, 19, 441310) That is why I present the spinning wheel to my people.
('35', 235, 1, 20, 441365) We cannot overreach the British by the glibness of our tongue or by the power of our pen.
('35', 235, 1, 21, 441455) Our threats they have grown quite accustomed to, while as for our physical prowess it can avail us but little against their bombs rained down from the aeroplanes.
('35', 235, 1, 22, 441618) But these people understand and respect patience, perseverance, determination and capacity for organization.
('35', 235, 1, 23, 441727) Cloth represents the biggest item of their trade.
('35', 235, 1, 24, 441777) The accomplishment of its boycott by us would awaken them to
('35', 236, 0, 1, 441838) VOL.35 : 2 APRIL, 1926 7 JULY, 1926 237
('35', 236, 1, 2, 441878) a sense of our strength.
('35', 236, 1, 3, 441903) They are not holding India merely to feed their pride; nor is it by mere force of arms, but it is by tact and cunning that their rule over us is maintained.
('35', 236, 1, 4, 442060) When their trade is made to rest on our untramelled free will, their rule also will undergo a similar transformation.
('35', 236, 1, 5, 442178) Today both are being imposed on us against our will.
('35', 236, 1, 6, 442231) If we succeed in shaping one of them according to our will, the other will automatically follow suit.
('35', 236, 1, 7, 442333) But it is easy enough to understand that while their trade relations with us remain unchanged, no change in the political relationship is possible.
('35', 236, 1, 8, 442481) I may repeat that I would today discard the spinning wheel if someone shows a better and more universal political programme than hand spinning.
('35', 236, 1, 9, 442625) But up to this time I have found none, I have been shown none.
('35', 236, 1, 10, 442688) I am anxious to know if there is any.
('35', 236, 1, 11, 442726) (5) HOW IT SOLVES THE BREAD PROBLEM—That the spinning wheel can solve our bread problem hardly needs to be proved to a reader of the Navajivan.
('35', 236, 1, 12, 442870) The figures published about various khadi organizations would show that thousands of poor women are today eking out their living by spinning.
('35', 236, 1, 13, 443012) Nobody has yet denied that the spinning wheel can bring the spinner at least an anna a day.
('35', 236, 1, 14, 443104) And there are crores of people in India who hardly earn even a pice a day.
('35', 236, 1, 15, 443179) So long as things stand thus, it is hardly necessary to point out the close relation that exists between the spinning wheel and the bread problem.
('35', 236, 1, 16, 443326) As for the charge that the spinning wheel has done harm to the country it is up to those who level it to prove it.
('35', 236, 1, 17, 443441) This activity is by its very nature such that there can be no waste of effort in it.
('35', 236, 1, 18, 443526) Nothing can interrupt its continuity and even a little exercise of it saves one from mighty evils.
('35', 236, 1, 19, 443625) What does it matter if some khadi shops came to an end?
('35', 236, 1, 20, 443681) That phenomenon is common to every trade.
('35', 236, 1, 21, 443723) The money invested in them has at least remained in the country, while the experi ence gained through it has enabled us to make further progress.
('35', 236, 1, 22, 443869) Besi des, if some of the shops had to close down, instances can be cited of many more, better organized shops that have grown up in their place.
('35', 236, 1, 23, 444014) (6) SUPPLEMENTS, DOES NOT REPLACE—I have not contemplated, much less advised, the abandonment of a single healthy, life giving industrial activity for the sake of hand spinning.
('35', 236, 1, 24, 444192) The entire foundation of the spinning wheel rests on the fact that there are crores of semi unemployed people in India.
('35', 236, 1, 25, 444312) And I should admit that if there were none s uch there would be no room for the spinning wheel.
('35', 236, 1, 26, 444408) But as a matter of fact everybody who has been to our villages knows that
('35', 237, 0, 1, 444482) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 238
('35', 237, 1, 2, 444524) they have months of idleness which may prove their ruin.
('35', 237, 1, 3, 444581) Even my appeal to the middle class people to spin for sacrifice is with reference to their spare hours.
('35', 237, 1, 4, 444685) The spinning wheel movement is destructive of no enterprise whatever.
('35', 237, 1, 5, 444755) It is a life giving activity.
('35', 237, 1, 6, 444785) And that is why I have called it Annapurna 1 or the butter for bread or the replenisher.
('35', 237, 1, 7, 444874) Young India, 27 5 1926
('35', 237, 2, 8, 444897) 311. MY NOTES
('35', 237, 3, 9, 444911) AMRELI KHADI CENTRE This Centre was started by Shri Chitalia at the very beginning of the khadi movement.
('35', 237, 3, 10, 445017) Thereafter Shri Amritlal Thakkar took it over and expanded its work considerably.
('35', 237, 3, 11, 445099) As everyone was inex perienced at that time, loss was inevitable.
('35', 237, 3, 12, 445165) The results, however, were beneficial on the whole for, besides our gaining experience, some poor women got a little help.
('35', 237, 3, 13, 445288) Shri Jivanlal and Ramji Hansraj also came to take interest in its activities.
('35', 237, 3, 14, 445366) The former invested some money in it, and Ramjibhai took over as its Manager.
('35', 237, 3, 15, 445444) He engaged Shri Jaisukhlal’s services.
('35', 237, 3, 16, 445483) They made a hand press for yarn and started preserving it in the form of bales.
('35', 237, 3, 17, 445563) They then established branches around Amreli in places where poverty was rampant and good workers were available, and brought about improvement in the quality of the yarn and the khadi.
('35', 237, 3, 18, 445749) Previsously, yarn of three counts was used for weaving, whereas now yarn of eight counts is used and this yarn is stronger than three count yarn.
('35', 237, 3, 19, 445895) With the beginning of this year the Centre entered the fourth stage in its growth, that is, Shri Jivanlal and Shri Ramji asked me to relieve them of the responsibility of running thus Centre and expressed their wish that some institution should take over its management.
('35', 237, 3, 20, 446166) Shri Ramji pleaded his failing health and Shri Jivanlal wished to be free so that he might be able to help in his own business.
('35', 237, 3, 21, 446294) The management of this Centre, therefore has been taken over on my advice by the Kathiawar Political Conference, and it will shortly be handed over to trustees appointed by the Conference so that the Centre may be run properly.
('35', 237, 3, 22, 446522) The amount of ten thousand rupees invested by Shri Jivanlal in this Centre remains with it.
('35', 237, 3, 23, 446614) Besides this, the amount of five thousand rupees contributed by him to the purse is also invested in the Centre in accordance with his wishes.
('35', 237, 3, 24, 446757) He is also giving a grant of two thousand rupees annually, and this he will continue for three years.
('35', 237, 3, 25, 446859) The following
('35', 237, 4, 26, 446873) 1 Provider of food—consort of Siva—worshipped as the giver of plenty
('35', 238, 0, 1, 446942) VOL.35 : 2 APRIL, 1926 7 JULY, 1926 239
('35', 238, 1, 2, 446982) plan has been drawn up for the present year.
('35', 238, 1, 3, 447027) There was a stock of old cotton and yarn weighing approximately 430 maunds.
('35', 238, 1, 4, 447103) Cotton weighing 850 maunds has been purchased at the new, that is, cheaper rate.
('35', 238, 1, 5, 447184) All the cotton will be spun, but at the end of the year 350 maunds of yarn will remain on hand, unwoven.
('35', 238, 1, 6, 447289) For this programme to be fulfilled the following amounts of money will have to reach homes of the poor by the end of the year.
('35', 238, 1, 7, 447416) Rs. 2,000 for carders Rs. 1,000 for women preparing slivers Rs. 8,000 for spinning (distributed among 1,000 women) Rs. 14,000 for weaving and bleaching The Centre has four branches : at Chalala, Bagasara, Chittal and Babara.
('35', 238, 1, 8, 447641) At the last place, work is done on a commission basis.
('35', 238, 1, 9, 447696) In all, 17 persons work there, including a cook and a peon.
('35', 238, 1, 10, 447756) The highest salary paid is Rs. 70 and next in order are Rs. 50 and Rs. 35. Five persons get Rs. 30 each.
('35', 238, 1, 11, 447861) Then there is one man get ting Rs. 25, two getting Rs. 20 each, two others getting Rs. 18 each, one getting Rs. 15, two others Rs. 12 each, and one more person getting Rs. 10. The monthly salary bill comes to Rs. 455. Add to this Rs. 70 as rent, Rs. 55 travelling expenses and Rs. 10 postage, making a total of Rs. 590. The expenses incurred at the villages of Babara, Gariyadhar and Panch Talavada, where work is done on commission basis, come to about Rs. 50 a month.
('35', 238, 1, 12, 448331) We shall now examine the costs.
('35', 238, 1, 13, 448363) The old stock of cotton weighing 430 maunds was purchased at the rate of Rs. 22 per maund and the 850 maunds of new cotton at the rate of Rs. 13 per maund.
('35', 238, 1, 14, 448519) The cost of cotton, therefore, comes to about Rs. 16 per maund.
('35', 238, 1, 15, 448583) Hence : 40 seers of cotton Cost .
('35', 238, 2, 16, 448617) Less 6 34 seers loss in carding seers of slivers Cost of carding it .
('35', 238, 2, 17, 448687) Rs. Rs. 3 19
('35', 238, 3, 18, 448700) Less 1 33 seers lost in spinning seers of yarn Cost of spinning .
('35', 238, 3, 19, 448766) Rs. Rs. 7 1 2
('35', 238, 5, 20, 448780) Less 2 31 seers lost while weaving seers, balance; cloth Cost of weaving .
('35', 238, 5, 21, 448855) from it, 88 yeds.
('35', 238, 5, 22, 448873) Rs. Rs. 10
('35', 238, 7, 23, 448884) This comes to 6 1 2 annas per yard (of unbleached khadi; width 28
('35', 238, 8, 24, 448950) inches).
('35', 238, 8, 25, 448959) Expenses on management have not been counted in working out this figure.
('35', 238, 8, 26, 449032) The payment for carding is not always Rs. 3. It varies bet 
('35', 239, 0, 1, 449092) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 240
('35', 239, 1, 2, 449134) ween Rs. 21 2 and Rs. 3. Payment is at the rate of Rs. 3 only if the
('35', 239, 2, 3, 449203) carding is of the highest quality.
('35', 239, 2, 4, 449238) The rate of payment for spinning is 2 paise per count, and the Rs. 71 2 counted here is for yarn of seven
('35', 239, 3, 5, 449344) counts.
('35', 239, 3, 6, 449352) These rates, therefore, should be considered as approximate.
('35', 239, 3, 7, 449413) The price at which the khadi is sold includes half an anna per yard added to the cost as worked out above, but that is not sufficient to defray the expenses on manage ment.
('35', 239, 3, 8, 449586) Shri Jivanlal’s grant will be utilized to meet this loss and any other loss which may occur will be met from the general collections made.
('35', 239, 3, 9, 449725) But the aim is to see that management expenses do not exceed one anna per rupee.
('35', 239, 3, 10, 449806) This ideal, however, has not been realized any where in the country.
('35', 239, 3, 11, 449875) But, as we gain experience, the workers become more efficient and the quality of spinning improves, the expenses on management will come down.
('35', 239, 3, 12, 450018) The position today is not what it was four years ago.
('35', 239, 3, 13, 450072) The point which anyone who buys khadi should note is this, that deducting the half anna per yard for management expenses, the rest of the price they pay for
('35', 239, 4, 14, 450229) khadi, i.e., 61 2 annas per yard, goes into the pockets of the cultivators
('35', 239, 5, 15, 450304) and the persons engaged in carding, spinning and weaving.
('35', 239, 5, 16, 450362) If, even from this, we deduct the cost of cotton, the wages paid for carding, spinning and weaving come to one and a quarter times the cost of cotton.
('35', 239, 5, 17, 450513) The reason for calling attention to all this is to tell the consumer who buys khadi that, if indigenous cotton is used in manufacturing all the cloth we require, not only will the cost of cotton be paid to our cultivators but the balance of the price paid by him will also go into the pockets of our workers.
('35', 239, 5, 18, 450822) On the other hand, those who purchase foreign cloth send the money outside, and those who purchase mill cloth help to make the rich richer.
('35', 239, 5, 19, 450962) The worker gets at the most one pice for every yard.
('35', 239, 5, 20, 451015) The reader will now appreciate Abbas Sahib’s motive in undertaking a sale tour of Kathiawar in such a hot season, and the reason why people should buy all the khadi he has.
('35', 239, 5, 21, 451188) The women who are engaged in spinning have no other work or source of income, and the few pice they earn daily go a long way to help them.
('35', 239, 5, 22, 451327) The purchaser of this khadi, therefore, helps these sisters and, along with them, those poor people who are engaged in weaving and carding, by providing them work.
('35', 239, 5, 23, 451491) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 16 5 1926

('35', 243, 6, 10, 457055) 318. WAR OR PEACE
('35', 243, 7, 11, 457073) It was not without purpose that I reproduced the main parts of Mr. Page’s very able pamphlet on the World War.
('35', 243, 7, 12, 457184) 2 I hope that the reader followed them with the care and attention the chapters deserved.
('35', 243, 7, 13, 457274) Mr. Page has proved conclusively that both the parties were equally to blame and that both resorted to barbarous and inhuman practices.
('35', 243, 7, 14, 457410) We did not need Mr. Page’s help to learn that no war of which history has any record took so many lives as this did.
('35', 243, 7, 15, 457527) Moral loss was greater still.
('35', 243, 7, 16, 457557) Poisonous forces destructive of the soul (lying and deception) were brought to perfection as much as the forces destructive of the body.
('35', 243, 7, 17, 457694) The moral results have been as terrible as the physical.
('35', 243, 7, 18, 457751) It is yet too early to measure the effect on mankind of the collapse of the sexual morality brought about by the War.
('35', 243, 7, 19, 457869) Vice has usurped the throne of virtue.
('35', 243, 7, 20, 457908) The brute in man has for the time being gained supremacy.
('35', 243, 7, 21, 457966) The after effects are, perhaps, more terrible than the actual and immediate effects.
('35', 243, 7, 22, 458051) There is no stability about the government of any single State of Europe.
('35', 243, 7, 23, 458125) No class is satisfied with its own condition.
('35', 243, 8, 24, 458171) 1 Not reproduced here.
('35', 243, 8, 25, 458194) These were for 1922 23 to 1925 26. 2 Vide “Notes”, 26 11 1925.
('35', 244, 0, 1, 458257) VOL.35 : 2 APRIL, 1926 7 JULY, 1926 245
('35', 244, 1, 2, 458297) Each wants to better it at the expense of the rest.
('35', 244, 1, 3, 458349) War between the States has now become a war within each State.
('35', 244, 1, 4, 458412) India has to make her choice.
('35', 244, 1, 5, 458442) She may try, if she wishes, the way of war and sink lower than she has.
('35', 244, 1, 6, 458514) In the Hindu Muslim quarrel, she seems to be taking her first lesson in the art of war.
('35', 244, 1, 7, 458602) If India can possibly gain her freedom by war, her state will be no better and will be, probably, much worse than that of France or England.
('35', 244, 1, 8, 458743) Paste examples have become obsolete.
('35', 244, 1, 9, 458780) Not even Japan’s comparative progress can be any guide.
('35', 244, 1, 10, 458836) For,“the science” or war has made much greater “progress” since the Russo Japanese war.
('35', 244, 1, 11, 458924) Its result can only be studied in the present condition of Europe.
('35', 244, 1, 12, 458991) We can safely say that if India throws off the British yoke by the way of war, she must go through the state Mr. Page has graphically described.
('35', 244, 1, 13, 459136) But the way of peace is open to her.
('35', 244, 1, 14, 459173) Her freedom is assured if she has patience.
('35', 244, 1, 15, 459217) That way will be found to be the shortest even though it may appear to be the longest to our impatient nature.
('35', 244, 1, 16, 459328) The way of peace insures internal growth and stability.
('35', 244, 1, 17, 459384) We reject it because we fancy that it involves submission to the will of the ruler who has imposed himself upon us.
('35', 244, 1, 18, 459500) But the moment we realize that the imposition is only so called and that through our unwillingness to suffer loss of life or property, we are party to the imposition, all we need do is to change that negative attitude of passive endorsement.
('35', 244, 1, 19, 459742) The suffering to be undergone by the change will be nothing compared to the physical suffering and the moral loss we must incur in trying the way of war.
('35', 244, 1, 20, 459896) And the sufferings of war harm both the parties.
('35', 244, 1, 21, 459945) The sufferings in following the way of peace must benefit both.
('35', 244, 1, 22, 460009) They will be like the pleasurable travail of a new birth.
('35', 244, 1, 23, 460067) Let us not be misled by a hasty generalization of the events of 1920 21. Great as the achievement of that brilliant period was, it was nothing compared to what it might have been, had we been true and had faith.
('35', 244, 1, 24, 460279) Violence was in the breasts of many of us whilst with our lips we paid homage to non violence.
('35', 244, 1, 25, 460374) And, though we were thus false to our creed, so far as we had accepted it, we blamed it and lost faith instead of blaming and correcting ourselves.
('35', 244, 1, 26, 460522) Chauri Chaura was a symptom of the disease that was poisoning us.
('35', 244, 1, 27, 460588) Ours was claimed to be a peaceful, non violent way.
('35', 244, 1, 28, 460640) We could not sustain the claim in its fulness.
('35', 244, 1, 29, 460687) The ‘enemy’s’ taunts we need not mind.
('35', 244, 1, 30, 460726) They saw vilolence within.
('35', 244, 1, 31, 460753) The way of peace is the way of truth.
('35', 244, 1, 32, 460791) Truthfulness is even more
('35', 245, 0, 1, 460817) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 246
('35', 245, 1, 2, 460859) important than peacefulness.
('35', 245, 1, 3, 460888) Indeed, lying is the mother of violence.
('35', 245, 1, 4, 460929) A truthful man cannot long remain violent.
('35', 245, 1, 5, 460972) He will perceive in the course of his search that he has no need to be violent and he will further discover that so long as there is the slightest trace of violence in him, he will fail to find the truth he is searching.
('35', 245, 1, 6, 461193) There is no half way between truth and non violence on the one hand and untruth and violence on the other.
('35', 245, 1, 7, 461300) We may never be strong enough to be entirely non violent in thought, word and deed.
('35', 245, 1, 8, 461384) But we must keep non violence as our goal and make steady progress towards it.
('35', 245, 1, 9, 461463) The attainment of freedom, whether for a man, a nation or the world, must be in exact proportion to the attainment of non violence as the only method of achieving real freedom, keep the lamp of non violence burning bright in the midst of the present impenetrable gloom.
('35', 245, 1, 10, 461733) The truth of a few will count, the untruth of millions will vanish even like chaff before a whiff of wind.

('35', 246, 0, 1, 462819) VOL.35 : 2 APRIL, 1926 7 JULY, 1926 247
('35', 246, 1, 2, 462859) This letter is an eye opener.
('35', 246, 1, 3, 462889) It was thought that in Australia there was no racial discrimination against those Asiatics who had settled there.
('35', 246, 1, 4, 463003) But the correspondent’s letter, fortified as it is with an original letter from the Mines Department, leaves no room for doubt.
('35', 246, 2, 5, 463131) TWO ANGLES OF VISION The deciding reason why with all the will in the world Europeans and Indians do not have hearty communion as a class is because we have different angles of vision.
('35', 246, 2, 6, 463316) We say that reforms are inadequate, that the educated classes can best represent the masses and that we are one nation though differing in language and religion.
('35', 246, 2, 7, 463478) It is not to the purpose just now to prove the assertions.
('35', 246, 2, 8, 463537) It is enough to state that educated India honestly holds the views set forth above.
('35', 246, 2, 9, 463621) But the European view honestly held is set forth in the briefest and the boldest manner in manifesto 1 addressed by the European Association to every European in India: How is it possible for the two to meet for common action in frank and free fellowship when the two stand as poles asunder in thought and aspirations as the manifesto clearly shows?
('35', 246, 2, 10, 463971) A mere make believe association or co operation can only debase both, for they meet with mental reservations and mutual distrust.
('35', 246, 2, 11, 464101) The situation is tragic; but ture.
('35', 246, 2, 12, 464136) To end the tragedy, the first essential is to realize the truth of it.
('35', 246, 2, 13, 464207) Union is desirable, it must come, but it will come only when we have begun to think the same thing.
('35', 246, 2, 14, 464307) And that will come when we Indians show our earnestness and prove our belief in a common nationality and capacity for representing the masses by acting as one nation and suffering for the masses.

('35', 248, 5, 9, 467407) 324. MY NOTES
('35', 248, 6, 10, 467421) “V EGETABLE GHEE” Nowadays misuse of names has been on the incerease.
('35', 248, 6, 11, 467491) Only cloth woven by hand from hand spun yarn can be called khadi, but the mills give to the thick cloth produced by them the name of khadi.
('35', 248, 6, 12, 467631) Again, some cheat the people by giving the name partial khadi to cloth woven by hand from mill spun yarn.
('35', 248, 6, 13, 467737) The same practice is followed in regard to ghee.
('35', 248, 6, 14, 467786) Ghee is in fact a product made from milk; still there is now a new product called “vegetable ghee”.
('35', 248, 6, 15, 467886) Coconut oil does not become ghee by merely calling it “vegetable ghee”, nor can it have the properties of ghee.
('35', 248, 6, 16, 467998) Nowadays such synthetic ghee is being improted in large quantities.
('35', 248, 6, 17, 468066) It is well packed and appears just like ghee; hence simple minded people buy it.
('35', 248, 6, 18, 468147) Moreover, since fat is sold under the name of ghee or because it is mixed with ghee, many people use “vegetable ghee”, being afraid of using ghee.
('35', 248, 6, 19, 468294) I shall not only use but even propagate vegetable ghee if a vegetable produce possessing the same properties as ghee is available.
('35', 248, 6, 20, 468425) I find fault with the use of ghee.
('35', 248, 6, 21, 468460) But I cannot disregard its good properties.
('35', 248, 6, 22, 468504) It has not so far been possible to extract a product from vegetables which will serve as a substitute for ghee.
('35', 248, 6, 23, 468616) Therefore, the product which is being sold as vegetable ghee has to be rejected on two counts : one, it is not ghee and two, it does not contain the properties of ghee.
('35', 248, 6, 24, 468785) Thirdly, the harm done is that today we use many foreign products and we have now unwillingly started using one more foreign product, much to our detriment.
('35', 248, 6, 25, 468942) Therefore, everyone using “vegetable
('35', 248, 7, 26, 468979) 1 The source has 11 which, however, was a Sunday.
('35', 249, 0, 1, 469029) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 250
('35', 249, 1, 2, 469071) ghee” should beware and give up its use.
('35', 249, 2, 3, 469112) HIGH OR LOW?
('35', 249, 2, 4, 469125) A newspaper correspondent writes : 1
('35', 249, 3, 5, 469162) This is a difficult question.
('35', 249, 3, 6, 469192) But from the point of ahimsa, there can be only one reply and that is that one who inflicts pain on small creatures for a selfish purpose also becomes low himself.
('35', 249, 3, 7, 469356) Man is a mixture of humility and greatness.
('35', 249, 3, 8, 469400) His greatness lies in his ability to be humble.
('35', 249, 3, 9, 469448) If he does not have the capacity to be humble, he cannot be considered to be great.
('35', 249, 3, 10, 469532) Then there will be no scope whatever for rising high.
('35', 249, 3, 11, 469586) Therefore it is said that one who does not harm other creatures for achieving his own ends and is ready to suffer pain for the sake of all living beings is alone fit to attain the vision of the self.

('35', 251, 1, 20, 474831) Such things are always best left to the steamship owners.
('35', 251, 1, 21, 474889) They know how to manage them.

('35', 258, 0, 1, 484493) 338. LETTER TO INDRA VIDYALANKAR
('35', 258, 1, 2, 484526) THE ASHRAM, SABARMATI, May 23, 1926
('35', 258, 2, 3, 484562) MY DEAR INDRA, I have your letter.
('35', 258, 2, 4, 484597) I am replying to you in English as you have chosen to write to me in English.
('35', 258, 2, 5, 484675) But why in English?
('35', 258, 2, 6, 484695) My promise of swaraj in 1921 was conditional.
('35', 258, 2, 7, 484741) 1 The condition was absolute acceptance of non violent non co operation by the people at large.
('35', 258, 2, 8, 484837) At Viramgam, Bombay 2 and Chauri Chaura 3 these conditions were broken not by the masses but by live Congressmen.
('35', 258, 2, 9, 484951) If I am silent about what is called the political aspect of the situation I am silent because through my silence I am preaching non violence.
('35', 258, 2, 10, 485093) I cannot say anything useful on the many controversial questions that are troubling the country today.
('35', 258, 2, 11, 485196) And If I am harping upon the charkha in season and out of season again it is because the charkha to me represents non violence in a concrete shape, for, non violence is action in the correct sense of the term whereas violence is bad action or in action.
('35', 258, 2, 12, 485450) 4 If people want swaraj through non violence means they can attain it by complete exclusion of foreign cloth and through the charkha and all it means.
('35', 258, 2, 13, 485601) During the year of grace 1921, I had the hope that we should achieve boycott of foreign cloth by a sudden and simultaneous manifestation of the charkha spirit on the part of the people.
('35', 258, 2, 14, 485787) That was not to be.
('35', 258, 2, 15, 485807) And now we have to build the charkha atmosphere among the people.
('35', 258, 2, 16, 485873) I do not think it will be so long as you imagine before the charkha becomes universal.
('35', 258, 2, 17, 485960) But even if it does, thinking non violence I cannot think of any other instrument or activity.
('35', 258, 3, 18, 486055) I see you expect a public reply to your question.
('35', 258, 3, 19, 486105) Do you really want a public reply?
('35', 258, 3, 20, 486140) I am more anxious to convince you of the soundnes of my position than to discuss with others or in Young India the question raised by you.
('35', 258, 4, 21, 486279) Yours sincerely
('35', 258, 5, 22, 486295) INDRA VIDYALANKAR, SARGODA

('35', 267, 2, 2, 498692) 352. LETTER TO DEVDAS GANDHI
('35', 267, 3, 3, 498721) ASHRAM, Wednesday, May 26, 1926
('35', 267, 4, 4, 498753) DEVDAS, I got your letter, and also Lalji’s.
('35', 267, 4, 5, 498798) Yesterday I dictated my letter in a hurry, and so one thing was left out.
('35', 267, 4, 6, 498872) The faintness that you felt when you tried to stand up was not weakness, it was the result of your not having had the practice of standing and walking for some time.
('35', 267, 4, 7, 499038) Perhaps you may not remember that, when Colonel Maddock permitted me to walk to the lavatory during daytime, he warned me that my legs might tremble and I might feel giddy, but told me not to be alarmed on that account.
('35', 267, 4, 8, 499258) After you have walked once or twice with some support, you will get back the ability to walk.
('35', 267, 4, 9, 499352) Hence I am not in the least wor ried because of your having felt giddy when you tried to stand up.
('35', 267, 4, 10, 499451) But I also see that your wound has not completely healed; this is a common enough experience in such operations.
('35', 267, 4, 11, 499564) No doctor can understand all the facts about the condition of the patient’s body, and, therefore, some complication always develops after an operation, but it can be easily cured.
('35', 267, 4, 12, 499744) The only thing is that the period of your convalescence is becoming a little too long.I have now concluded that Lalji and you will be discharged at about the same time.
('35', 267, 4, 13, 499913) This, I think, sould please you, though what you wanted was that you should get well but should have the privilege of staying on for Lalji’s sake.
('35', 267, 4, 14, 500060) It seems that you will not have that privilege.
('35', 267, 4, 15, 500108) If,however, all our wishes were granted, would not the world perish?
('35', 267, 4, 16, 500177) As against one good wish, based on regard for truth, entertained by one person, how many wicked wishes, based on disregard for truth, would there be entertained by others?
('35', 267, 4, 17, 500349) Yesterday I got a telegram from Paul, and there was second one today.
('35', 267, 4, 18, 500419) He informs that he has collected Rs. 6,000 and hopes that I will not think it necessary to cancel the trip.
('35', 267, 4, 19, 500527) I will wait for a reply to my letter, but it seems to me that we shall have to go.

('35', 268, 3, 6, 501043) The All India Spinners’ Association has received from most provinces quarterly returns of production and sale of khadi between January and March 1926. I give the figures 1 below : The Andhra figures give no indication of the extent of the work that is being done.

('35', 268, 5, 16, 502258) 354. ITS MEANING
('35', 268, 6, 17, 502275) On my return from Mahabaleshwar I was waylaid, though by previous appointment, by fellow non co operators.
('35', 268, 6, 18, 502382) I had limited myself strictly to visiting patients during this unexpected visit to His Excellency the Acting Governor at Mahabaleshwar.
('35', 268, 6, 19, 502518) And so before reaching Poona station I had arranged just to go to Prof.
('35', 268, 6, 20, 502590) Trivedi’s house to see my young friend Manu who among others had been to
('35', 268, 7, 21, 502663) 1 Not reproduced here 2 ibid.
('35', 268, 8, 22, 502693) VOL.35 : 2 APRIL, 1926 7 JULY, 1926 269
('35', 269, 0, 1, 502733) me at the Sassoon Hospital in Poona in 1924 an angel of mercy.
('35', 269, 0, 2, 502796) It was during this visit that I had to divide my time between Manu and the non co operators.
('35', 269, 0, 3, 502889) The latter had the lion’s share of it.
('35', 269, 0, 4, 502928) Manu disengaged me in a few minutes.
('35', 269, 0, 5, 502965) I envied him as a patient.
('35', 269, 0, 6, 502992) For though he has been laid up in bed for over six mon ths, I found him quite cheerful and resigned.
('35', 269, 0, 7, 503093) I had therefore no compunc tion about leaving him for a chat with the non co operating friends.
('35', 269, 0, 8, 503189) “How can you go to the Governor and call yourself a non co operator?” was the question with which I was greeted.
('35', 269, 0, 9, 503302) “I knew what your ailment was, ” said I. “I shall answer all your questions fully, but on condition that nothing of what I say is to be published by you.
('35', 269, 0, 10, 503456) If I find it advisable I shall deal with the matter in the pages of Young India.” “Yes, we won’t publish anything and shall be satisfied if you will answer our questions in Young India.
('35', 269, 0, 11, 503642) Not that I have any doub about the propriety of your action,” added the questioner, “but I represent a large number of non co operators whom you often confound by your unexpectted acts.” Well, then, let me have all your question and I shall endea vour to answer them though I confess that it will be all a waste of time.
('35', 269, 0, 12, 503963) For I feel that time is past for explanations and persuasion.
('35', 269, 0, 13, 504025) Non co operators must instinctively know that I not likely to do anything contrary to our code.
('35', 269, 0, 14, 504121) And if I do,—for I admit I am lible to err,—they must disown me and remain firm in their own convictions.
('35', 269, 0, 15, 504227) They may have derived their non co operation from me but if they have assimilated it, their convictions must not depend upon mine.
('35', 269, 0, 16, 504358) It must be independent of me and my weaknesses and errors.
('35', 269, 0, 17, 504417) If I turn traitor, or to put it mildly, if I alter my opinion, they must be ready to denounce me and still abide by their own convictions.
('35', 269, 0, 18, 504556) That is why I say that our conversation will be a waste of national time.
('35', 269, 0, 19, 504630) Convinced non co operators know their task.
('35', 269, 0, 20, 504674) Let them fulfil it.
('35', 269, 0, 21, 504694) But let me have your questions.
('35', 269, 0, 22, 504726) “ It has been suggested in Bombay that you went to the Governor uninvited, in fact you forced yourself upon his attention.
('35', 269, 0, 23, 504849) If so, was it not co operation even without response?
('35', 269, 0, 24, 504903) What could you have to do with the Governor, I wonder?” My answer is that I am quite capable even of forcing myself upon the attention of my opponent when I have strength.
('35', 269, 0, 25, 505075) I did so in South Africa.
('35', 269, 0, 26, 505101) I sought interviews after inerviews with General Smuts
('35', 269, 1, 27, 505156) THE COLLECTED WORTKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 270
('35', 270, 0, 1, 505199) when I knew that I was ready for battle.
('35', 270, 0, 2, 505240) I pleaded with him to avoid the untold hardships that the Indian settlers must suffer, if the great historic march 1 had to be undertaken.
('35', 270, 0, 3, 505379) It is true that he in his haughtiness turned a deaf ear; but I lost nothing.
('35', 270, 0, 4, 505456) I gained added strength by my humility.
('35', 270, 0, 5, 505496) So would I do in India when we are strong enough to put up a real fight for freedom.
('35', 270, 0, 6, 505581) Remember that ours is a non violent struggle.
('35', 270, 0, 7, 505627) It presupposes humility.
('35', 270, 0, 8, 505652) It is a truthful struggle and consiousness of truth should give us firmness.
('35', 270, 0, 9, 505729) We are not out to destroy men.
('35', 270, 0, 10, 505760) We own no enemy.
('35', 270, 0, 11, 505777) We have no ill will against a single soul on earth.
('35', 270, 0, 12, 505829) We mean to covert by our suffering.
('35', 270, 0, 13, 505865) I do not despair of converting the hardest hearted or the most selfish Englishman.
('35', 270, 0, 14, 505948) Every opportunity of meeting him is therefore welcome to me.
('35', 270, 0, 15, 506009) Let me distinguish.
('35', 270, 0, 16, 506029) Non violent non co operation means renuncia tion of the benefits of a system with which we non co operate.
('35', 270, 0, 17, 506136) We therefore renounce the benefits of schools, courts, titles, legislatures and offices set up under the system.
('35', 270, 0, 18, 506249) The most extensive and permanent part of our non co operation consists in the renunciation of foreign cloth which is the foundation for the vicious system that is crushing us to dust.
('35', 270, 0, 19, 506433) It is possible to think of other items of non co operation.
('35', 270, 0, 20, 506493) But owing to our weakness or want of ability, we have restricted ourselves to these items only.
('35', 270, 0, 21, 506589) If then I go to any official for the purpose of seeking the benefits above named, I co operate.
('35', 270, 0, 22, 506685) Whereas if I go to the meanest official for the purpose of converting him, say to khaddar, or weaning him from his service or persuading him to withdraw his children from Government schools, I fulfil my duty as a non co operator.
('35', 270, 0, 23, 506915) I should fail if I did not go to him with that definite and direct purpose.
('35', 270, 0, 24, 506991) Now for the case in point.
('35', 270, 0, 25, 507018) I went to the Acting Governor at his instance.
('35', 270, 0, 26, 507065) He wrote to me not as Governor nor for any purpose connected with his office as Governor.
('35', 270, 0, 27, 507155) He invited me to go to Mahabaleshwar to discuss with him agricultural matters.
('35', 270, 0, 28, 507234) As I explained some time ago in the pages of Navajivan, I told him that I could not be identified with the Royal Commission in any way, that I was still confirmed in my views on non co operation and generally had no faith in Commisions.
('35', 270, 0, 29, 507471) I added further that it would suit me to see him when he descened to the plains.
('35', 270, 0, 30, 507552) His Excellency therefore wrote saying it would suit him to meet me in June.
('35', 270, 0, 31, 507628) But susbequently he changed his
('35', 270, 1, 32, 507660) 1 On November 6, 1913, against the £3 tax; vide “Telegram to Minister of Interior”, 7 11 1913.
('35', 270, 2, 33, 507755) VOL.35 : 2 APRIL, 1926 7 JULY, 1926 271
('35', 271, 0, 1, 507795) mind and sent a message that it would suit him better if I could go to Mahabaleshwar.
('35', 271, 0, 2, 507881) I had no hesitation in going there.
('35', 271, 0, 3, 507917) We had two very pleasant and long talks.
('35', 271, 0, 4, 507958) And you are entitled to guess (and that correctly) that our talk revolved round the charkha.
('35', 271, 0, 5, 508051) That was the central theme.
('35', 271, 0, 6, 508079) And I could not discuss agriculture without discussing the terrific cattle problem!
('35', 271, 0, 7, 508163) I have given but a brief summary of the pleasant conversation I had with the No change friend.
('35', 271, 0, 8, 508258) In parts I have amplified my answer in order to make it more intelligible to the general reader.
('35', 271, 0, 9, 508355) There were many other points discussed, of which I must mention one or two.
('35', 271, 0, 10, 508431) I was asked to give my opinion on the Sabarmati pact.
('35', 271, 0, 11, 508485) I refused to say anything for publication.
('35', 271, 0, 12, 508528) I must not add to the existing bitterness into the controversy.
('35', 271, 0, 13, 508592) I can say nothing that would bring the parties together.
('35', 271, 0, 14, 508649) They are all my co workers.
('35', 271, 0, 15, 508677) They are all patriots.
('35', 271, 0, 16, 508700) The quarrel is purely domestic.
('35', 271, 0, 17, 508732) It behoves me as a humble servant of the country to be silent where speech is useless.
('35', 271, 0, 18, 508819) I prefer therefore to wait and pray.
('35', 271, 0, 19, 508856) I was told that I was misrepresented.
('35', 271, 0, 20, 508894) I must own that I have studiously avoided reading the literature about the pact.
('35', 271, 0, 21, 508975) I am used to misrepresentation all my life.
('35', 271, 0, 22, 509019) It is the lot of every public worker.
('35', 271, 0, 23, 509057) He has to have a tough hide.
('35', 271, 0, 24, 509086) Life would be burdensome if every misrepresentation had to be answered and cleared.
('35', 271, 0, 25, 509170) It is a rule of life with me never to explain misrepresen tations except when the cause requires correction.
('35', 271, 0, 26, 509279) This rule has saved much time and worry.
('35', 271, 0, 27, 509320) “But what should we do when all accept offices and what should we do at the forthcoming elections?” was the last question.
('35', 271, 0, 28, 509443) My answer was: When the acceeptance of office by all parties becomes a settled fact I presume those who have conscientious scruples will refrain from voting altogether.
('35', 271, 0, 29, 509612) At the forthcoming elections, too, those who have conscientious objections will refrain.
('35', 271, 0, 30, 509701) The others will naturally follow the Congress lead and vote as the Congress directs.
('35', 271, 0, 31, 509786) I have given my definition of a Congressman already in these pages.
('35', 271, 0, 32, 509854) Not every man who says, “I am a Congressman” is such, but only he who does the will of the Congress.
