('35', 271, 1, 34, 509978) 355. SPINNING AN ART
('35', 271, 2, 35, 509999) A Madras Inspectress of Education has pronounced sentence
('35', 271, 3, 36, 510057) THE COLLECTED WORTKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 272
('35', 272, 0, 1, 510100) against the spinning wheel for Brahmin girls.
('35', 272, 0, 2, 510146) This judgment of hers has given rise to criticism against the lady.
('35', 272, 0, 3, 510214) If the charkha is good enough for non Brahmin girls why not, it is argued, for Brahmin girls?
('35', 272, 0, 4, 510308) The question is apposite when caste arrogance is being levelled to the ground.
('35', 272, 0, 5, 510387) Moreover the Inspectress evidently does not know that the finest yarn is spun by Brahmin girls and that in many Brahmin families the tradition of spinning for the sacred thread is still kept up.
('35', 272, 0, 6, 510582) But a side question has arisen out of the criticism of the Inspectress.
('35', 272, 0, 7, 510654) Is spinning an art?
('35', 272, 0, 8, 510674) Is it not a humdrum monotonous process likely to weary the children?
('35', 272, 0, 9, 510743) Well all the evidence hitherto collected goes to show that spinning is an elegant art and the process itself is extremely pleasant.
('35', 272, 0, 10, 510875) No mechanical pull is enough to draw the various counts.
('35', 272, 0, 11, 510932) And those who do spinning as an art know the pleasure they derive when the fingers and the eyes infallibly guide the required count.
('35', 272, 0, 12, 511065) Art to be art must soothe.
('35', 272, 0, 13, 511092) I reproduced over a year ago the testimony of Sir Prabhashankar Pattani to show how after the day’s trying work he went to the charkha for soothing his nerves and giving him undisturbed sleep.
('35', 272, 0, 14, 511285) I extract the following passage from the letter of a friend who found solace for her shattered nerves in spinning:
('35', 272, 1, 15, 511400) .I hastened to my room and then in the dark struggled with
('35', 272, 2, 16, 511459) an anguish which rent me from top to toe, I prayed and strove for some time
('35', 272, 3, 17, 511535) and then turned to the spinning wheel and found in it a magical comfort.
('35', 272, 4, 18, 511608) quiet regular motion of its rhythm immediately steadied me and the thought of
('35', 272, 5, 19, 511686) its service brought me nearer to God.
('35', 272, 5, 20, 511724) This is not the solitary experience of one or two but many spinners.
('35', 272, 5, 21, 511793) It is however no use saying that spinning will be pleasurable to all because it has been the joy of many.
('35', 272, 5, 22, 511899) Painting is acknowledged to be an exquisite art.
('35', 272, 5, 23, 511948) But it is not everybody who takes to it.

('35', 275, 5, 7, 515311) NORMAN LEYS
('35', 275, 6, 8, 515323) THE ASHRAM, SABARMATI, May 28, 1926
('35', 275, 7, 9, 515359) DEAR FRIEND, I have your letter of the 26th ultimo forwarded through Mr. Vaze.
('35', 275, 7, 10, 515438) 2 I thank you for that latter.
('35', 275, 7, 11, 515469) I appreciate it for I know that it is only by a frank exchange of views that we come nearer one another.
('35', 275, 7, 12, 515574) For me the word ‘political’ is inclusive.
('35', 275, 7, 13, 515616) I do not divide different activities—political, social, religious, economical—into water tight compartments.
('35', 275, 7, 14, 515725) I look upon them all as one indivisible whole each running into the rest and affected by the rest.
('35', 275, 7, 15, 515824) I also believe with you that our political freedon properly so called will depend upon our ability to solve many of our domestic problems such as the communal trouble.
('35', 275, 7, 16, 515992) In other words, it will depend upon internal reforms.
('35', 275, 7, 17, 516046) The outward will be merely therefore a symptom of the inward.
('35', 275, 7, 18, 516108) I do not at all hold that this communal problem is insoluble.
('35', 275, 7, 19, 516170) It seems to defy human effort for the time being.
('35', 275, 7, 20, 516220) But I have the fullest faith in our ability finally to solve it.
('35', 275, 7, 21, 516285) It may be of course that before we reach a solution there will be bloody fights between the two.
('35', 275, 7, 22, 516382) In spite of all efforts sometimes they become as it were unavoidable.
('35', 275, 7, 23, 516452) I would however like to add a word of caution against thinking, if you did think, that these communal troubles are not due to our dependence upon the British rule.
('35', 275, 7, 24, 516616) It is my conviction that rule is based upon the policy of ‘divide and rule’ which policy sometimes English officials have been frank enough to admit.
('35', 275, 7, 25, 516766) If the Government chose, it can certainly contribute much to a speedy and permanent solution.

('35', 283, 3, 20, 528928) 370. DRAFT HOUSING SCHEME FOR MILL WORKERS 2
('35', 283, 4, 21, 528973) The additional sums that may be received, if the demand for increase in wages is conceded, should be utilized for one year to implement a housing scheme for workers.
('35', 283, 4, 22, 529139) Under this scheme, it is intended to build houses for workers, which would meet the health requirements of the workers, and provide them necessary amenities and yet not be beyond the means of the ordinary working man.
('35', 283, 4, 23, 529357) In every locality with houses built under this scheme, every provision will be made to meet the common needs of the workers living
('35', 283, 5, 24, 529488) 1 Vide “Letter to K. T. Paul”, 23 5 1926.
('35', 283, 6, 25, 529530) 2 The scheme was formulated to suggest the right manner of utilizing the additional wages which the workers of Ahmedabad might get if the 15 percent cut effected in 1923 was restored.
('35', 283, 6, 26, 529714) Only the chief clauses of the scheme were reproduced in the source.
('35', 283, 7, 27, 529782) THE COLLECTED WORTKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 284
('35', 284, 0, 1, 529825) there and provide them other facilities.
('35', 284, 0, 2, 529866) These will include, funds permitting, schools, gardens, halls with facilities for playing games, libraries, shops and dispensaries.
('35', 284, 0, 3, 529998) A committee consisting of representative of the Labour Union and the the Millowners’ Association—the former being in a majority—will implement this scheme in accordance with the conditions of the Trust, will look after the properties and manage the fund.
('35', 284, 0, 4, 530253) The management of the properties will be with the Labour Union.
('35', 284, 0, 5, 530317) All workers employed in the mills during the current year and entitled to an increase in their wages will be regarded as joint owners of the funds of the Trust and the property purchased with that money.
('35', 284, 0, 6, 530521) The share of each worker in the property will be in proportion to his contrbution to the fund.
('35', 284, 0, 7, 530616) Each such worker who is a joint owner of the property will be given a share certificate.
('35', 284, 0, 8, 530705) Shareholders will not be permitted to sell or mortgage their shares to any person or body other than the Trust except in accordance with the conditions to be laid down by the Trust.
('35', 284, 0, 9, 530887) Houses will be allotted to workers on the results of lots drawn for the purpose.
('35', 284, 0, 10, 530968) The claims of shareholders will receive priority.
('35', 284, 0, 11, 531018) The decision to implement this scheme will be taken after obtaining in writing the votes of workers in every department and ascertaining whether there is a two thirds majority in favour of it.
('35', 284, 0, 12, 531211) If it is decided to utilize the increased quantum of wages in this manner, no demand for a further increase in wages will be made for a period of one year thereafter, and if, in violation of this condition, any workers go on strike for increase in wages, such workers will not be entitled to take benefit of this scheme for a period to be decided by the Trustees.

('35', 288, 3, 13, 540894) 373. THE SPINNING WHEEL IN GUJARAT
('35', 288, 4, 14, 540929) The reader will find elsewhere in this issue some information collected by Shri Lakshmidas concerning the progress of spinning in Gujarat.
('35', 288, 4, 15, 541068) We can see from it that even in big cities like Ahmedabad and Nadiad spinning has been adotped only by a few isolated individuals.
('35', 288, 4, 16, 541199) We must admit that it has a very limited field, but we can see that for those women who do spinning it is the only work they can take up.
('35', 288, 4, 17, 541337) No effort is made to induce a woman to take up spinning if she can earn more through some other work.
('35', 288, 4, 18, 541439) The spinning wheel has a place in our life which nothing else can fill.
('35', 288, 4, 19, 541511) It has been conceived only for those people who have no other honest means of livelihood, but in a vast and thickly populated country like India spinning is the only work which crores can take up.
('35', 288, 4, 20, 541708) If people can be found to ply it for money even in cities like Ahmedabad and Nadiad, we can easily imagine how useful it can prove in the villages.
('35', 288, 4, 21, 541856) If we do not hear the sweet music of
('35', 288, 5, 22, 541893) VOL.35 : 2 APRIL, 1926 7 JULY, 1926 289
('35', 289, 0, 1, 541933) this annapurna, the spinning wheel, in the homes of the poor, it is for lack of sufficient number of dedicated, self sacrificing and intelligent workers.
('35', 289, 0, 2, 542087) There is, of course, the other equally strong reason for this state of affairs, namely, that very little khadi is used in Gujarat.
('35', 289, 0, 3, 542218) It will come to be universally used, like wheat and ghee, and all the khadi produced will be sold out, when national consciousness has fully developed in us.
('35', 289, 0, 4, 542376) We have not yet entered the homes of the poor in Gujarat, have not qualified ourselves nor do we feel the desire to do so.
('35', 289, 0, 5, 542499) When we really feel a new life in us, large numbers of young men will come forward to go into villages and serve the people, and they will take pride in living on the modest return they will get from such service.

('35', 302, 0, 1, 563066) 395. THE BAR SINISTER
('35', 302, 1, 2, 563088) Lord Birkenhead has spoken on the Colour Bar Bill of South Africa and he has blessed it.
('35', 302, 1, 3, 563177) I hold to my opinion that as a piece of racial legis lation it is worse than the Class Areas Reservation Bill which awaits discussion at the forthcoming Conference.
('35', 302, 1, 4, 563342) It may not be put into operati on against Asiatics for the time being or at all.
('35', 302, 1, 5, 563423) It may not be enforced ha rshly against the Native population.
('35', 302, 1, 6, 563486) But the objection against that mea sure is based upon a fundamental principle and upon the vast possibilities of mischief it contains.
('35', 302, 1, 7, 563621) It is no wonder, therefore, that the Indian settlers are agitated and that Mr. Andrews has spoken strongly upon it.
('35', 302, 1, 8, 563737) The settlers must continue their agitation against the Bill with vigour and prepare their case for presentation to the Conference.
('35', 302, 1, 9, 563868) No presentation can avoid reference to the Colour Bar Bill.
('35', 302, 1, 10, 563928) For the one reflects the policy of the other.
('35', 302, 1, 11, 563974) The Colour Bar Bill is an indication of the designs of the Union Government in respect of Natives and Indian settlers.
('35', 302, 1, 12, 564093) And the Class Areas Reservation Bill must be examined in the light of the Government policy on the Colour Bar Bill.
('35', 302, 1, 13, 564209) The postponement of the former does not mean any change of policy.
('35', 302, 1, 14, 564276) It may well mean only postponement of the agony.
('35', 302, 1, 15, 564325) It is therefore necessary for all who are interested in this thorny question not to relax vigilance.
('35', 302, 1, 16, 564426) What has been done hitherto was work of destruction.
('35', 302, 1, 17, 564479) The more difficult work of construction has now begun.
('35', 302, 1, 18, 564534) Much will depend upon the attitude of the Government of India.
('35', 302, 1, 19, 564597) They control the situation if the settlers are weak.
('35', 302, 1, 20, 564650) When the latter are strong they can mould their own destiny.
('35', 302, 1, 21, 564711) But I am sorry to note that the Hon.
('35', 302, 1, 22, 564748) Syed Raza Ali considers that there should be no protest in India against the Colour Bar Bill.
('35', 302, 1, 23, 564842) Though he commences his statement by saying that it is not a legislative measure against Indians, ‘he is forced to admit that the Union Government will under the Bill have the power to extend such prohibition to our people if it deems it necessary’.
('35', 302, 1, 24, 565092) Why is he then surprised at Mr. Andrews’ opposition?
('35', 302, 1, 25, 565145) The Syed Saheb should also know that the Indian settlers in South Africa are much agitated over the Bill.
('35', 302, 1, 26, 565251) In a cable just received, the Secretary of the South African Indian Congress says: ‘Trust strong action taken by you on Colour Bar Bill which has not yet received the Royal assent.’ Mr. Andrews is bound to
('35', 302, 2, 27, 565457) VOL.35 : 2 APRIL, 1926 7 JULY, 1926 303
('35', 303, 0, 1, 565497) object to this inhuman legislation which is principally aimed at Natives of South Africa, if he may be expected to raise his voice on behalf of us Indains.
('35', 303, 0, 2, 565653) He has merged himself in us as a citizen of the world, not for any special virtues of our own.
('35', 303, 0, 3, 565748) But the reason for his intervention is not the point at issue.
('35', 303, 0, 4, 565811) The point at issue raised by the Syed Saheb is whether we here should oppose the Bill or not.
('35', 303, 0, 5, 565905) Well, we have always opposed it.
('35', 303, 0, 6, 565938) The settlers have always opposed it.
('35', 303, 0, 7, 565975) And there is no burden on us, now that the Conference is agreed upon not to oppose the Bill.
('35', 303, 0, 8, 566068) There was—could be—no tacit understanding not to oppose it.
('35', 303, 0, 9, 566128) We may distinguish as we have distinguished between the two measures.
('35', 303, 0, 10, 566198) The Colour Bar Bill is not so deadly in its effect against us as the Class Areas Reservation Bill.
('35', 303, 0, 11, 566297) And therefore it was that greater stress was put upon the latter by the Indian deputation and the public.
('35', 303, 0, 12, 566403) But the opposition to the former cannot be abated because the latter has been postponed.
('35', 303, 0, 13, 566492) Nor are the honesty and good intentions of General Hertzok relevant to the discussion.
('35', 303, 0, 14, 566579) General Hertzog is not the autocrat of South Africa.
('35', 303, 0, 15, 566632) He is no permanent head.
('35', 303, 0, 16, 566657) He may find himself tomorrow in the same place 1 that General Smuts occupies today.
('35', 303, 0, 17, 566741) It is only the written undertaking of the Government that can be taken into account, though we have found to our cost that even written undertakings may be thrown on the scrapheap when occasion requires the performance.
('35', 303, 0, 18, 566961) The coming Conference cannot be endangered because we oppose a measure which it is our duty to oppose.
('35', 303, 0, 19, 567064) In order to ensure a peaceful atmosphere at the Conference all that is necessary is for us not to impute motives, not to exaggerate and not to use harsh language in discussing subjects, however painful they may be.
('35', 303, 0, 20, 567279) To go beyond is to surrender the right of free and just criticism and judgment.
('35', 303, 0, 21, 567359) To do so would be to pay a price out of all proportion to the result sought to be achieved.

('35', 303, 2, 23, 567473) 396. NATIONAL EDUCATION 2
('35', 303, 3, 24, 567499) A Gujarati correspondent has raised certain questions about
('35', 303, 4, 25, 567559) 1 Among the opposition 2 Vide also “Non co operation and Education”, 30 5 1926.
('35', 303, 5, 26, 567639) THE COLLECTED WORTKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 304
('35', 304, 0, 1, 567682) national education.
('35', 304, 0, 2, 567702) Some of them are summarized below: Since some of the staunchest supporters of non co operation have lost faith in it and since the numbers attending national institutions are dwindling, what is the use of holding on to these tottering schools and colleges and wasting good money after bad institutions?
('35', 304, 0, 3, 568005) My believing eye detects a flaw in this argument.
('35', 304, 0, 4, 568055) My faith in non co operation remaining as staunch as ever, I can find it possible to reconcile myself to the existing national institutions even though the attendance may be reduced to half a dozen.
('35', 304, 0, 5, 568254) For the half a dozen will be the makers of swaraj whenever it comes.
('35', 304, 0, 6, 568323) When virgins are required to perform certain sacred ceremonies, others are not accepted as substitute if no virgin is found.
('35', 304, 0, 7, 568448) And even one virgin if found is enough to save the situation.
('35', 304, 0, 8, 568510) So will it be with the planting of the swaraj flag post.
('35', 304, 0, 9, 568567) The flags will be unfurled with the unsullied hands of those, be they ever so few, who have remained true to their creed.
('35', 304, 0, 10, 568689) I do not therefore regard it as waste of money to continue the national institutions.
('35', 304, 0, 11, 568775) They are so many oases in the desert.
('35', 304, 0, 12, 568813) They give the water of life to the souls thirsting for freedom.
('35', 304, 0, 13, 568877) In writing this I cast no reflection upon those who attend or otherwise support Government schools.
('35', 304, 0, 14, 568977) They are entitled to hold the view if they choose that theirs is the only way or also a way to freedom.
('35', 304, 0, 15, 569081) National institutions are meant for those whose thirst for freedom is not satisfied by the ones managed or patronized by the Government.
('35', 304, 0, 16, 569218) Few as they are, insignificant though they may appear, they supply a felt want and contain in them the seeds, as it appears to non co operators, of true and lasting freedom.
('35', 304, 0, 17, 569392) The final success of these institutions depends upon the worth of the teachers.
('35', 304, 0, 18, 569472) “But they are deserting the national schools and colleges,” says the critic.
('35', 304, 0, 19, 569549) So some of them are.
('35', 304, 0, 20, 569570) It tries the faith of the survivors.
('35', 304, 0, 21, 569607) Have they the courage to stand alone?
('35', 304, 0, 22, 569645) Are there enough monied men to support the surviving national institutions?
('35', 304, 0, 23, 569721) On the correct answer to these questions depends the future of the national institutions and with them the freedom of the country, and so far as I can judge, there are teachers enough to stand the severest test and there are monied men enough to support them.
('35', 304, 0, 24, 569981) I know no organization that has died for want of funds.
('35', 304, 0, 25, 570037) Organizations die always for want of men, i.
('35', 304, 0, 26, 570082) e., honesty, efficiency and selfsacrifice.
('35', 304, 0, 27, 570125) And it is my certain knowledge that where there are teachers, pupils are not wanting.
('35', 304, 0, 28, 570211) But the pupils have perhaps the largest share of responsibility on
('35', 304, 1, 29, 570278) VOL.35 : 2 APRIL, 1926 7 JULY, 1926 305
('35', 305, 0, 1, 570318) their shoulders.
('35', 305, 0, 2, 570335) The future depends upon their ability, integrity, application, and patriotism.
('35', 305, 0, 3, 570414) The teachers cannot give what the pupils have not.
('35', 305, 0, 4, 570465) The teachers can help to ‘draw out’ in the pupils what they have.
('35', 305, 0, 5, 570531) If it were otherwise, if the teachers were capable of putting something into their pupils, all the latter receiving instruction under them will be alike, whereas we know as a matter of fact that no two pupils have been yet known to be alike.
('35', 305, 0, 6, 570773) The pupils must therefore have initiative.
('35', 305, 0, 7, 570816) They must cease to be mere imitators.
('35', 305, 0, 8, 570854) They must learn to think and act for themselves and yet be thoroughly obedient and disciplined.
('35', 305, 0, 9, 570950) The highest form of freedom carries with it the greatest measure of discipline and humilty.
('35', 305, 0, 10, 571042) Freedom that comes from discipline and humility cannot be denied; unbridled licence is a sign of vulgarity injurious alike to self and one’s neighbours.

NOTES SERVANTS OF INDIA SOCIETY’S LOSS I have received the following 1 from the Servants of India Society for publication : I have not the slightest doubt that not only will the subscribers excuse the unavoidable intrerruption in the publication of the two journals, but that the Society will have the fullest sympathy of the subscribers and numerous other friends like myself in the great loss that the Society, or rather the public, have suffered by the destruction of the two presses.
('35', 305, 1, 13, 571710) I hope that the publication of the Servant of India and the Dnyan Prakash will be soon resumed.
('35', 305, 1, 14, 571806) PATRIOTISM v.
('35', 305, 1, 15, 571820) CAPITALISM These two “isms” are no doubt contradictory or have been so hitherto.
('35', 305, 1, 16, 571901) But capital is totally different from capitalism and the capitalist from both.
('35', 305, 1, 17, 571980) Capital is necessary for all enterprise.
('35', 305, 1, 18, 572021) Labour itself may be described as a kind of capital.
('35', 305, 1, 19, 572074) But even in the narrower sense of money, some capital, be it ever so little, is necessary even for labour’s enterprise.
('35', 305, 1, 20, 572194) Therefore there is no contradiction between capital and patriotism.
('35', 305, 1, 21, 572262) A capitalist may or may not be patriotic.
('35', 305, 1, 22, 572304) Khan Bahadur Mohiuddin Ahmed, Registrar of Co operative Societies in Bihar, has pointed out a patriotic way to the capitalist.
('35', 305, 1, 23, 572431) The Times of India says : On the occasion of the opening ceremony of the new building of the Motihari Central Co operative Bank, the Khan Bahadur, in his speech, distinguished harmful from useful capitalism.
('35', 305, 1, 24, 572639) He suggested that industrial activities should be divided into two classes, one to be taken up by the capitalists and the other to be taken up on
('35', 305, 2, 25, 572785) 1 Statement on the fire which had destroyed the two presses where the Society’s journals were being printed
('35', 305, 3, 26, 572893) THE COLLECTED WORTKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 306
('35', 306, 0, 1, 572936) VOL.35 : 2 APRIL, 1926 7 JULY, 1926 307
('35', 306, 1, 2, 572976) co operative lines for the benefit of 90 per cent of the population in India.
('35', 306, 1, 3, 573054) Any industry based on agricultural produce such as cotton, sugar, oil seeds, wheat, etc., should be on a co operative basis so that the producers could secure the best value for their outturn.
('35', 306, 1, 4, 573247) All sorts of mining and iron works, leather and other large scale industries, which do not exploit the agriculturists, should be left to the capitalists so that they may also use their capital for more production of wealth in the country rather than forexploiting the farmers and thereby sapping the very source of wealth in India.
('35', 306, 1, 5, 573579) If the capitalists would follow the Khan Bahadur’s advice and restrict the use of their capital for purposes beneficial alike to the masses as also themselves, India’s poverty would soon be a thing of the past.
('35', 306, 1, 6, 573790) In the Khan Bahadur’s opinion :
('35', 306, 2, 7, 573822) Jute mills, sugar mills, cotton mills are all meant to exploit the agriculturists and these exploited men are driven into the factories to work like slaves.
('35', 306, 2, 8, 573979) The jute millowners of Bengal did not show the least concern for the Bengal jute growers during the War when foreign export was closed.
('35', 306, 2, 9, 574115) The result of this exploitation was that the jute growers were reduced to poverty and jute millowners realized cent per cent dividends.
('35', 306, 3, 10, 574251) RESOURCEFULNESS The manager of the Satyagraha Ashram tells me that he has more orders than he can cope with for taklis.
('35', 306, 3, 11, 574371) It is a healthy sign that so many people want taklis.
('35', 306, 3, 12, 574425) But if spinning is, and it is, an art, it must evoke one’s resourcefulness.
('35', 306, 3, 13, 574501) It is not possible to supply millions of taklis in one centre.
('35', 306, 3, 14, 574564) The virtue of spinning lies in its capacity to be independent of central help.
('35', 306, 3, 15, 574643) The aim of the All India Spinners’ Association is to de centralize everything at the earliest possible moment.
('35', 306, 3, 16, 574754) Taklis are being manufactured at the Ashram for those who need inducement to make the effort.
('35', 306, 3, 17, 574848) But it is an insturment that can be and should be made by every one for himself.
('35', 306, 3, 18, 574929) A simple piece of dried bamboo, a piece of broken slate, a knife, a little hammer, a small file, and if possible a compass, is all that is necessary to make first class taklis at one pice each.
('35', 306, 3, 19, 575123) A bamboo takli can be made inside of half an hour and gives just as good work as the steel instrument.
('35', 306, 3, 20, 575226) Those who will master the art must be resourceful.
('35', 306, 3, 21, 575277) Let us remember that spinning is the poor man’s art.
('35', 306, 3, 22, 575330) It is his solace.
('35', 306, 3, 23, 575348) The tools also of that art must be within easy reach of the poorest.
('35', 306, 3, 24, 575417) Let each boy and girl be therefore taught to make the takli himself or herself.
('35', 306, 3, 25, 575497) They will take pleasure in making their own taklis and greater pleasure than hitherto in spinning with taklis made by themselves.
('35', 307, 0, 1, 575627) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 308
('35', 307, 1, 2, 575669) GOOD AND BAD The Vice Chairman of the Berhampur Municipal Council says in his letter to the All India Spinners’ Association : Only boys’ schools have been supplied with 54 charkhas.
('35', 307, 1, 3, 575851) Ten tolas of
('35', 307, 2, 4, 575864) yarn is being spun per month.
('35', 307, 2, 5, 575894) Rs. 15 a month is paid to the spinning instruc tor.
('35', 307, 2, 6, 575946) One period of 40 minutes is allotted for spinning in each school per day.
('35', 307, 2, 7, 576020) This is good in so far that the wheel has found a place in the boys’ schools under the Berhampur Municipal Council.
('35', 307, 2, 8, 576136) But it is bad in that the output of yarn is too poor for the number of the wheels.
('35', 307, 2, 9, 576219) A boy can easily spin half a tola of 10 counts per half hour.
('35', 307, 2, 10, 576281) That means 27 tolas per day from 54 wheels.
('35', 307, 2, 11, 576325) And that would be 675 tolas per month of twenty five working days.
('35', 307, 2, 12, 576392) A spinning insturctor who is satisfied with only 10 tolas per month out of 54 wheels does not deserve to draw Rs. 15 per month of national money.
('35', 307, 2, 13, 576538) I hope that there is some mistake in the figures sent.
('35', 307, 2, 14, 576593) For ten tolas per month would be too little even for one wheel.
('35', 307, 2, 15, 576657) The wheels are not ornamental furniture.
('35', 307, 2, 16, 576698) They are wealth producing machines.
('35', 307, 2, 17, 576734) And it is up to the keepers to see that thay are not left idle.
('35', 307, 2, 18, 576798) Every spinning instructor should deem it a point of honour to earn his wages by ensuring production enough to pay them.
('35', 307, 2, 19, 576918) And this he can do easily when he has a large class and he does not mind himself carding and making slivers for the boys.
('35', 307, 2, 20, 577040) It is the best way of interesting and instructing his pupils in the art of spinning.
('35', 307, 2, 21, 577125) Let it be remembered that spinning includes carding and ginning.
('35', 307, 2, 22, 577190) And carding and ginning are processes that fetch more money per day than spinning.
('35', 307, 3, 23, 577273) APRIL FIGURES
('35', 307, 4, 24, 577287) The following are the figures 1 for production and sale of khadi during the month of April : The Andhra figures are incomplete and to some extent even the Karnatak figures.

('35', 307, 4, 26, 577582) I do wish we could make the figures complete for all the provinces.

('35', 315, 10, 17, 588518) 412. LETTER TO A MUSLIM LEADER
('35', 315, 11, 18, 588549) THE ASHRAM, SABARMATI, June 4, 1926
('35', 315, 12, 19, 588585) BHAISAHEB, For many days now I have been thinking of writing to you.
('35', 315, 12, 20, 588654) I had no intention of writing in English , and have none now.
('35', 315, 12, 21, 588716) I wanted to write at length, and it is hard for me to write such a long letter in the Urdu script.
('35', 315, 12, 22, 588815) This I am getting written in the Urdu Script by a brother of an Ashram inmate.
('35', 315, 12, 23, 588894) I have your message from Brother Andrews.
('35', 315, 12, 24, 588936) I wanted to write to you even before I got the message, in
('35', 316, 0, 1, 588995) VOL.35 : 2 APRIL, 1926 7 JULY, 1926 317
('35', 316, 1, 2, 589035) fact since the time Alibhai went to Mecca.
('35', 316, 1, 3, 589078) Regarding the Hindu Muslim question I have deliberately refrained form saying anything.
('35', 316, 1, 4, 589166) What can I write?
('35', 316, 1, 5, 589184) To whom can I tell the tale of my woe?
('35', 316, 1, 6, 589223) I know very well that I have no influence whatsoever over the quarrelling elements.
('35', 316, 1, 7, 589307) Bhai Shaukat Ali and Manzur Ali spoke to me at length about your grief, and I have also been given to understand that you were rather pained at my silence.
('35', 316, 1, 8, 589463) Since I am unable to bring about a compromise what is the good of my writing?
('35', 316, 1, 9, 589541) I cannot bring myself to believe the various Press reports.
('35', 316, 1, 10, 589601) I am asked to make a public statement that Malaviyaji and others are enemies of the Muslims, the Hindus ask me to make a similar statement regarding the Muslim leaders.
('35', 316, 1, 11, 589770) How can I write something which I do not believe?
('35', 316, 1, 12, 589820) I cannot accept that Malaviyaji and others are enemies of the Muslims; this does not however mean I approve of everything they do.
('35', 316, 1, 13, 589951) Nor can I agree to calling Mahomed Ali an enemy of the Hindus.
('35', 316, 1, 14, 590014) In his case, too, I do not approve of all he does.
('35', 316, 1, 15, 590065) I am asked to state my opinion regarding the Calcutta affair.
('35', 316, 1, 16, 590127) 1 What opinion can I give out?
('35', 316, 1, 17, 590158) I have no occult power by which to know who started the trouble in Calcutta and whose crime was heavier.
('35', 316, 1, 18, 590263) But I do know that the parties are both prejudiced against each other, they look only for each other’s faults and have lost mutual trust.
('35', 316, 1, 19, 590401) In the circumstances there is no other way for a person like me but to keep my peace.
('35', 316, 1, 20, 590487) I cannot tolerate the killing of even a single Muslim or Hindu or for that matter of any human being.
('35', 316, 1, 21, 590589) Nor can I tolerate the destruction of a mosque or a temple or a church.
('35', 316, 1, 22, 590661) It is my belief that the same God that dwells in the heart of a Hindu is enshrined in the heart of every other person.
('35', 316, 1, 23, 590780) And I also believe that a temple belongs to God as much as a mosque.
('35', 316, 1, 24, 590849) I can never agree to the rule of blood for blood and temple for a mosque.
('35', 316, 1, 25, 590923) But who listens to me?
('35', 316, 1, 26, 590946) It is my firm belief, however, that God does not approve of this rule of blood and temple for a mosque.
('35', 316, 1, 27, 591050) A day will come when Hindus and Muslims will own their guilt, feel sorry for their behaviour and unite with each other.
('35', 316, 1, 28, 591170) This is the culmination that I wish to witness in my life time.
('35', 316, 1, 29, 591234) And I always pray to God to recall me from this world if I am not to see the light of that day.
('35', 316, 1, 30, 591330) My desire to live springs solely from this hope.
('35', 316, 1, 31, 591379) And I want you
('35', 316, 2, 32, 591394) 1 here were two outbursts of communal rioting in Calcutta during April and May 1926.
('35', 317, 0, 1, 591479) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 318
('35', 317, 1, 2, 591521) too to cherish this hope with me and never despair.
('35', 317, 1, 3, 591573) Brother Andrews tells me about your proposal that Brother Stokes and he should invite, on their own, a few Hindus and Muslims and attempt a reconciliation.
('35', 317, 1, 4, 591729) I am afraid their efforts cannot achieve this task.
('35', 317, 1, 5, 591781) Nor is the time ripe to bring the Hindus and Muslims together in this way.
('35', 317, 1, 6, 591856) You alone can bring them together when the time comes.
('35', 317, 1, 7, 591911) Those Muslims who are regarded as enemies of the Hindus as well as those Hindus that are supposed to be Muslim haters must also be invited to this conference.
('35', 317, 1, 8, 592070) What good can mere discussions bring when there is mutual mistrust and when people speak one thing and think another in their hearts?
('35', 317, 1, 9, 592204) I hope you are in Mussoorie and keeping well.

('35', 321, 3, 14, 599205) The immediate effect of this loss will be that two journals, Servant of India and Dnyan Prakash will not come out for some time.

('35', 322, 1, 2, 599787) 421. PROBLEM OF NON VIOLENCE
('35', 322, 2, 3, 599816) A gentleman writes as follows : 1
('35', 322, 3, 4, 599850) Such questions are frequently raised.
('35', 322, 3, 5, 599888) They cannot be brushed aside, either, as being trivial.
('35', 322, 3, 6, 599944) These problems have been discussed both in the West and the East in books dealing with the deeper meaning of life.
('35', 322, 3, 7, 600059) In my humble view, there is only one solution to these problems, since they all arise from the same cause.
('35', 322, 3, 8, 600166) The actions mentioned above certainly involve violence, for every motion or action involves it and, therefore, no action is altogether innocent.
('35', 322, 3, 9, 600311) The difference between one action and another lies only in the degree of violence involved in either.
('35', 322, 3, 10, 600413) The very association of the atman with the body rests on violence.
('35', 322, 3, 11, 600480) Every sin is a form of violence, and complete freedom from sin is possible only with the deliverance of the atman from the body.
('35', 322, 3, 12, 600609) A human being, therefore, may keep perfect non violence as his or her ideal and strive to follow it as completely as possible.
('35', 322, 3, 13, 600736) But no matter how near it he reaches, he will find some degree of violence unavoidable, in breathing or eating, for instance.
('35', 322, 3, 14, 600862) There is life in each grain which we consume.
('35', 322, 3, 15, 600908) When, therefore, we adopt a vegetarian diet and abstain from non vegetarian food we cannot claim that we completely avoid violence.
('35', 322, 3, 16, 601040) But we prefer the former and regard the violence involved in it as inescapable.
('35', 322, 3, 17, 601120) This is why eating for pleasure must never be indulged in.
('35', 322, 3, 18, 601179) We should eat only in order that we may live, and should live only to realize the self.
('35', 322, 3, 19, 601267) If our living for this purpose involves any violence, we may be a party to it as being unable to escape it.
('35', 322, 3, 20, 601375) We can now see that if, in spite of all our precautions, there are germs in the water and bugs [in the furniture], we may do whatever we find necessary to get rid of them.
('35', 322, 3, 21, 601547) I do not believe that it is a divine law that everyone should act in the same way at certain times and in certain circumstances.
('35', 322, 3, 22, 601676) Non violence is a quality of the heart.
('35', 322, 3, 23, 601716) Whether there is violence or non violence in our actions can be judged only by reference to the spirit behind them.
('35', 322, 3, 24, 601832) Everyone, therefore, who regards the observance of non violence as a moral duty should guide his actions by the principle stated above.
('35', 322, 3, 25, 601968) I know that there is a flaw in this reply.
('35', 322, 3, 26, 602011) One may commit violence as much as one chooses and then, deceiving oneself and the world, justify one’s actions with the plea of their being unvaoidable.
('35', 322, 4, 27, 602165) 1 The letter is not translated here.
('35', 322, 4, 28, 602202) The correspondent had asked for Gandhiji’s views about the impossibility of observing perfect non violence in practical life, since destruction of insects could never be completely avoided.
('35', 323, 0, 1, 602392) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 324
('35', 323, 1, 2, 602434) article is not meant for such persons.
('35', 323, 1, 3, 602473) It is addressed only to those who believe in the principle of non violence and are assailed by moral doubts from time to time.
('35', 323, 1, 4, 602600) Such persons will commit even unavoidable violence most hesitatingly, and limit, not expand, the scope of their activities, so much so that they will not use any of their powers for sel fish ends.
('35', 323, 1, 5, 602797) They will use all their energies for public service, dedicating to God everything they do.
('35', 323, 1, 6, 602888) All the gifts and abilities of a good man, that is, a non violent, compassionate man, are for service to others.
('35', 323, 1, 7, 603001) There is violence always in the attachment to one’s ego.
('35', 323, 1, 8, 603058) When doing anything, one must ask oneself this question : “Is my action inspired by egoistic attachment?” If there is no such attachment, then there is no violence.

('35', 327, 2, 3, 611308) THE ASHRAM, SABARMATI, June 6, 1926
('35', 327, 3, 4, 611344) DEAR FRIEND,
('35', 327, 4, 5, 611357) I have your letter and the original letters from the Committee of arrangements.
('35', 327, 4, 6, 611437) The letters make it clear to me that the idea of invitation was prompted by you out of your great goodwill towards me and your exaggerated notion of my influence over people especially the young mind.
('35', 327, 4, 7, 611638) But I feel more than ever convinced that the time is not yet for me to leave India on such pretext as is furnished by the correspondence before me.

('35', 330, 4, 8, 615960) 428. INTERVIEW ON COLOUR BAR BILL
('35', 330, 5, 9, 615994) AHMEDABAD, [On or before June 8, 1926] 1
('35', 330, 6, 10, 616035) Interviewed regarding the recent communique 2 of the Government of India on
('35', 330, 7, 11, 616111) the Colour Bar Bill, Mahatma Gandhi said: The assurance given in the communique in my opinion takes us no further than we were before it.
('35', 330, 7, 12, 616249) The Union Government have indeed repeatedly said that they have no present intention of extending the scope of the Bill beyond the position that existed prior to the judgment in Rex v.
('35', 330, 7, 13, 616434) Hildick Smith.
('35', 330, 7, 14, 616449) Opponents of the Bill, however, attack it on the principle that the enabling powers under it go much beyond the position anterior to the judgment and that it can be made applicable not merely to the natives of the soil but to Indians also.
('35', 330, 7, 15, 616689) Nor is it possible to derive any comfort from the fact that when the scope of the Regulations to be framed thereunder is extended, all parties in the Union will be enabled to make representations.
('35', 330, 7, 16, 616886) The Bill does not take away the right of petition, and one knows by this time the fact of the representations by parties without power to enforce their will.
('35', 330, 7, 17, 617044) I wonder if this assurance means that the party without the Union, namely the Government of India, will have no right of representation.
('35', 330, 7, 18, 617181) The Bombay Chronicle, 9 6 1926
('35', 330, 8, 19, 617212) 1 From the correspondent’s date line 2 Vide “Valueless Assurance”, 10 6 1926.

('35', 335, 2, 3, 623690) ASHRAM, SABARMATI, Tuesday, June 8, 1926
('35', 335, 3, 4, 623731) BHAI PRABHUDAS,
('35', 335, 4, 5, 623747) I have your detailed letter.
('35', 335, 4, 6, 623776) You did well to write.
('35', 335, 4, 7, 623799) Your argument is perfect, but it is my experience and also that of persons who have tried pranayam and other methods that brahmacharya cannot be observed merely with the help of pranayam.
('35', 335, 4, 8, 623987) But I believe pranayam, etc., help those who have acquired control over their mind.
('35', 335, 4, 9, 624071) We come across very few people who have made a deep study of the yoga from this point of view and have tried yogic methods.
('35', 335, 4, 10, 624195) If one takes only one meal a day, I have nothing to say.
('35', 335, 4, 11, 624252) But if one consumes at one sitting a quantity of food equal to three meals, that will not help him in brahmacharya.
('35', 335, 4, 12, 624368) This is a violation of it and it damages one’s health.
('35', 335, 4, 13, 624423) There are two opinions and I have my own doubts regarding the need of nutritious diet for the observance of brahmacharya.
('35', 335, 4, 14, 624545) But I do not want you to change your method if it greatly helps you in the observance of brahmacharya, if it keeps up your spiritual progress and all your senses are brought under control.
('35', 335, 4, 15, 624734) You should try your own method and effect such changes as your experience may dictate.
('35', 335, 4, 16, 624821) And if you succeed so that even your mind is not disturbed by passions the world will stand to gain by your experiment.
('35', 335, 4, 17, 624941) Remember that brahmacharya implies control of all the senses in respect of thought, speech and action.
('35', 335, 4, 18, 625044) According to this definition if you have a lustful eye or an evil thought or there is a discharge even in dream brahmacharya would be violated.

('35', 336, 6, 13, 625931) SERVANTS OF INDIA SOCIETY In the note issued by the Society upon the loss suffered by it owing to the recent fire nothing so much stirs one as the offer of the employees of the press.
('35', 336, 6, 14, 626115) It is evidence of the scrupulous care with which the Society has dealt by its employees.
('35', 336, 6, 15, 626204) Unless the latter felt the loss to be personal, they would not make the self sacrificing and handsome offer that they have made of forgoing half the bonus and offering to work without extra pay for ten instead of eight hours a day and the printer himself offering to work for six months without any pay whatsoever.
('35', 336, 6, 16, 626519) Both the Society and the employees deserve heartiest congratulations for this spirit of comradeship existing between what may be called Capital and Labour.
('35', 336, 6, 17, 626675) This expression of the excellent spirit is no small compensation for the tremendous losses the Society has suffered.
('35', 336, 6, 18, 626792) The loss of the valuable manuscripts containing Gokhale’s life and the files of the Dnyan Prakash for the last eighty years is indeed irreparable.
('35', 336, 6, 19, 626939) But it is only in this manner that Nature gives us rude shocks and reminds us that there is nothing permanent, nothing ever lasting except God himself; and that therefore ours is but honourably
('35', 337, 0, 1, 627133) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 338
('35', 337, 1, 2, 627175) and humbly to labour only to do His will irrespective of consequ ences.
('35', 337, 1, 3, 627247) The members of the Society are now manfully striving to restart without avoidable delay the interrupted activities.
('35', 337, 1, 4, 627363) The question is how will the public help.
('35', 337, 1, 5, 627405) Assurances have been given from many parts of India.
('35', 337, 1, 6, 627458) It is to be hoped that the assurances will be translated into action without delay and without fuss.
('35', 337, 1, 7, 627559) However much one may differ from the politics of the Society, there is no denying the honest and self sacrificing labours of its members, there is no denying their patriotism.
('35', 337, 1, 8, 627735) It stands unique in its great social activities no less valuable than the political.
('35', 337, 1, 9, 627820) I hope that the readers of Young India will show their appreciation of the many services of the Society, and their toleration where they differ from the Society’s politics, by sending in their subscriptions in response to its appeal.
('35', 337, 2, 10, 628054) SPINNING WHEEL IN MYSORE In his speech 1 at the District Conference, the Deputy Commissioner and the President of the District Board of Mysore presented spinning as a useful subsidiary occupation, and as pre eminetly suited in poor families to supplement the family income, and thus exhorted the local bodies and public spirited people to take it up in right earnest :
('35', 337, 3, 11, 628423) To secure increased popularity and to ensure its general adoption by the people .
('35', 337, 3, 12, 628505) it is necessary that the leaders in each village, the Yejmans the Sahukars, the Budhivantas should take to it.
('35', 337, 3, 13, 628616) I appeal to all Municipal
('35', 337, 4, 14, 628642) Councils, Panchayats, and Village Committees, Co operative Societies and other Associations to stock and sell charkha to the local people, and secure at least one trained weaver for their town or village, provide him with a loom, and get woven into dupaties and towels all the yarn locally spun by people
('35', 337, 5, 15, 628947) who could not drive any other trade or calling owing to age, infirmity, disease or lack of occupation.
('35', 337, 5, 16, 629050) The District Board hopes to be able to take full advantage in the coming year of the recent order of Government promising to meet half the cost of demonstrations and competitions arranged for weaving and spinning.
('35', 337, 5, 17, 629264) Here at least there is an official recognition of the spinning wheel.
('35', 337, 5, 18, 629334) The more the possibilities of this simple instrument are known, the greater will be its hold upon the people.

('35', 338, 1, 2, 629516) SPINNING FOR FAMINE RELIEF The Kathiawar Rajkiya Parishad is nursing a khadi centre in Kathiawar in and near Amreli by way of famine relief.
('35', 338, 1, 3, 629657) Though there is no actual famine there, for want of sufficient rain the cultivation has been below par for three successive years, the result being that many cultivators are living from hand to mouth.
('35', 338, 1, 4, 629858) It is in this centre that nearly a thousand farmers’ wives are supplementing their poor resources with wages earned from hand spinning.
('35', 338, 1, 5, 629994) Instead of these women remaining in idleness and in a state of semi starvation, they are earning from anything between one to three rupees per month according to the time they are able or willing to give to spinning.
('35', 338, 1, 6, 630211) Incidentally this work furnishes occupation for carders, weavers and washermen.
('35', 338, 1, 7, 630291) The difficulty however had to be confronted of selling khadi so made.
('35', 338, 1, 8, 630361) Mr. Abbas Tyabji came to the rescue and he, assisted by Sjts.
('35', 338, 1, 9, 630423) Amritlal Seth and Ramdas Gandhi, toured in parts of Kathiawar for the purpose of hawking the khadi.
('35', 338, 1, 10, 630523) It was not possible to sell it as cheap as khadi produced in some parts of India where carders, weavers, washermen and even spinners do not demand or receive the same wage as those in Kathiawar.
('35', 338, 1, 11, 630718) But Mr. Abbas Tyabji was able successfully to appeal to local patriotism for the disposal of his khadi.
('35', 338, 1, 12, 630822) And he tells me that nowhere was he put off by people, but, as soon as they understood what this khadi meant, they took all that he had to offer.
('35', 338, 1, 13, 630968) This khadi, as all other khadi, has had an interesting history.
('35', 338, 1, 14, 631032) Its price has gone down in the same proportion as it has risen in quality.
('35', 338, 1, 15, 631107) And yet there is plenty of room for improvement in the quality of khadi and decline of its prices.
('35', 338, 1, 16, 631206) The decline in prices and progress in improvement depend upon steady improvement in carding and spinning upon which increasingly great attention is being bestowed.
('35', 338, 1, 17, 631370) But the chief points to be noticed in this connection are that khadi has been the means of giving work and wages to poor women who would have been without either but for khadi and that there is unlimited scope for this work provided demand for khadi can be kept up.
('35', 338, 2, 18, 631636) PERIPATETIC KHADI EXHIBITION Khadi workers all the country over are discovering the great utility of khadi exhibitions in popularizing and demonstrating the various processes connected with cotton till it becomes khadi on the weavers’ loom.
('35', 338, 2, 19, 631877) Recently a peripatetic exhibition was organized in the district of Ratnagiri.
('35', 338, 2, 20, 631955) It covered eight villages.
('35', 338, 2, 21, 631982) In all these places
('35', 339, 0, 1, 632002) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 340
('35', 339, 1, 2, 632044) demonstrations were given in hand ginning, carding, spinning on the wheel as well as the takli, and methods of testing the strength of yarn.
('35', 339, 1, 3, 632185) There were exhibited samples of indigenous dyes, yarn spun by leaders, khadi of various grades and a small assortment of other swadeshi goods.
('35', 339, 1, 4, 632328) Whilst the exhibition was on, in the respective villages, hawking too was resorted to.
('35', 339, 1, 5, 632415) There was a reading room improvised which furnished literature on khadi.
('35', 339, 1, 6, 632488) There was a magic lantern demonstration.
('35', 339, 1, 7, 632529) Singing parties gave songs and bhajans 1. People were encouraged and enabled to subscribe to the All India Deshbandhu Memorial [Fund] and addresses on khadi were delivered by well known speakers.
('35', 339, 1, 8, 632725) The whole thing was organized in an efficient and inexpensive manner.
('35', 339, 1, 9, 632795) The expenses amounted to Rs. 622 9 11. And these were partly covered by profits made on the khadi sales.
('35', 339, 1, 10, 632900) There is no doubt that such exhibitions have a great educative value and further experience and consequent improvements may make them self supporting.

('35', 339, 4, 16, 633318) 440. VALUELESS ASSURANCE
('35', 339, 5, 17, 633343) The Union Government have, the Government of India tell the public in a communique, given the assurance that
('35', 339, 6, 18, 633452) there is no present intention on the part of the Union Government of extending the regulations beyond the position as it existed prior to the judgment of the Transvaal Provincial Division of the Supreme Court in the case, Rex v.
('35', 339, 6, 19, 633681) Hildick Smith, when it was held that certain regulations
('35', 339, 7, 20, 633738) with reference to miners and works, which have actually been in force in South Africa since 1911 and in certain provinces for many years before that date, were not valid under the sections of the Act in terms of which they were promulgated.
('35', 339, 8, 21, 633979) 1 Devotional songs 2 Not reproduced here
('35', 340, 0, 1, 634020) VOL.35 : 2 APRIL, 1926 7 JULY, 1926 341
('35', 340, 1, 2, 634060) The communique further states :
('35', 340, 2, 3, 634092) that the Government of India have also been assured that should any such extension of the scope of these regulations be contemplated in future, every reasonable opportunity will be given to all parties in the Union interested in the matter to make representations.
('35', 340, 2, 4, 634357) I hold these two assurances to be simple camouflage.
('35', 340, 2, 5, 634410) For the Union Government, in reply to questions in the Union House of Assembly, have been repeatedly saying the same thing that they have now told the Government of India, namely, that they had no present intention of exceeding the scope of the regulations beyond the position that existed prior to the judgment in question.
('35', 340, 2, 6, 634735) The sting of the new Bill lies in its enabling powers.
('35', 340, 2, 7, 634790) It is like the sword of Damocles hanging over the heads of both the Natives of South Africa and the Indian settlers, for, it can be made applicable to the latter precisely as the former.
('35', 340, 2, 8, 634977) The Bill is, therefore, as insulting as it can possibly be made.
('35', 340, 2, 9, 635042) Only it does not affect the material interests of the Indians as much as the Class Areas Bill, not because of any goodwill on the part of the Union Government, but because Indians as a rule do not take to labour, skilled or unskilled, of the kind contemplated under the Colour Bar Bill.
('35', 340, 2, 10, 635329) They are better touched materially through their trade and through restriction of residential rights.
('35', 340, 2, 11, 635431) And this is sought to be accomplished by the Class Areas Bill which is to be considered by the Round Table Conference.
('35', 340, 2, 12, 635550) The Colour Bar Bill shows the mentality of the Union Government and as The Times of India correspondent very properly says in effect the acceptance by the Union Government of the proposal for a Round Table Confe rence is a mere courteous gesture.
('35', 340, 2, 13, 635797) It is not to be interpreted to mean a change in the Union Government’s angle of vision.
('35', 340, 2, 14, 635885) And this deduc tion is further strengthened by the later information that in adumbrat ing his native policy, General Hertzog has made it clear that, whilst he is prepared to allow limited representation in the Union Parlia ment to the Natives and to the Coloured people, he will not allow any whatsoever to the Indian.
('35', 340, 2, 15, 636204) The result which The Times of India correspondent rightly deduces is that the Indian, in the estimation of General Hertzog, stands infinitely lower than the Native.
('35', 340, 2, 16, 636369) In fact, he is to be tolerated till he can be effaced from South Africa as a necessary evil.
('35', 340, 2, 17, 636462) The Colour Bar Bill therefore cannot be isolated from the different Acts of the Union Government.
('35', 340, 2, 18, 636560) It forms part of its settled policy and furnishes the key to it.
('35', 341, 0, 1, 636625) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 342
('35', 341, 1, 2, 636667) Nor is the second assurance given by the Union Government of the slightest value.
('35', 341, 1, 3, 636749) Is it any new right that they have conceded when they say that when the scope of the regulations is extended every reasonable opportunity will be given to all parties in the Union, interested in the matter, to make representations specially when it is known to them that representations of Indians carry no voting force behind them?
('35', 341, 1, 4, 637082) And, if the qualifying phrase in the communique means that parties outside the Union, that is, the Government of India or the Imperial Government will not be allowed even to make representations, surely the assurance is worse than useless, because, it is a restriction of which the announcement has been made and not a concession.

('35', 341, 2, 6, 637436) 441. WHAT IS PRAYER?
('35', 341, 3, 7, 637457) A medical graduate asks :
('35', 341, 4, 8, 637483) What is the best form of prayer?
('35', 341, 4, 9, 637516) How much time should be spent at it?
('35', 341, 4, 10, 637553) In my opinion to do justice is the best form of prayer and one who is sincere about doing justice to all does not need to do any more praying.
('35', 341, 4, 11, 637696) Some people spend a long time over Sandhya 1 and 95% of them do not understand the
('35', 341, 5, 12, 637779) meaning of what they say.
('35', 341, 5, 13, 637805) In my opinion prayer should be said in one’s mother tongue.
('35', 341, 5, 14, 637865) It alone can affect the soul best.
('35', 341, 5, 15, 637900) I should say that a sincere prayer for one minute is enough.
('35', 341, 5, 16, 637961) It should suffice to promise God not to sin.
('35', 341, 5, 17, 638006) Prayer means asking God for something in a reverent attitude.
('35', 341, 5, 18, 638068) But the word is used also to denote any devotional act.
('35', 341, 5, 19, 638124) Worship is a better term to use for what the correspondent has in mind.
('35', 341, 5, 20, 638196) But definition apart, what is it that millions of Hindus, Mussalmans, Christians and Jews and others do every day during the time set apart for the adoration of the Maker?
('35', 341, 5, 21, 638368) It seems to me that it is a yearning of the heart to be one with the Maker, an invocation for His blessing.
('35', 341, 5, 22, 638476) It is in this case the attitute that matters, not words uttered or muttered.
('35', 341, 5, 23, 638553) And often the association of words that have been handed down from ancient times has an effect which in their rendering into one’s mother tongue they will lose altogether.
('35', 341, 5, 24, 638725) Thus the Gayatri translated and recited in, say, Gujarati, will not have the same effect as the original.
('35', 341, 5, 25, 638831) The utterance of the word ‘Rama’ will instantaneoulsy affect millions of Hindus, when the word ‘God’, although they may
('35', 341, 6, 26, 638951) 1 Ritual prayer to Sun God
('35', 342, 0, 1, 638978) VOL.35 : 2 APRIL, 1926 7 JULY, 1926 343
('35', 342, 1, 2, 639018) understand the meaning, will leave them untouched.
('35', 342, 1, 3, 639069) Words after all acquire a power by long usage and sacredness associated with their use.
('35', 342, 1, 4, 639157) There is much therefore to be said for the retention of the old Sanskrit formulae for the most prevalent mantras or verses.
('35', 342, 1, 5, 639281) That the meaning of them should be properly understood goes without saying.
('35', 342, 1, 6, 639357) There can be no fixed rule laid down as to the time these devotional acts should take.
('35', 342, 1, 7, 639444) It depends upon individual temperament.
('35', 342, 1, 8, 639484) These are precious moments in one’s daily life.
('35', 342, 1, 9, 639532) The exercises are intended to sober and humble us and enable us to realize that nothing happens without His will and that we are but ‘clay in the hands of the Potter’.
('35', 342, 1, 10, 639700) These are moments when one reviews one’s immediate past, confesses one’s weakness, asks for forgiveness and strength to be and do better.
('35', 342, 1, 11, 639838) One minute may be enough for some, twenty four hours may be too little for others.
('35', 342, 1, 12, 639921) For those who are filled with the presence of God in them, to labour is to pray.
('35', 342, 1, 13, 640002) Their life is one continuous prayer or act of worship.
('35', 342, 1, 14, 640057) For us ordinary mortals there must be a middle path between these two extremes.
('35', 342, 1, 15, 640137) We are not so exalted as to be able to say that all our acts are a dedication, nor perhaps are we so for gone as to be living purely for self.
('35', 342, 1, 16, 640280) Hence have all religions set apart times for general devotion.
('35', 342, 1, 17, 640343) Unfortunately these have nowadays become merely mechanical and formal, where they are not hypocritical.
('35', 342, 1, 18, 640447) What is necessary therefore is the correct attitude to accompany these devotions.
('35', 342, 1, 19, 640529) For definte personal prayer in the sense of asking God for something, it should certainly be in one’s own tongue.
('35', 342, 1, 20, 640643) Nothing can be grander than to ask God to make us act justly towards everything that lives.
('35', 342, 2, 21, 640735) Young India, 10 6 1926
('35', 342, 3, 22, 640758) 442. CO OPERATION IN SPINNING
('35', 342, 4, 23, 640788) A dear friend asks me to answer the question that has occurred to him and his other friends.
('35', 342, 5, 24, 640881) Is there co operation in spinning?
('35', 342, 5, 25, 640916) Does it not rather make people purely
('35', 342, 6, 26, 640954) individualistic, self centred and keep them separate from one another even as
('35', 342, 7, 27, 641032) so many pebbles?
('35', 342, 7, 28, 641049) The briefest and the most decisive answer I can give is : “Go,
('35', 343, 0, 1, 641112) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 344
('35', 343, 1, 2, 641154) watch any well organized spinning centre and test the thing for yourself.
('35', 343, 1, 3, 641228) You will then discover that spinning cannot succeed without co operation.” But brief though this answer is, it is, I know, useless for those (and they are the majority) who cannot or will not make the time for paying such a visit.
('35', 343, 1, 4, 641459) I must therefore try to convince by describing such a centre in the best way I can.
('35', 343, 1, 5, 641543) In speaking to a co operative society in Madras last year, I said that through hand spinning I was trying to found the largest co operative society known to the world.
('35', 343, 1, 6, 641711) This is not an untrue claim.
('35', 343, 1, 7, 641740) It may be ambitious.
('35', 343, 1, 8, 641761) It is not untrue because hand spinning cannot serve the purpose for which it is intended unless millions actually co operate in it.
('35', 343, 1, 9, 641893) The purpose is to drive away enforced idleness and pauperism which is the result mainly of that idleness in India.
('35', 343, 1, 10, 642008) This purpose, it will be admitted, is grand enough.
('35', 343, 1, 11, 642060) The effort must be correspondinlgy great.
('35', 343, 1, 12, 642102) There must be co operation from the very commencement.
('35', 343, 1, 13, 642157) If spinning makes one self reliant it also enables one to understand the necessity of interdependence almost at every step.
('35', 343, 1, 14, 642281) An ordinary spinner must find a ready market for her surplus yarn.
('35', 343, 1, 15, 642348) She cannot weave it.
('35', 343, 1, 16, 642369) There can be no market for her yarn without the co operation of a large number of people.
('35', 343, 1, 17, 642459) Just as our agriculture is possible only because there is co operation, be it ever so little, of millions in regard to the cultivation and disposal of the produce, so will spinning be successful only if there is co operation on an equally large scale.
('35', 343, 1, 18, 642711) Take the working of any typical centre.
('35', 343, 1, 19, 642751) At the central office is collected seed cootton for spinners.
('35', 343, 1, 20, 642813) The cotton is ginned by ginners perhaps at the centre.
('35', 343, 1, 21, 642868) It is distributed then among carders who re deliver it in the shape of slivers.
('35', 343, 1, 22, 642948) These are now ready to be distributed among the spinners who bring their yarn from week to week and take away fresh slivers and their wages in return.
('35', 343, 1, 23, 643099) The yarn thus received is given to weavers to weave and received back for sale in the shape of khaddar.
('35', 343, 1, 24, 643203) This latter must now be sold to the wearers—the general public.
('35', 343, 1, 25, 643267) Thus the centre office has to be in constant living human touch with a very large number of people irrespective of caste, colour or creed.
('35', 343, 1, 26, 643406) For the centre has no dividends to make, has no exclusive
('35', 344, 0, 1, 643464) VOL.35 : 2 APRIL, 1926 7 JULY, 1926 345
('35', 344, 1, 2, 643504) care but the care of the most needy.
('35', 344, 1, 3, 643541) The centre to be useful must keep itself clean in every sense of the term.
('35', 344, 1, 4, 643616) The bond between it and the component parts of the vast organization is purely spiritual or moral.
('35', 344, 1, 5, 643715) A spinning centre therefore is a co operative society whose members are ginners, carders, spinners, weavers and buyers—all tied together by a common bond, mutual goodwill and service.
('35', 344, 1, 6, 643899) In this society the course of every piece can be traced almost with certainty as it floats to and fro.
('35', 344, 1, 7, 644002) And as these centres grow and draw the youth of the country who have the fire of patriotism burning brightly in their hearts and whose purity will stand the strain of all temptation, they will, they must, become centres for radiating elementary knowledge in hygiene, sanitation, domestic treatment of simple diseases among the villagers and education among their children suited to their needs.
('35', 344, 1, 8, 644397) That time is not yet.
('35', 344, 1, 9, 644419) The begin ning indeed has been made.
('35', 344, 1, 10, 644456) But the movement can grow only slowly.
('35', 344, 1, 11, 644495) It is not possible to show substantial results till khadi has become a salable article in the bazaar like ghee or, better still, postage stamp.
('35', 344, 1, 12, 644639) For the present a vast amount of energy has to be spent in educating the people to buy khadi in the place of any other cloth even as a child would eat and bless the rice cooked by its mother without stopping to think of the quality or the price of the rice so cooked.
('35', 344, 1, 13, 644907) If it did, it would find that the rice cooked by the mother was far too dear for the labour and the love spent upon the working.
('35', 344, 1, 14, 645036) And so will it be with khadi one day, when the children of mother Hind wake from their deep sleep and realize that yarn spun and worked by the hands of her daughters and sons can never be too dear for her crores of children.
('35', 344, 1, 15, 645261) When this simple truth dawns upon us, spinning centres will multiply a hundredfold, a ray of hope will penetrate the dark Indian cottages and that hope will be the surest foundation for the freedom we want but do not know how to achieve.
('35', 344, 2, 16, 645499) Young India, 10 6 1926

('35', 347, 7, 19, 649462) 447. LETTER TO EMIL RONIGER
('35', 347, 8, 20, 649490) THE ASHRAM, SABARMATI, June 11, 1926
('35', 347, 9, 21, 649527) DEAR FRIEND, I have your letter.
('35', 347, 9, 22, 649560) The idea of making any money out of my writings even for a charitable purpose is quite foreign to me.
('35', 347, 9, 23, 649662) Up to now I have avoided all such temptation.
('35', 347, 9, 24, 649708) This time the temptation has come in a double manner.

('35', 356, 3, 13, 663943) 462. WHAT IS NATURAL?
('35', 356, 4, 14, 663965) No word seems to be more abused today than the word ‘natural’.
('35', 356, 4, 15, 664028) For instance, a correspondent writes, “as eating and drinking are natural to man, even so is anger.” Another seems to argue : “The sexual function is as natural as the other functions of the body.
('35', 356, 4, 16, 664225) Were it not so, God would not have endowed it to man.
('35', 356, 4, 17, 664279) If it was not our duty to curse the wicked and to bless the good, why should we have been endowed with the faculty of cursing and blessing?
('35', 356, 4, 18, 664419) May it not be our duty to develop all our faculties to perfection?
('35', 356, 4, 19, 664486) And thus himsa would appear to be as much one’s dharma as ahimsa.
('35', 356, 4, 20, 664552) In short virtue and vice are figments of our imagination.
('35', 356, 4, 21, 664610) Your ahimsa is a sign of weakness, inasmuch as it expresses only one side of our nature.
('35', 356, 4, 22, 664699) Rather than regard it as the highest religion, why should we not regard it as the highest irreligion?
('35', 356, 4, 23, 664801) Ahimsa Paramo Dharmah was orginally Ahimsa Paramo Adharmah the negative prefix a (not) having somehow dropped out, or been rubbed out by some enemy of mankind.
('35', 356, 4, 24, 664961) For on many occasions, ahimsa can be demonstrated to be the highest irreligion.” This is not one man’s argument, I have boiled down and put together the arguments of many.
('35', 356, 4, 25, 665133) The theoryabout the negative a in ahimsa 2 being
('35', 356, 5, 26, 665182) 1 The Gujarati original of this appeared in Navajivan, 13 6 1926. This is a translation by Mahadev Desai.
('35', 356, 5, 27, 665288) 2 Slip for adharma
('35', 357, 0, 1, 665307) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 358
('35', 357, 1, 2, 665349) dropped was propounded by an old barrister friend, and he did so in all seriousness.
('35', 357, 1, 3, 665434) Indeed if we were to put man in the same category as the brute, many things could be proved to come under the description ‘natural’.
('35', 357, 1, 4, 665567) But if they belong to two different species, not everything that is natural to the brute is natural to man.
('35', 357, 1, 5, 665675) “Progress is man’s distinction, man’s alone, not beast’s.” Man has discrimination and reason.
('35', 357, 1, 6, 665769) Man does not live by bread alone, as the brute does.
('35', 357, 1, 7, 665822) He uses his reason to worship God and to know Him, and regards the attainment of that knowledge as the summum bonum of life.
('35', 357, 1, 8, 665947) The desire to worship God is inconceivable in the brute, while man can voluntarily worship even Satan.
('35', 357, 1, 9, 666050) It must therefore be, and is, man’s nature to know and find God.
('35', 357, 1, 10, 666115) When he worships Satan, he acts contrary to his nature.
('35', 357, 1, 11, 666171) Of course, I will not carry conviction to one who makes no distinction bet ween man and the brute.
('35', 357, 1, 12, 666270) To him virtue and vice are convertible terms.
('35', 357, 1, 13, 666316) While to the man whose end and aim is realization of God, even the functions of eating and drinking can be natural only within certain limits.
('35', 357, 1, 14, 666459) For having knowledge of God as his end, he will not eat or drink for the sake of enjoyment but solely for sustaining the body.
('35', 357, 1, 15, 666586) Restraint and renunciation will therefore always be his watchwords even in respect of these functions.
('35', 357, 2, 16, 666689) And if it is man’s nature to know and find God, sexual indulgence should be contrary to his nature, and complete renunci ation of it will accord best with his mission.
('35', 357, 2, 17, 666857) For realization of God is impossible with out complete renunciation of the sexual desire.
('35', 357, 2, 18, 666947) It is not man’s duty to develop all his faculties to perfection; his duty is to develop all his Godward faculties to perfection and to suppress completely those of a contrary tendency.
('35', 357, 3, 19, 667132) Anyone blessed with choice or free will to accept and reject cannot but distinguish between good and evil, virtue and vice.
('35', 357, 3, 20, 667256) For these mean in other words nothing but things to be accepted and things to be rejected.
('35', 357, 3, 21, 667347) Thus robbing someone of his property is a thing to be rejected, hence bad or sinful.
('35', 357, 3, 22, 667432) We have within us both good and bad desires.
('35', 357, 3, 23, 667477) It is our duty to cultivate the former and to suppress or eradicate the latter, and if we fail therein we should remain brutes though born men.
('35', 357, 3, 24, 667621) Birth as a human being is therefore declared by all religions as a rare privilege—a state of probation.
('35', 357, 3, 25, 667725) And Hinduism says that if we are weighed and found wanting we should have to be reborn as beasts.
('35', 358, 0, 1, 667823) VOL.35 : 2 APRIL, 1926 7 JULY, 1926 359
('35', 358, 1, 2, 667863) The world is full of himsa and nature does appear to be ‘red in tooth and claw’.
('35', 358, 1, 3, 667944) But if we bear in mind that man is higher than the brute, then is man superior to that Nature.
('35', 358, 1, 4, 668039) If man has a divine mission to fulfil, a mission that becomes him, it is that of ahimsa.
('35', 358, 1, 5, 668128) Standing as he does in the midst of himsa, he can retire into the innermost depths of his heart and declare to the world around him that his mission in this world of himsa is ahimsa, and only to the extent that he practises it does he adorn his kind.
('35', 358, 1, 6, 668379) Man’s nature then is not himsa, but ahimsa, for he can speak from experience, his innermost convi ction, that he is not the body but atman, and that he may use the body only with a view to expressing the atman, only with a view to self realization.
('35', 358, 1, 7, 668628) And from that experience he evolves the ethics of subduing desire, anger, ignorance, malice and other passions, puts forth his best effort to achieve the end and finally attains complete success.
('35', 358, 1, 8, 668824) Only when his efforts reach that consummation can be said to have fulfilled himself, to have acted according to his nature.
('35', 358, 1, 9, 668948) Conquest of one’s passions therefore is not superhuman, but human, and observance of ahimsa is heroism of the highest type, with no room therein for cowardice or weakness.

('35', 358, 2, 11, 669143) 463. MAHUDHA KHADI CENTRE
('35', 358, 3, 12, 669169) I give below some facts from the report of this Centre which Shri Mohanlal Pandya has sent to me.
('35', 358, 3, 13, 669267) The Centre provides spinning work to 261 women, of whom 236 are Muslims.
('35', 358, 3, 14, 669340) The rest belong to the Brahmin, Vania and Barot communities.
('35', 358, 3, 15, 669401) The number of spinners is increasing day by day.
('35', 358, 3, 16, 669450) This work is a great help to them, as they would not go out of their homes to do any other work.
('35', 358, 3, 17, 669547) The Muslim women call the spinning wheel the glory of the housewife.
('35', 358, 3, 18, 669616) As a result of this activity, three persons are employed in carding and five women in making slivers.
('35', 358, 3, 19, 669718) Eight looms are operating.
('35', 358, 3, 20, 669745) The quantity of yarn produced is 20 maunds a month.
('35', 358, 3, 21, 669797) Previously, they spun yarn of 6 counts, but now the Centre does not want them to spin yarn of less than 10 counts and does not, therefore, pay less than 5 annas per pound.
('35', 358, 3, 22, 669969) That comes to Rs. 121 2 per maund,
('35', 358, 4, 23, 670004) the total for 20 maunds being Rs. 246. This means an average earning of less than a rupee for every woman who spins.

('35', 359, 1, 2, 670178) however, tells me that it is probably one and a half rupees.
('35', 359, 1, 3, 670239) If he is right, then either the number of spinners is smaller or the yarn spun is of a higher count.
('35', 359, 1, 4, 670340) From this quantity of yarn they weave every month 65 pieces of khadi, each of 18 yds.
('35', 359, 1, 5, 670426) length and 27 inches width.

('35', 359, 2, 12, 670739) Their sale during the last three months amounted to Rs. 842. The selling price of the khadi is fixed at 20 per cent less than the cost price.
('35', 359, 2, 13, 670881) The Centre has a staff of six persons.
('35', 359, 2, 14, 670920) I commend to this Centre and others like it the example of Bengal.
('35', 359, 2, 15, 670987) There all khadi is produced for local consumption and, therefore, every effort is made to meet local needs.
('35', 359, 2, 16, 671095) The result is that a large quantity of fine khadi with greater width is produced, and the production of such khadi is increasing day by day.
('35', 359, 2, 17, 671236) If, in this manner, we work to meet local needs, we get opportunities of coming into contact with people belonging to all classes of society and are able to serve them, and at the same time the consumption of khadi will also spread to larger numbers.
('35', 359, 2, 18, 671487) If we adopt this method of promoting the use of khadi, a good many problems will be solved automatically and by and by we shall advance not in arithmetical progression but in geometrical progression.
('35', 359, 2, 19, 671687) If the same attention were paid to improving the strength of the yarn as is paid to its fineness, every weaver would agree to weave that yarn.
('35', 359, 2, 20, 671830) Experience tells us that if we wish to improve the quality of yarn, the spinner should himself or herself prepare the slivers.
('35', 359, 2, 21, 671957) It need not be pointed out that this will add to the earnings of the spinners.

('35', 359, 2, 23, 672196) They should study the conditions of the poor in those villages and examine the possibility of introducing the spinning wheel among them.

('35', 360, 4, 14, 673842) Cow protection means preventing, in a manner consistent with dharma, that is, without doing anyone harm, the unnecessary slaughter of cattle which is going on at present.
('35', 360, 4, 15, 674013) Today, either through ignorance or fanaticism, we have given cow protection an extremely narrow meaning.
('35', 360, 4, 16, 674118) That is why we helplessly witness or tolerate the unnecessary slaughter of cows before our very eyes.
('35', 360, 4, 17, 674220) With a little intelligence, some self sacrifice and a measure of practical knowledge, we can save countless cows and buffaloes and thereby preserve the wealth of the country.
('35', 360, 4, 18, 674395) An attempt is being made in these pages to explain this.
('35', 360, 4, 19, 674452) This way of protecting cattle will necessarily ensure the protection of disabled and infirm cattle.
('35', 360, 4, 20, 674552) At present, such cattle are a burden on us, and therefore, one might even say that they are not protected in the right manner.
