('35', 364, 1, 2, 679765) 469. MESSAGE TO THE STUDENTS
('35', 364, 2, 3, 679794) The Gujarati Mahavidyalaya opened, after the last summer vacation, on June
('35', 364, 3, 4, 679869) 14th, with an address from Gandhiji which, it being his day of silence, was read for
('35', 364, 4, 5, 679954) The following is the translation : 1921 and 1926—What a difference?
('35', 364, 4, 6, 680022) Please do not think that I am striking a melancholy note.
('35', 364, 4, 7, 680080) We are not going back, our country is not going back.
('35', 364, 4, 8, 680134) We have gone five years nearer swaraj and there can be no doubt about it.
('35', 364, 4, 9, 680208) If someone says that it was very nearly achieved in 1921 and today it is far away—no one knows how far—do not believe it.
('35', 364, 4, 10, 680330) Prayerful, well meaning effort never goes in vain, and man’s success lies only in such an effort.
('35', 364, 4, 11, 680428) The result is in His hands.
('35', 364, 4, 12, 680456) Strength of numbers is the delight of the timid.
('35', 364, 4, 13, 680505) The valiant of spirit glory in fighting alone.
('35', 364, 4, 14, 680552) And you are all here to cultivate that valour of the spirit.
('35', 364, 4, 15, 680613) Be you one or many, this valour is the only true valour, all else is false.
('35', 364, 4, 16, 680689) And the valour of the spirit cannot be achieved without Sacrifice, Determination, Faith and Humility.
('35', 364, 4, 17, 680791) We have built our Vidyalaya on the foundation of self purification.
('35', 364, 4, 18, 680859) Non violent non co operation is one aspect of it.
('35', 364, 4, 19, 680909) The ‘non’ means renunciation of violence and all that stands for it, i.e., all Government control.
('35', 364, 4, 20, 681008) But so long as we do not co operate with our ‘untouchable’ brethren, so long as there is no heart unity between men of different faiths, so long as we do not co operate with the millions of our countrymen by according to the spinning wheel and khaddar the sacred place they deserve, the negative prefix is entirely nugatory.
('35', 364, 4, 21, 681333) That non co operation will not be based on ahimsa, but himsa, i.e., hatred.
('35', 364, 4, 22, 681409) A negative injunction without a positive obligation is like body without soul, worthy to be consigned to the flames.
('35', 364, 4, 23, 681526) There are 7,000 railway station for the 7,00,000 villages of India.
('35', 364, 4, 24, 681594) We do not even claim to know these 7,000 villages.
('35', 364, 4, 25, 681645) We know only through history the condition of villages not within easy reach of railway stations.
('35', 364, 4, 26, 681743) The only loving tie of service that can bind the villagers to us is the spinning wheel.

('35', 365, 1, 3, 682270) The spinning wheel is the centre of that service.

('35', 369, 6, 11, 690091) But I adhere to my opinion that no real solution is to come at the present moment out of any effort.
('35', 369, 6, 12, 690192) I see distrust everywhere.

('35', 369, 6, 14, 690312) When each party expects to humble the other, peace is impossible.
('35', 369, 6, 15, 690378) It is more over my firm conviction that this exaggerated importance we are giving to the Councils out of all proportion to their usefulness, if there ever was any, is keeping us apart.
('35', 369, 6, 16, 690563) Everyone who remains outside the Councils thinks that he is losing something.
('35', 369, 6, 17, 690641) And, what is true of individuals is true of communities and, therefore, there is a mad rush over getting as much representation as possible and then getting in as many men as possible with a communal taint.
('35', 369, 6, 18, 690848) If you can see any good out of effort made in an atmosphere such as this, I can but admire your zeal and credulity.
('35', 369, 6, 19, 690964) But I cannot enthuse over any such effort.

('35', 372, 5, 6, 694052) 480. NOTES
('35', 372, 6, 7, 694063) DESHBANDHU
('35', 372, 7, 8, 694074) Today 1 is the first anniversary of Deshbandhu’s death.
('35', 372, 7, 9, 694130) He died in harness, full of glory because full of faith.
('35', 372, 7, 10, 694187) He believed in himself, in his country, because he believed in God; Up to the very last day he thought not of himself but of his country.
('35', 372, 7, 11, 694325) He died for an ideal and he lives today through his ideal because it survives him.
('35', 372, 7, 12, 694408) The dissensions in Bengal and the fratricidal war that is going on in India are indeed a negation of his ideal.
('35', 372, 7, 13, 694520) But this aberration I hold to be merely a passing phase in working out the ideal.
('35', 372, 7, 14, 694602) In the course of self purification, we are bound to come upon steep rocks and deep ravines.
('35', 372, 7, 15, 694694) We must bridge our way over the ravines and cut it through the rocks.
('35', 372, 7, 16, 694764) And I have full faith that we shall overcome our difficulties.
('35', 372, 7, 17, 694827) They are costing us dear.
('35', 372, 7, 18, 694853) They may cost us dearer still.
('35', 372, 7, 19, 694884) But no price will be greater for working out our own salvation for which Lokamanya, Deshbandhu and their predecessors lived and died.
('35', 372, 8, 20, 695018) THE POSITION OF NON CO OPERATORS
('35', 372, 9, 21, 695051) A friend asks:
('35', 372, 10, 22, 695066) In the midst of so many parties in the country we hardly see where to set our feet.
('35', 372, 10, 23, 695150) When so many parties are being formed, is it not desirable that those few who still believe in the boycott of Councils, Hindu Muslim unity, etc., should consolidate their forces and re declare their ideals?
('35', 372, 10, 24, 695357) We are being accused of having turned our backs on swaraj and our creed of non violence is being openly sneered at.
('35', 372, 10, 25, 695473) At every step we are being taunted that we are wasting our time and energy.
('35', 372, 10, 26, 695549) I admit that one need not be disturbed by taunts, but it does appear desirable to organize ourselves and call upon those who are of our way of thinking to join us.
('35', 372, 10, 27, 695713) How long are we to have patience?
('35', 372, 10, 28, 695747) How long must our faith be tried?
('35', 372, 10, 29, 695781) If patience is worth anything, it must endure to the end of time.
('35', 372, 11, 30, 695847) 1 June 16, 1926
('35', 373, 0, 1, 695863) 374 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('35', 373, 1, 2, 695905) And a living faith will last in the midst of the blackest storm.
('35', 373, 1, 3, 695970) Non violence acts in a manner contrary to violence.
('35', 373, 1, 4, 696022) I cannot advise the formation of an additional party.
('35', 373, 1, 5, 696076) Non violent non co operation can and must stand without an organized party.
('35', 373, 1, 6, 696152) Non violent non co operation is on its trial.
('35', 373, 1, 7, 696198) Let each one who has faith in boycott of Councils, law courts, etc., stand firm even though he may be alone in his own district.
('35', 373, 1, 8, 696327) Khaddar and national schools should satisfy everyone who wants an occupation.
('35', 373, 1, 9, 696405) The facts and figures I am reproducing from week to week from reports received from various khadi centres must convince the most sceptical of the progress that khadi is making, surely though slowly.
('35', 373, 1, 10, 696604) And the progress that is now being made is not due to any momentary enthusiasm but it is due to a reasoned faith in khadi.
('35', 373, 1, 11, 696727) If non co operators have faith in non violent non co operation they will know that it is not dead but it is very much alive and that it will give a good account of itself when the darkest cloud threatens the horizon.
('35', 373, 1, 12, 696944) It will be found then to be the one sheet anchor of India’s hope.
('35', 373, 2, 13, 697010) IN SEARCH OF GURU
('35', 373, 3, 14, 697028) As a result of my statement in Chapter I, Part II of My Experiments with Truth 1, that I was still in search of a guru, numerous correspondents, Hindus, Mussalmans and Christians, have favoured me with long letters telling me how to find a guru.
('35', 373, 3, 15, 697274) More letters are still coming in.
('35', 373, 3, 16, 697308) Some tell me actually where to go and whom to see.
('35', 373, 3, 17, 697359) Some refer me to certain literature.
('35', 373, 3, 18, 697396) I am grateful to all these correspondents for their solicitude for my welfare.
('35', 373, 3, 19, 697475) But let them and others realize that my difficulty is fundamental.
('35', 373, 3, 20, 697542) Nor does it trouble me.
('35', 373, 3, 21, 697566) It is fundamental because my conception of a guru is perhaps not of the ordinary.
('35', 373, 3, 22, 697648) Nothing but perfection will satisfy me.
('35', 373, 3, 23, 697688) I am in search of one who, though in the flesh, is incorruptible and unmoved by passion, free from the pairs of opposites, who is truth and ahimsa incarnate and who will therefore fear none and be feared by none.
('35', 373, 3, 24, 697901) Everyone gets the guru he deserves and strives for.
('35', 373, 3, 25, 697953) The difficulty of finding the guru I want is thus obvious.
('35', 373, 3, 26, 698012) But it does not worry me; for it follows from what I have said, that I must try to perfect myself before I meet the guru in theflesh.
('35', 373, 3, 27, 698146) Till then I must contemplate him in the spirit.
('35', 373, 3, 28, 698194) My success lies in my continuous, humble, truthful striving.
('35', 373, 3, 29, 698255) I know the
('35', 373, 4, 30, 698266) 1 Gandhiji’s autobiography started appearing serially in Young India, 3 12 1925.
('35', 374, 0, 1, 698347) VOL.35 : 2 APRIL, 1926 7 JULY, 1926 375
('35', 374, 1, 2, 698387) It is straight and narrow.
('35', 374, 1, 3, 698414) It is like the edge of a sword.
('35', 374, 1, 4, 698446) I rejoice to walk on it.
('35', 374, 1, 5, 698471) I weep when I slip.
('35', 374, 1, 6, 698491) God’s word is: ‘He who strives never perishes.’ I have implicit faith in that promise.
('35', 374, 1, 7, 698578) Though therefore from my weakness I fail a thousand times, I will not lose faith but hope that I shall see the Light when the flesh has been brought under perfect subjection as some day it must.
('35', 374, 1, 8, 698773) I wonder if the kind correspondents will now understand my position and cease to worry about me but join me in the search, unless they are satisfied that they have found Him.
('35', 374, 2, 9, 698948) FOR MANAGERS OF “GAUSHALAS”
('35', 374, 3, 10, 698976) The Secretary of the All India Cow Protection Association circulated some time ago among the managers of all known gaushalas and pinjrapoles a set of questions asking for information.
('35', 374, 3, 11, 699160) Very poor response has been made to the request hitherto.
('35', 374, 3, 12, 699218) Lists have been printed and they can now be supplied on application to the Secretary, All India Cow Protection Association, Sabarmati.
('35', 374, 3, 13, 699353) Chaunde Maharaj has undertaken to visit the majority of gaushalas in Maharashtra and get the information personally from the managers on behalf of the Association.
('35', 374, 3, 14, 699517) I trust that the managers in these places will give him all the information required.
('35', 374, 3, 15, 699603) I need hardly say that the A.I.C.P.A. has no desire whatsoever to acquire ownership of or control over any of these gaushalas.
('35', 374, 3, 16, 699730) The desire is merely to collect information, tabulate and publish it for the guidance of all trustees and managers of such institutions and to assist them with advice.
('35', 374, 3, 17, 699898) It is open to them, if they so wish, to be affiliated to the Association and receive its guidance and the benefit of the assistance of experts whose services the Association hopes to be able to secure at an early date.
('35', 374, 3, 18, 700117) But whether any of these institutions is affiliated or not, it will be the duty of the Association to give all, the information in its possession to these societies.
('35', 374, 3, 19, 700283) It is hardly necessary to state that co ordination of effort on the part of nearly 1,500 gaushalas and their efficient management must result in the saving of many more cattle than are now saved.
('35', 374, 3, 20, 700479) Affiliation would no doubt carry some responsibility on the part of those who seek affiliation.
('35', 374, 3, 21, 700575) In their own interest they will be bound by rules made for their management and they will have to give a percentage of their income to the central Association.
('35', 374, 3, 22, 700735) But it is entirely optional for every institution to seek or not to seek affiliation.
('35', 374, 3, 23, 700821) The object of this note is merely to seek information.

('35', 375, 1, 2, 700918) SOUTH AFRICAN LEGISLATION
('35', 375, 2, 3, 700944) If anything is needed to emphasize the meaning of the warning issued by Mr. Andrews and myself, here is an extract from a South African letter:
('35', 375, 3, 4, 701088) I feel that through the passage of the Colour Bar Bill the Government is not keeping its word with the Indian Government and the community, especially when on the top of this comes the Natal Educational Ordinance which, if passed, will mean the negation of educational rights we have, little as they are at present.
('35', 375, 3, 5, 701404) In the direction of economics we see joint Councils raised under the Union Conciliation Act of 1921 in industries like furniture, printing, building, etc.—in which thousands of Indians are involved, without the Indian employees and employers being allowed to become members of the Trade Unions or Masters’ Union who negotiate on behalf of the employees and employers and who go to make up the joint Councils who prepare the schedules or wages and other benefits; or, either allowed a voice in the joint Councils.
('35', 375, 3, 6, 701917) Of course we have no objection to legislation aimed at bettering the conditions of workers, but at the same time what we do object to is that it is not fair to Indian employees and employers that schedules of wages be prepared which they have to abide by in which they have had no voice and the effect of it all is the annihilation of both the Indian employer and employees.
('35', 375, 3, 7, 702292) It shows as clearly as day light which way the wind is blowing.
('35', 375, 3, 8, 702356) The Class Areas Bill, because so much opposition was raised against it, has been postponed hut the policy underlying it is being pursued by the Union Government in a thousand other ways as instanced by the correspondent.
('35', 375, 3, 9, 702577) It is impossible therefore to be too watchful about the way things are shaping in South Africa.

('35', 376, 2, 3, 703154) Young India, 17 6 1926
('35', 376, 3, 4, 703177) 481. SOME KNOTTY POINTS
('35', 376, 4, 5, 703201) A medical friend from far off Burma writes:
('35', 376, 5, 6, 703245) Why do you emphasize khaddar and not swadeshi?
('35', 376, 5, 7, 703292) Is not swadeshi the principle and khaddar a mere detail?
('35', 376, 5, 8, 703349) I do not regard khaddar to be a detail.
('35', 376, 5, 9, 703389) Swadeshi is a theoretical term.
('35', 376, 5, 10, 703421) Khaddar is the concrete and central fact of swadeshi.
('35', 376, 5, 11, 703475) Swadeshi without khaddar is like the body without life, fit only to receive a decent burial or cremation.
('35', 376, 5, 12, 703581) The only swadeshi cloth is khaddar.
('35', 376, 5, 13, 703617) If one is to interpret swadeshi in the language of and in terms of the millions of this country, khaddar is a substantial thing in swadeshi like the air we breathe.
('35', 376, 5, 14, 703782) The test of swadeshi is not the universality of the use of an article which goes under the name of swadeshi, but the universality of participation in the production or manufacture of such article.
('35', 376, 5, 15, 703979) Thus considered, mill made cloth is swadeshi only in a restricted sense.
('35', 376, 5, 16, 704052) For, in its manufacture only an infinitesimal number of India’s millions can take part.
('35', 376, 5, 17, 704140) But in the manufacture of khaddar millions can take part.
('35', 376, 5, 18, 704198) The more the merrier.
('35', 376, 5, 19, 704220) Khaddar, in my opinion, is bound up the welfare of millions of human beings.
('35', 376, 5, 20, 704297) Khaddar is, therefore, the largest part of swadeshi and it is the only true demonstration of it.
('35', 376, 5, 21, 704394) All else follows from it.
('35', 376, 5, 22, 704420) India can live even if we do not use brass buttons or tooth picks made in India.
('35', 376, 5, 23, 704501) But India cannot live if we refuse to manufacture and wear khaddar.
('35', 376, 5, 24, 704569) Khaddar will cease to have this paramount importance when a more profitable employment is discovered for the idle hours of India’s millions.
('35', 376, 5, 25, 704710) But says the Doctor:
('35', 376, 6, 26, 704731) Good khaddar is costly and the ordinary variety is ugly.
('35', 376, 6, 27, 704788) I deny that any khaddar is ugly.
('35', 376, 6, 28, 704821) Want of the dead sameness of a machine made article is not a sign of ugliness, but it is a sign of life, even as absence of sameness in the millions of leaves of a tree is no sign of its ugliness.
('35', 376, 6, 29, 705018) As a matter of fact, it is the variety about the leaves which gives a tree its life like beauty.
('35', 376, 6, 30, 705115) I can picture a machine made tree whose every leaf would be absolutely the same
('35', 377, 0, 1, 705195) 378 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('35', 377, 1, 2, 705237) It would look a ghastly thing, because we have not yet ceased to love the living tree.
('35', 377, 1, 3, 705324) And, why should the cost of khaddar, good or bad, worry us if every penny we pay for it goes directly into the pockets of the starving millions?
('35', 377, 1, 4, 705469) My experience is that in the majority of cases where people have taken to khaddar they have revised their tastes about dress.
('35', 377, 1, 5, 705595) Though khaddar may be dearer yard per yard than the same quality of Manchester calico, the rejection of superfluous clothing more than balances the extra cost.
('35', 377, 1, 6, 705755) Those who wish to wear fine khaddar can now obtain it at all the principal khadi centres.
('35', 377, 1, 7, 705845) The medical friend next questions the desirability of spinning and gravely suggests that if everybody would spin, the poor people who depend upon spinning for their livelihood would be losers.
('35', 377, 1, 8, 706038) He forgets that those who are called upon to spin by way of sacrifice promote the khaddar atmosphere and make it possible to render spinning easier and by small inventions and discoveries make it more profitable.
('35', 377, 1, 9, 706251) The wages of professional spinners cannot suffer in any way whatsoever by sacrificial spinning.
('35', 377, 1, 10, 706347) The friend then asks:
('35', 377, 2, 11, 706369) Should doctors cease to prescribe foreign drugs and instead learn the use of Ayurvedic and Unani drugs?
('35', 377, 2, 12, 706473) I have never considered the exclusion of everything foreign under every conceivable circumstance as part of swadeshi.
('35', 377, 2, 13, 706591) The broad definition of swadeshi is the use of all home made things to the exclusion of foreign things in so far as such use is necessary for the protection of home industry more especially those industries without which India will become pauperized.
('35', 377, 2, 14, 706842) In my opinion, therefore, swadeshi which excludes the use of everything foreign, because it is foreign, no matter how beneficial it may be, and irrespective of the fact that it impoverishes nobody, is a narrow interpretation of swadeshi.
('35', 377, 2, 15, 707080) Foreign drugs therefore, where they are highly efficacious and not otherwise objectionable, I should use without the slightest hesitation; that is, if I did not object to drugs altogether.
('35', 377, 2, 16, 707269) But there is no doubt that there is among many medical men with Western diplomas a fashion, altogether harmful, of decrying Ayurvedic and Unani drugs, some of which are indeed of great potency and cheap withal.
('35', 377, 2, 17, 707480) Any movement therefore on the part of those who have received a training in Western medicine to explore the possibilities of Ayurvedic and Unani systems would be most welcome and desirable.
('35', 377, 2, 18, 707670) The last question that this friend asks has been repeatedly
('35', 378, 0, 1, 707730) VOL.35 : 2 APRIL, 1926 7 JULY, 1926 379
('35', 378, 1, 2, 707770) answered in these pages: “Are you against all machinery?” Myanswer is emphatically, “No”.
('35', 378, 1, 3, 707860) But, I am against its indiscriminate multiplication.
('35', 378, 1, 4, 707913) I refuse to be dazzled by the seeming triumph of machinery.
('35', 378, 1, 5, 707973) I am uncompromisingly against all destructive machinery.
('35', 378, 1, 6, 708030) But simple tools and instruments and such machinery as save individual labour and lighten the burden of the millions of cottagers I should welcome.
('35', 378, 1, 7, 708178) Young India, 17 6 1926

('35', 379, 4, 10, 710628) 484. CATTLE WEALTH
('35', 379, 5, 11, 710647) The reader who has been following Sjt.
('35', 379, 5, 12, 710686) V. G. Desai’s writings about the cow could not have failed to notice the fact that in no other country in the world save India are cattle a burden on the land or its people.
('35', 379, 5, 13, 710860) It may be said that the slaughter of cattle is not only not repugnant to the vast majority of people in other lands but they deliberately kill out superfluous cattle.
('35', 379, 5, 14, 711027) One may even go further and say that in such countries there is no such thing as superfluous cattle, because cattle are actually bred for slaughter.
('35', 379, 5, 15, 711176) In this argument there is no doubt considerable force.
('35', 379, 5, 16, 711231) But all the writings in these pages are devoted to showing that, although the vast majority of people in India will not slaughter cattle for food, by judicious management, her cattle need not become a burden on the land and that their slaughter can be made so dear as to enable only those people to slaughter who will do so for luxury or in the name of religion.
('35', 379, 5, 17, 711594) The aim of Young India writings is to show that cattle at thepresent moment go to the slaughter houses because of our criminal negligence and want of proper knowledge.
('35', 379, 5, 18, 711762) It is further to show that the saving of an enormous number of cattle is more a problem of economics than
('35', 380, 0, 1, 711868) VOL.35 : 2 APRIL, 1926 7 JULY, 1926 381
('35', 380, 1, 2, 711908) religion; or rather to show that there is no conflict between religion and economics.
('35', 380, 1, 3, 711994) Indeed, I have myself gone further and stated that a religion which is in conflict with fundamental economics is bad, and that, in the reverse way, economics that are in conflict with fundamental religion are also equally bad.
('35', 380, 1, 4, 712221) From the Western countries we can learn a great deal about cattle economics apart from their slaughter for food.
('35', 380, 1, 5, 712334) If the nation, or say Hindus, would forego profits from cattle keeping, the self denial would be enough to keep cattle during the natural term of their lives even after they cease to give us a return in the shape of milk or labour.
('35', 380, 1, 6, 712566) The following passages 1 from the introduction to Henry and Morrisson’s treatise on Feeds and Feeding show how they regard cattle wealth in America.

('35', 389, 8, 13, 725269) COMMUNITY DINNER AFTER A DEATH
('35', 389, 9, 14, 725300) A gentleman writes as follows, expressing his feelings about my describing the custom of giving a community dinner after a death as uncivilized: 2
('35', 389, 10, 15, 725447) I have stated so often that all that is written in Sanskrit should not be regarded as holy scriptures.
('35', 389, 10, 16, 725550) Nor should everything which we find written in the Manusmriti and other authoritative works be accepted as coming from the pen of the original authors of the works, or, even if that is so, as having literal authority at the present day.
('35', 389, 10, 17, 725787) I do nothing of the sort.
('35', 389, 10, 18, 725813) Certain principles aresanatana 3, and people who
('35', 389, 11, 19, 725862) 1 In 1926 two presses of the Servants of India Society were destroyed by the fire.
('35', 389, 11, 20, 725945) The reference to the loss indicates that the letter was written in that year; vide “Servants of India Society’s Relief Fund”, 24 6 1926. 2 The letter is not translated here.
('35', 389, 11, 21, 726119) The correspondent had asked Gandhiji how, calling himself a sanatani Hindu, he could denounce the practice of community dinners after a death, which was enjoined by the Shastras.
('35', 389, 11, 22, 726298) 3 Eternal
('35', 390, 0, 1, 726308) VOL.35 : 2 APRIL, 1926 7 JULY, 1926 391
('35', 390, 1, 2, 726348) believe in them are sanatanis; but we need not believe that the practices which were enjoined in certain ages on the basis of those principles are valid in other ages too.
('35', 390, 1, 3, 726520) Customs and practices change with place, time and circumstances.
('35', 390, 1, 4, 726585) The practice of giving a community dinner after someone’s death may have had some meaning in old days, but in modern times our reason cannot accept it.
('35', 390, 1, 5, 726737) Faith has no place in a sphere in which we can exercise our reason.
('35', 390, 1, 6, 726805) Faith has meaning only in relation to what is above reason.
('35', 390, 1, 7, 726865) In this case, our reason tells us that giving a community dinner after a death is not a part of dharma.
('35', 390, 1, 8, 726969) Our experience of the world also tells us that no other religion enjoins or sanctions such a practice.
('35', 390, 1, 9, 727072) We should therefore, have much stronger reason than the authority of Sanskrit verses to accept such dinners as enjoined in Hinduism.
('35', 390, 1, 10, 727205) They are not at all consistent with the principles taught by the holy books of Hinduism or, for that matter, by the holy books of any other religion.
('35', 390, 1, 11, 727355) We can see with our own eyes the harm they do.
('35', 390, 1, 12, 727402) Against this evidence of direct observation, what weight can we attach to Sanskrit verses.
('35', 390, 1, 13, 727493) Neither our reason nor our heart nor our knowledge of other countries of the world justifies the practice of giving community dinners after a death.
('35', 390, 1, 14, 727642) I have no better reason than this, and no one need be expected to have, for believing that such dinners are uncivilized.
('35', 390, 1, 15, 727763) As those who believe that everything old is bad are wrong, so also are those who believe that it is good.
('35', 390, 1, 16, 727869) Whether old or new, everything should be tested on the anvil of reason, and anything which does not stand the test should be rejected.

A joint Hindu Muslim deputation had toured the Province “to carry the message of peace to the masses”.
('35', 397, 8, 17, 740547) Shafee had stressed in his letter that it was time “to pursue the work of reconciliation with greater vigour, in a larger area and with bigger personalities” (S.N. 11073).
('35', 397, 8, 18, 740719) 2 Shafee had alleged that some Congress workers considered that in Bihar the Hindus, by virtue of their superior numbers, could retaliate against the Muslims for wrongs done to the Hindus in other Provinces.

('35', 408, 6, 8, 755531) BHAISHRI SHAMBHUSHANKER1, I had your letter.
('35', 408, 6, 9, 755576) I accept and applaud your decision about salary.
('35', 408, 6, 10, 755625) You will draw Rs. 50 p.m.
('35', 408, 6, 11, 755651) up to the month of July, so the change will take effect from August onwards.
('35', 408, 6, 12, 755728) I have not yet received Bhai Jagjivandas’s letter.
('35', 408, 6, 13, 755779) You have not sent me the copy of the agreement which has been sent to you for your signature; but from what you write I can see no objection to including the immovable property if you wish to bind yourself.
('35', 408, 6, 14, 755986) As I see it, the responsibility for paying the damages will arise only for losses caused by your carelessness; not for other losses.
('35', 408, 6, 15, 756119) I also agree with you that there should be a worker to help you.
('35', 408, 6, 16, 756184) We should think over the conditions on which such a man should be engaged.
('35', 408, 6, 17, 756259) Let us hope that by the grace of God it would rain.
('35', 408, 6, 18, 756311) Think about and write to me of all the jobs that are usually done during the rainy season and others that could be done.
('35', 408, 6, 19, 756432) It is better if you have a talk about khadi with Maneklal and Chhaganlal.
('35', 408, 6, 20, 756506) How much of such khadi could they have with them?
('35', 408, 6, 21, 756556) We have to think about it if it is much.
('35', 408, 6, 22, 756597) The khadi that Bhai Vajeshanker sells, in whose name does he get it made?
('35', 408, 6, 23, 756671) How much khadi has he got woven?
('35', 408, 6, 24, 756704) Isn’t he in Hanod on behalf of the State?
('35', 408, 6, 25, 756746) There is only one principle underlying the khadi activity.
('35', 408, 6, 26, 756805) In India crores of people do not have any occupation except agriculture.
('35', 408, 6, 27, 756878) Sufficient livelihood for the crores cannot be obtained from agriculture alone.
('35', 408, 6, 28, 756958) Similarly, agriculture can’t take up their whole time.
('35', 408, 6, 29, 757013) They must have some other occupation and that is hand spinning.
('35', 408, 6, 30, 757077) So we are propagating it everywhere.
('35', 408, 6, 31, 757114) Khadi produced
('35', 408, 7, 32, 757129) 1 A khadi worker of Gariyadhar in Saurashtra
('35', 409, 0, 1, 757174) 410 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('35', 409, 1, 2, 757216) from hand spun yarn is thus a means of propagating spinning.
('35', 409, 1, 3, 757277) We endure the various fraudulent practices of [some] spinners, ginners and weavers, etc., but when we come to a stage when we can’t bear such practices, we stop taking work from them.
('35', 409, 1, 4, 757461) The way you have suggested is the only way to make them guileless.
('35', 409, 1, 5, 757528) That is, we should ourselves become guileless, pure, selfless and hardworking.

('35', 409, 9, 17, 758085) C. Balaji Rao of Coimbatore has circulated printed extracts collected with much labour from ‘Peoples of All Nations’ showing what place the ancient wheel occupies in the homes of other peoples.
('35', 409, 9, 18, 758279) I reproduce them below slightly abridged: 1
('35', 409, 10, 19, 758323) Only those who are obsessed with prejudice will refuse to see the potency of the wheel in the foregoing extracts, assuming, ofcourse, that the statements made in the original compilation are true.
('35', 409, 10, 20, 758520) The greatest obsession is the poor wage earned by the spinner.
('35', 409, 10, 21, 758583) If we would but get out of ourselves for a while and step into the shoes of the famishing millions, we would at once discover that what appears trifling to us is a fortune for them.
('35', 409, 10, 22, 758765) We would further discover that millions can add only a few pice to their daily income which, as it is, is
('35', 409, 11, 23, 758871) 1 These are not reproduced here.
('35', 409, 11, 24, 758904) They dealt with the position of the spinning industry in various countries of Africa, Europe, Asia and South America.

('35', 410, 2, 5, 759171) 529. SERVANTS OF INDIA SOCIETY’S RELIEF FUND
('35', 410, 3, 6, 759216) I gladly publish the following appeal to the public made by Sjt.
('35', 410, 3, 7, 759281) Sastri:
('35', 410, 4, 8, 759289) The Servants of India Society have sustained a terrible loss by the fire which brought to ruin the Arya Bhushan Press and the Dnyan Prakash Press.
('35', 410, 4, 9, 759436) These had been built up with great patience and foresight by Mr. Gokhale, who knew the mutations of public support and desired to provide for the Society a constant source of income.
('35', 410, 4, 10, 759619) Deprived of their mainstay, the members of the Society cannot but turn in their distress to their countrymen for that prompt and generous help in money which alone can put them back in their former position and enable them to resume their career of service to the public.
('35', 410, 4, 11, 759891) I have already appealed to personal friends through private letters, and I wish by this means to reach the wider pubic who are interested in the Society and its work.
('35', 410, 4, 12, 760058) Sympathy and help are flowing in from all sides, and our hearts have been gladdened beyond measure by the spontaneous expressions of goodwill received from those who are not in habitual agreement with us on public matters.
('35', 410, 4, 13, 760281) As I said on another occasion, it seems as though the essential kindliness of human nature, being so often forced out of its natural current by conflict of interests, were only waiting for a pretext to come back to its own channel.
('35', 410, 5, 14, 760513) We calculate that two lakhs of rupees would be required to enable us to make a fresh start.
('35', 410, 5, 15, 760605) The sum is large, and there is depression all round.
('35', 410, 5, 16, 760658) Still my colleague and I have every confidence that in a few months’ time we shall get what we want.
('35', 410, 5, 17, 760759) Our members will go round to various places, but they are not many and cannot be everywhere.
('35', 410, 5, 18, 760852) We look to our associates and sympathizers in all parts of the country for active help.
('35', 410, 5, 19, 760940) We beg them to respond to this appeal as though it had been made to them individually and in person.
('35', 410, 5, 20, 761041) No amount is so small but it will be welcome; in fact small reflection that we are known and appreciated by a wide circle of those whom we seek to serve.
('35', 410, 5, 21, 761195) The total amount collected at the time of circulation of the appeal amounted to over Rs. 26,000. I hope that the whole of the two lacs required to set the two presses and the papers going will have been subscribed by the time these lines appear in print.
('35', 410, 5, 22, 761450) The true
('35', 411, 0, 1, 761459) 412 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('35', 411, 1, 2, 761501) insurance for public concerns like the Servants of India Society is public goodwill reduced to concrete terms.
('35', 411, 2, 3, 761612) Young India, 24 6 1926
('35', 411, 3, 4, 761635) 530. SACRIFICE
('35', 411, 4, 5, 761650) I have before me several letters from young men complaining that they have so many family burdens that the poor salary they get from public work is totally inadequate for their wants.
('35', 411, 4, 6, 761834) One therefore says he must give up public work and go to Europe by raising a loan or securing a gift and increase his earning capacity; another is in search of a paying job; yet another wants a capital to start a paying business.
('35', 411, 4, 7, 762064) Everyone of these young men is a sound, honest and self sacrificing worker.
('35', 411, 4, 8, 762140) But a reaction has set in.
('35', 411, 4, 9, 762167) Family requirements have increased.
('35', 411, 4, 10, 762203) Khadi or national education does not satisfy them.
('35', 411, 4, 11, 762254) They do not desire to be a burden upon public service by asking for an increase.
('35', 411, 4, 12, 762335) But the logical outcome of this attitude of mind must mean, if it becomes at all general, either stoppage of the public service which depends upon the labours of such men and women, or a general indefinite increase which in its turn must bring about the same undesirable result.
('35', 411, 4, 13, 762614) It was because this process of multiplication of wants out of proportion to our surroundings was discovered to be going on with increasing velocity that non co operation was conceived.
('35', 411, 4, 14, 762799) And thus conceived it was not non co operation with persons, but with an attitude that was responsible for the system which had seized us in its serpentine coils and which was reducing us to dust.
('35', 411, 4, 15, 762996) The system had raised the standard of living among us, its creatures, wholly unwarranted by the general condition of the country.
('35', 411, 4, 16, 763126) And since India did not live upon exploitation of other peoples, the expansion of the middle class who were also the middle men meant extinction of the lowest strata.
('35', 411, 4, 17, 763293) Hence the smallest villages were dying out through sheer exhaustion.
('35', 411, 4, 18, 763362) This was all plain to many of us in 1920. The arresting movement is yet in its infancy.
('35', 411, 4, 19, 763450) Let us not hinder it by any hasty action.
('35', 411, 4, 20, 763492) This artificial increase in our wants has been felt more severely than it otherwise would have been, because of the persistence of the family system which the Western method is ill designed to support.
('35', 411, 4, 21, 763694) The joint system having become wooden, its evils have become
('35', 412, 0, 1, 763755) VOL.35 : 2 APRIL, 1926 7 JULY, 1926 413
('35', 412, 1, 2, 763795) accentuated, its sweet graces have disappeared.
('35', 412, 1, 3, 763843) Thus, evil has been added to evil.
('35', 412, 1, 4, 763878) Our self sacrifice must, therefore, be in terms of the require ments of the country.
('35', 412, 1, 5, 763963) The reforms required are more from within than from without.
('35', 412, 1, 6, 764024) A perfect constitution superimposed upon a rotten internal condition will be like a whited sepulchre.
('35', 412, 1, 7, 764126) The process of self purification must therefore be completed.
('35', 412, 1, 8, 764188) The spirit of self sacrifice must be extended.
('35', 412, 1, 9, 764235) Great as the sacrifice has been, it is nothing compared to the demands made upon us by the country.
('35', 412, 1, 10, 764335) We dare not support able bodied members of the family— men or women—who will not work.
('35', 412, 1, 11, 764422) We may not contribute a single pice towards the expenses of conforming to meaningless or superstitious customs, such as caste dinners, or towards forming expensive marriage connections.
('35', 412, 1, 12, 764608) Every marriage and every death brings an unnecessary, cruel burden upon the head of the family.
('35', 412, 1, 13, 764704) We must refuse to regard such acts of self denial as self sacrifice.
('35', 412, 1, 14, 764773) They are evils to be counteracted with courage and resolution.
('35', 412, 1, 15, 764836) There is too, for us, the inordinately expensive education.
('35', 412, 1, 16, 764896) When it is difficult for millions even to make the two ends meet, when millions are dying of starvation, it is monstrous to think of giving our relatives a costly education.
('35', 412, 1, 17, 765070) Expansion of the mind will come from hard experience, not necessarily in the college or the school room.
('35', 412, 1, 18, 765175) When some of us deny ourselves and ours the so called higher education, we shall find true means of giving and receiving a really high education.
('35', 412, 1, 19, 765321) Is there not, may there not be, a way of each boy paying for his own education?
('35', 412, 1, 20, 765401) There may be no such way.
('35', 412, 1, 21, 765427) Whether there is or there is not such a way is irrelevant.
('35', 412, 1, 22, 765486) But there is no doubt that when we deny ourselves the way of expensive education seeing that aspiration after higher education is a laudable end, we shall find out a way of fulfilling it more in accord with our surroundings.
('35', 412, 1, 23, 765711) The golden rule to apply in all such cases is resolutely to refuse to have what millions cannot.
('35', 412, 1, 24, 765808) This ability to refuse will not descend upon us all of a sudden.
('35', 412, 1, 25, 765873) The first thing is to cultivate the mental attitude that will not have possessions or facilities denied to millions, and the next immediate thing is to re arrange our lives as fast as possible in accordance with that mentality.
('35', 412, 1, 26, 766101) Without a large, very large, army of such self sacrificing and determined workers, real progress of the masses, I hold, to be an impossibility.
('35', 412, 1, 27, 766245) And without that progress, there is no such thing as
('35', 413, 0, 1, 766298) 414 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('35', 413, 1, 2, 766340) swaraj.
('35', 413, 1, 3, 766348) Progress towards swaraj will be in exact proportion to the increase in the number of workers who will dare to sacrifice their all for the cause of the poor.
('35', 413, 2, 4, 766505) Young India, 24 6 1926
('35', 413, 3, 5, 766528) 531. ‘MAHATMAJI’S ORDER’
('35', 413, 4, 6, 766553) A teacher writes:
('35', 413, 5, 7, 766571) There is a small group of boys of our school in .
('35', 413, 5, 8, 766621) who have been regularly sending 1,000 yards of self spun yarn to the A.I.S.A. for some months, and they have been doing this little service merely on account of intense love for you.
('35', 413, 5, 9, 766804) If anyone asks them the reason for their spinning, they reply: ‘It is Mahatmaji’s order.
('35', 413, 5, 10, 766893) It has got to be obeyed.’ I think such mentality on the part of little boys is to be encouraged in every way.
('35', 413, 5, 11, 767003) Slave mentality is something quite different from the spirit of hero worship or implicit obedience.
('35', 413, 5, 12, 767103) These boys are now anxious to get some message from you in your own handwriting for their inspiration.
('35', 413, 5, 13, 767206) I am sure their request will be complied with.
('35', 413, 5, 14, 767253) I do not know whether the mentality betrayed by this letter is hero worship or blind worship.
('35', 413, 5, 15, 767347) I can conceive occasions when implicit obedience without waiting for reasoning out causes is a necessity.
('35', 413, 5, 16, 767453) It is essentially the quality of a soldier.
('35', 413, 5, 17, 767497) And no nation can make substantial progress without the possession of that quality by a vast number of its people.
('35', 413, 5, 18, 767612) But occasions for such obedience are and must be rare in any well ordered society.
('35', 413, 5, 19, 767695) The worst thing that can happen to boys in a school is to have to render blind obedience to everything that the teacher says.
('35', 413, 5, 20, 767821) On the contrary, if teachers are to stimulate the reasoning faculty of boys and girls under their care, they would continuously tax their reason and make them think for themselves.
('35', 413, 5, 21, 768002) Faith only begins where reason stops.
('35', 413, 5, 22, 768040) But there are very few actions in the world for which reasonable justification cannot be found.
('35', 413, 5, 23, 768136) A teacher would not tolerate from his pupils, who were asked to account for drinking boiled and filtered water in a locality where the quality of well water was suspected, an answer to the effect that such were the orders of a mahatma.
('35', 413, 5, 24, 768372) And if it be wrong to admit such an answer, in the supposed case, it is surely wrong to approve of the justification for spinning that the boys of the school in question have given for their spinning.
('35', 413, 5, 25, 768573) When I am dislodged from my mahatmaship in that school, as I have certainly been dislodged in several homes to my
('35', 414, 0, 1, 768687) VOL.35 : 2 APRIL, 1926 7 JULY, 1926 415
('35', 414, 1, 2, 768727) knowledge (for some of my correspondents have been gracious enough to inform me of their lost love), I am afraid the spinning wheel will be destroyed.
('35', 414, 1, 3, 768878) Surely, a cause is often greater than the man.
('35', 414, 1, 4, 768925) Certainly, the spinning wheel is greater than myself.
('35', 414, 1, 5, 768979) I should be exceedingly sorry to find, when the hero worship of me is destroyed, because of some fatuous mistakes that I may commit or because people are enraged against me for some cause or other, that the good cause of the spinning wheel had to suffer.
('35', 414, 1, 6, 769234) It is therefore infinitely better that the pupils should reason out for themselves all the things that are capable of being so treated.
('35', 414, 1, 7, 769370) The spinning wheel is essentially a thing for reasoning out.
('35', 414, 1, 8, 769431) With it, in my opinion, is mixed up the well being of the whole mass of Indian humanity.
('35', 414, 1, 9, 769520) Pupils should, therefore, learn something about the deep poverty of the masses.
('35', 414, 1, 10, 769600) They should have an ocular demonstration of some villages that are crumbling down to pieces.
('35', 414, 1, 11, 769693) They should know the population of India.
('35', 414, 1, 12, 769735) They should know the vast extent of this peninsula and they should know what it is that all the many millions can do to add to their scanty resources.
('35', 414, 1, 13, 769886) They should learn to identify themselves with the poor and the downtrodden in the land.
('35', 414, 1, 14, 769974) They should be taught to deny themselves, so far as possible, things that the poorest cannot have.
('35', 414, 1, 15, 770073) Then they will understand the virtue of spinning.
('35', 414, 1, 16, 770123) It will then survive any shock including disillusionment about myself.
('35', 414, 1, 17, 770194) The cause of the spinning wheel is too great and too good to have to rest on mere hero worship.
('35', 414, 1, 18, 770290) It lends itself to scientific economic treatment.
('35', 414, 1, 19, 770340) I know that there is among us a great deal of blind hero worship such as this correspondent has described, and I hope that the teachers of national schools will take note of the warning I have uttered and prevent their pupils from lazily basing their actions upon statements, without testing, of men reputed to be great.
('35', 414, 1, 20, 770661) Young India, 24 6 1926

('35', 415, 2, 6, 771509) 533. NOTES
('35', 415, 3, 7, 771520) VILLAGE ORGANIZATION
('35', 415, 4, 8, 771541) Professor Narayandas Malkani’s notes on his recent tour in Bardoli Taluka are both interesting and instructive.
('35', 415, 4, 9, 771653) The reader will find there a brief account of an experiment in village work that has been going on in that Taluka amongst the backward classes since 1921 when the wave of temperance reform swept through the land.
('35', 415, 4, 10, 771866) Here in this small tract the introduction of the wheel is bringing about a slow but steady revolution in the life of the simple dwellers.
('35', 415, 4, 11, 772004) But for the charkha, temperance workers could not have had any footing in these villages.
('35', 415, 4, 12, 772094) Nor could they have produced any impression whatsoever upon the villagers, if they had not come in touch with the people in many other ways and found a profitable employment for occupying every idle moment of theirs.
('35', 415, 4, 13, 772311) The workers have been able to divert the minds of villagers from drink and interest them in spinning.
('35', 415, 4, 14, 772413) Effort is being made to educate the children of these people.
('35', 415, 4, 15, 772475) The education that is being given them is by no means of the orthodox type.
('35', 415, 4, 16, 772551) It fits in with their surroundings and is intended to draw out all their faculties.
('35', 415, 4, 17, 772635) The idea being not to manufacture clerks but to make citizens of the children, well able to take care of themselves and well able to preserve intact their hereditary occupation, namely, agriculture, spinning, weaving, etc.
('35', 415, 4, 18, 772858) But the experiment is still in its infancy.
('35', 415, 4, 19, 772902) The child is father to the man.
('35', 415, 4, 20, 772934) And even in this infant stage of the experiment everything that has gone on hitherto gives promise of a brilliant future.
('35', 415, 4, 21, 773056) For, with the introduction of hand spinning, the trades necessary for sustaining it are also being gradually revived amongst the people.
('35', 415, 4, 22, 773193) It is not too much to hope that this revolution that is going on amongst the people may enable them to get rid of, what Professor Malkani calls, ‘the native bureaucracy’ and that not by violent but by strictly non violent means, means that are calculated to convert not to coerce ‘the native bureaucracy’.
('35', 416, 0, 1, 773499) VOL.35 : 2 APRIL, 1926 7 JULY, 1926 417
('35', 416, 1, 2, 773539) the people simply need to be independent of both the money lender and the publican, of the first by ceasing to want credit and of the second by ceasing to drink.
('35', 416, 2, 3, 773701) A TRAVESTY
('35', 416, 3, 4, 773712) ‘The voluntary repatriation’ described by Dr. Malan, the Union Minister 1, is anything but voluntary.
('35', 416, 3, 5, 773814) It is stimulated, aided or induced.
('35', 416, 3, 6, 773850) And if the process continues unchecked, it may presently become compulsory.
('35', 416, 3, 7, 773926) A large number of men repatriated are said to be colonial born.
('35', 416, 3, 8, 773990) No colonial born Indian to whom India is only a geographical expression will voluntarily repatriate himself.
('35', 416, 3, 9, 774099) Again it is not voluntary repatriation when an agency is set up, probably paid by results, to collect repatriation recruits and when these recruits are detained in compounds pending repatriation.
('35', 416, 3, 10, 774295) It seems to me that this detention in compounds is likely to be declared illegal if it is tested in a court of law.
('35', 416, 3, 11, 774411) For detention without a guard would be useless.
('35', 416, 3, 12, 774459) And placing a guard over free and innocent men would amount to wrongful confinement.
('35', 416, 3, 13, 774544) I know of no regulation in 1914 that permitted the Government to detain such men in guarded camps.
('35', 416, 3, 14, 774643) If repatriation is to be voluntary it must be free from the pestering attention of recruiting agents and there should be no detention in depots or camps.
('35', 416, 4, 15, 774797) THE TRUE GURU
('35', 416, 5, 16, 774811) In confirmation of my note on the definition of a guru, a correspondent sends the following interesting information:
('35', 416, 6, 17, 774928) In connection with your definition of a guru, I am reminded of the beautiful lines of the poet saint Ramadas.
('35', 416, 6, 18, 775038) He said:
('35', 416, 7, 19, 775047) ‘You cannot find a better guru than viveka or the power of discriminating from untruth, right from wrong or good from evil.
('35', 416, 7, 20, 775171) There is no better disciple than chitta or mind, and no nobler friend than one’s jeeva or soul.’ In fact, Ramadas points out that man need not go outside himself in search of a guru.
('35', 416, 7, 21, 775354) ‘Be guided by your power of discrimination, derived from your implicit faith in God, keep your mind under control of such a power and nobly sacrifice the self.’ This in essence is the advice of the Maharashtrian saint.

('35', 417, 1, 2, 775656) 534. TO READERS OF “ HINDI NAVAJIVAN”
('35', 417, 2, 3, 775694) It has ever been a matter of sorrow to me that I am not able to write for Hindi Navajivan or look after it.
('35', 417, 2, 4, 775802) After Shri Haribhau Upadhyaya was posted for khadi work, I have received several complaints regarding the language of Hindi Navajivan.
('35', 417, 2, 5, 775937) It is said that the quality of the language has deteriorated, that there are grammatical errors and that the idiom has a foreign ring.
('35', 417, 2, 6, 776072) It is also said that sometimes the meaning conveyed is just the opposite of what is intended.
('35', 417, 2, 7, 776166) All this may be true.
('35', 417, 2, 8, 776188) Although the translators do their work with devotion and industry, it may well be that they, being Gujaratis, make mistakes.
('35', 417, 2, 9, 776313) I am looking for a person who knows Hindi.
('35', 417, 2, 10, 776356) I hope, when I find one, the chances of error will be fewer.
('35', 417, 2, 11, 776417) At the same time, it may be appropriate to point out that, after all, Hindi Navajivan carries only translations.
('35', 417, 2, 12, 776530) Of course, I shall do my best to see that the meaning is not distorted.
('35', 417, 2, 13, 776602) The truth, however, remains that I have not the ability to bring out Navajivan in Hindi.
('35', 417, 2, 14, 776691) I have neither the time to manage its affairs nor the requisite knowledge of Hindi.
('35', 417, 2, 15, 776775) I agreed to bring out Hindi Navajivan on the insistence of friends and out of a desire that those who know only Hindi should not remain unacquainted with my ideas.
('35', 417, 2, 16, 776939) This work can be continued if readers will help.
('35', 417, 2, 17, 776988) They can help in two ways: (1) they can point out the errors, and (2) they can refuse to buy the paper when the errors become too many to put up with.
('35', 417, 2, 18, 777139) Navajivan is not published out of any financial motive.
('35', 417, 2, 19, 777195) It is brought out solely to advance the general good.
('35', 417, 2, 20, 777249) If, owing to faults of language or some other reason, it cannot serve the purpose for which it is intended, it will be our duty to close it down.
('35', 417, 2, 21, 777395) All the translations carried in this issue are by persons whose mother tongue is Hindi.
('35', 417, 3, 22, 777483) Readers will oblige me by pointing out errors in this issue.

('35', 424, 5, 10, 787111) From a microfilm of the Gujarati: S.N. 19921
('35', 424, 6, 11, 787156) 546. POSSESSED BY GHOST OF SUSPICION
('35', 424, 7, 12, 787193) “A Passenger” has written the following letter without giving his name.
('35', 424, 7, 13, 787265) 1 Such letters do not deserve any notice.
('35', 424, 7, 14, 787307) One does not know, however, how many workers may be victims of such suspicions.
('35', 424, 7, 15, 787387) The issues raised in the letter are worthy of attention.
('35', 424, 7, 16, 787444) I made inquiries immediately on receiving the letter, and discovered that the facts of the case are quite different from what they are represented to be by “A Passenger”.
('35', 424, 7, 17, 787615) The person against whom these allegations are made is engaged in work which he simply could not have carried on if he travelled without paying proper fare as he is stated in this letter to havedone.
('35', 424, 7, 18, 787814) He is, moreover, being watched by railway officials.
('35', 424, 7, 19, 787867) If he were even once caught travelling without a proper ticket, his career of public service would come to an immediate end.
('35', 424, 7, 20, 787992) He generally travels third class, but a friend had bought for him a second class ticket from Morbi and so he had taken a seat in that compartment.
('35', 424, 7, 21, 788139) From Muli, he changed into a third class compartment for a short distance because he wanted to be with a friend who was travelling in that compartment.
('35', 424, 8, 22, 788291) 1 The letter is not translated here.
('35', 424, 8, 23, 788328) It stated that a leading worker in Saurashtra had been travelling by railway without paying the proper fare.
('35', 425, 0, 1, 788437) 426 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('35', 425, 1, 2, 788479) The worker has still with him the number on the second class ticket which he held.
('35', 425, 1, 3, 788562) Normally, no one preserves the number on a railway ticket but, as mentioned above, railway officials are a little too kindly disposed to him and ask him frequently to show his ticket.
('35', 425, 1, 4, 788746) He also, therefore, has made it a practice to note down the number on his ticket.
('35', 425, 1, 5, 788828) It does not appear that “A Passenger” had taken the trouble to examine the ticket himself or ask the worker for his explanation.
('35', 425, 1, 6, 788957) So much about the facts of this case.
('35', 425, 1, 7, 788995) The complaint made in this letter should give every public worker reason for pride, and also teach him to be vigilant.
('35', 425, 1, 8, 789114) It should give reason for pride because it shows that people expect to see perfection in workers who wear khadi, and it teaches him the need for vigilance because a worker wearing khadi must avoid any lapse.
('35', 425, 1, 9, 789322) It should, however, be admitted that many self seeking “workers” have exploited the khadi dress.
('35', 425, 1, 10, 789419) Wearing khadi and having made people believe that they were men of self sacrifice, such workers deceive society and refuse to make any amends.
('35', 425, 1, 11, 789562) Such khadi wearers disgrace khadi.
('35', 425, 1, 12, 789597) It is a perfectly legitimate assumption that anyone who cheats the railway company in the matter of fare will ultimately plunder the country, too, for his own gain.
('35', 425, 1, 13, 789762) And yet many people think that it is not wrong to cheat the railway company and to travel by a higher class on a lower class ticket.
('35', 425, 1, 14, 789895) It is desirable that people who wear khadi and others engaged in national work keep away from such dishonesty.
('35', 425, 1, 15, 790006) People, too, should understand that all persons who wear khadi are not saints, and those who do not wear it are not wicked men.
('35', 425, 1, 16, 790134) Anybody, irrespective of whether he is a good man or a bad man, is free to adopt khadi as his dress.
('35', 425, 1, 17, 790235) If others look upon khadi as sacred and feel themselves sanctified by wearing it, that is their special faith and does them honour.
('35', 425, 1, 18, 790367) But this special faith of theirs does not concern the world.
('35', 425, 1, 19, 790428) It is but right that people in the world should trust a person only after he has been put to the test.
('35', 425, 1, 20, 790531) In conclusion, I should like everyone to know that I have no disciple, or rather that I have only one, myself.
('35', 425, 1, 21, 790642) All my time is taken up in teaching myself, and so I need no other disciple.
('35', 425, 2, 22, 790719) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 27 6 1926
('35', 426, 0, 1, 790756) VOL.35 : 2 APRIL, 1926 7 JULY, 1926 427
('35', 426, 1, 2, 790796) 547. NOTES
('35', 426, 2, 3, 790807) SPINNING IN SANSOLI1
('35', 426, 3, 4, 790828) Sansoli is a village in the Kalol taluka of Panch Mahals district.
('35', 426, 3, 5, 790895) Shri Ranchhoddas Shah has sent some interesting information about the spinning activity there, which I reproduce below: 2
('35', 426, 4, 6, 791017) The number of spinning wheels is not large enough to be remarkable, but the quantity of yarn produced on each wheel is quite good.
('35', 426, 4, 7, 791148) But the most interesting particular mentioned in this report is that the spinner himself or herself cards the cotton and makes the slivers.
('35', 426, 4, 8, 791288) It is essential that this improvement in the method of work should, wherever possible, be adopted forthwith.
('35', 426, 4, 9, 791397) Carding is an easy operation, and those who card their own cotton can spin better and finer yarn and produce more of it in the same time, whereas it is difficult to spin to one’s satisfaction if the carding has been done by a hired carder.
('35', 426, 4, 10, 791637) Another point worth noting here is that the cultivator who gins the cotton grown by himself increases his earning considerably.
('35', 426, 4, 11, 791765) The practice of ginning cotton at home can be revived only if the spinning is also done at home.
('35', 426, 4, 12, 791862) Thus the revival of hand spinning will automatically bring about the revival of many other industries which have disappeared, and enable an intelligent cultivator to add considerably to his income.
('35', 426, 5, 13, 792060) SELF PURIFICATION AMONG CHODHRAS3
('35', 426, 6, 14, 792094) Shri Narayan Malkani, a professor in the Gujarat Mahavi dyalaya, had recently been to the parts around Vedchhi in Bardoli taluka and saw the work being done among the Chodhras there.
('35', 426, 6, 15, 792277) He has sent a report of his observations for Young India of which I give here only the gist, since many points mentioned in the original are meant for readers outside Gujarat.
('35', 426, 6, 16, 792453) In 1921 a good many villages had got rid of the evil of drink.
('35', 426, 6, 17, 792516) Afterwards, a good number had started drinking again.
('35', 426, 6, 18, 792570) The enduring work which is now being done there, thanks to some workers having settled for good in the area, is interesting to observe.
('35', 426, 6, 19, 792706) Shri Narayan Malkani is reporting only about the “clean” villages, clean in respect of drinking.
('35', 426, 7, 20, 792803) 1 The name, Sanosali, as originally spelt, was corrected in a note in Navajivan, 11 7 1926.
('35', 426, 8, 21, 792895) 2 The letter is not translated here.
('35', 426, 8, 22, 792932) 3 A scheduled tribe in South Gujarat
('35', 427, 0, 1, 792969) 428 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('35', 427, 1, 2, 793011) The Chodhras rank high among the Kaliparaj 1 communities.
('35', 427, 1, 3, 793069) They till their own land; but, thanks to their addiction to drinking, the owners of liquor shops and money lenders in the area have become their masters and function as the “local” Government of the area.
('35', 427, 1, 4, 793274) Those among them who succeed in freeing themselves from the grip of this “local” Government may be said to have won swaraj.
('35', 427, 1, 5, 793398) The Vedchhi Ashram 2 has strengthened the anti drink movement through sound work in the field of khadi.
('35', 427, 1, 6, 793502) Four hundred spinning wheels are in commission at present, which means that 800 persons spin on them daily.
('35', 427, 1, 7, 793610) There are more men than women among them.
('35', 427, 1, 8, 793652) In the first 3 year 500 lbs.
('35', 427, 1, 9, 793681) of yarn was spun; last 4 year, the quantity rose to 16,000 lbs.
('35', 427, 1, 10, 793745) This gave about 4,000 square yards of khadi.
('35', 427, 1, 11, 793790) The people stock the required cotton from what they grow in their own fields, card it themselves and then spin.
('35', 427, 1, 12, 793902) The yarn is woven into cloth in Vedchhi itself by Chodhra boys.
('35', 427, 1, 13, 793966) The charge for weaving is only two annas a yard but the weaver gets some other help in addition to his wages.
('35', 427, 1, 14, 794076) In some villages, this activity has provided work to carpenters too, and as a result people can have a fairly good spinning wheel for Rs. 2. In this way, the people who wear khadi spend only two annas for every yard they use; and, where previously no supplementary occupation existed, two such occupations, weaving and carpentry, have come into existence.
('35', 427, 1, 15, 794432) When I visited the area two years ago, I asked the people how much they got through the spinning wheel every year.
('35', 427, 1, 16, 794547) An old man replied with evident pleasure that they got ten rupees.
('35', 427, 1, 17, 794614) Shri Narayan Malkani gives detailed figures now.
('35', 427, 1, 18, 794663) A Chodhra family requires 34 yds.
('35', 427, 1, 19, 794697) of cloth in a year—10 yds.
('35', 427, 1, 20, 794724) for children and 24 yds.
('35', 427, 1, 21, 794749) for the husband and the wife.
('35', 427, 1, 22, 794779) The family gets these 34 yards for Rs. 4_, whereas previously when they bought their requirements in the market they had to pay Rs. 22 for the same quantity.
('35', 427, 1, 23, 794937) Thus a family producing its own cloth saves Rs. 17_.
('35', 427, 1, 24, 794990) It is true, of course, that this does not take into account the cost of cotton.
('35', 427, 1, 25, 795070) What would a poor Chodhra get for that cotton if he sold it in the market?
('35', 427, 1, 26, 795145) Seven rupees for 14 lbs.
('35', 427, 1, 27, 795170) The net saving, therefore, comes to Rs. 11. To them this is
('35', 427, 2, 28, 795230) 1 Scheduled tribes in Gujarat; literally, dark skinned people 2 The Ashram at Vedchhi, a village in the Surat district of Gujarat, managed by Jugatram Dave 3 The words “first year” and “last year” were corrected in Navajivan, 11 7 1926. 4 ibid
('35', 428, 0, 1, 795474) VOL.35 : 2 APRIL, 1926 7 JULY, 1926 429
('35', 428, 1, 2, 795514) a big enough saving.
('35', 428, 1, 3, 795535) It is not as if all the families keep back the 14 lbs.
('35', 428, 1, 4, 795590) of cotton which they would require and spin it into yarn, but we may say that a movement in the direction has started.
('35', 428, 2, 5, 795709) REFORMING VILLAGE LIFE
('35', 428, 3, 6, 795732) We saw above that with the help of the spinning wheel a slow but steady change is being brought about in the lives of the poor Chodhras.
('35', 428, 3, 7, 795869) Without the aid of the spinning wheel, the workers could not have come into contact with the village people merely by making speeches against the evil of drinking.
('35', 428, 3, 8, 796033) If, moreover, they had not shown to the latter a profitable way of spending the whole of their spare time, what effect could they have produced by their propaganda work?
('35', 428, 3, 9, 796203) The workers stopped the village people from drinking and placed the spinning wheel in their hands.
('35', 428, 3, 10, 796302) They started schools for children, schools, moreover, in which the pupils do not receive the kind of clerk making education which other schools impart but get education which will help them to be good farmers, spinners and weavers and live as useful members of society.
('35', 428, 3, 11, 796572) The experiment is still in its initial stage; but the present ways of a child can tell us a little what he will be like when he grows up, and we can, therefore, hope from what has been achieved so far that we shall get excellent results in course of time.
('35', 428, 3, 12, 796828) For, along with spinning, other occupations connected with it are also being revived.
('35', 428, 3, 13, 796914) We may hope that, as a result of the work which is being done, the people will become free from the grip of what Prof.
('35', 428, 3, 14, 797033) Malkani calls the “local” Government of the area, and that not by throwing off its yoke through force but by awakening the conscience of the present masters and bringing about a change of heart in them.
('35', 428, 3, 15, 797236) This will happen because, once people learn to give all their time to work and stop borrowing money from professional money lenders and patronizing the liquor shops, they are bound to become free from the grip of either.
('35', 428, 4, 16, 797457) A CORRECTION
('35', 428, 5, 17, 797470) Referring to the “Note” in the Navajivan of June 13, about the Mahudha khadi centre, a gentleman writes as follows: 1
('35', 428, 6, 18, 797588) If we had many more such readers who read their Navajivan carefully and drew attention to errors, in a short time the paperwould
('35', 428, 7, 19, 797717) 1 The letter is not translated here.
('35', 428, 7, 20, 797754) For the “Note”, vide “Mahudha Khadi Centre”, 13 6 1926.
('35', 429, 0, 1, 797810) 430 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('35', 429, 1, 2, 797852) be free from errors.
('35', 429, 1, 3, 797873) It is certainly my own ambition that the paper should contain no error of fact, should use no improper word or be faulty in language.
('35', 429, 1, 4, 798007) I know, however, that faults of language occur.
('35', 429, 1, 5, 798055) Errors of fact creep in sometimes through inadvertence.
('35', 429, 1, 6, 798111) The only claim I can make is that the language of the paper is restrained.
('35', 429, 1, 7, 798186) As regards errors of fact, we need the help of readers.
('35', 429, 1, 8, 798242) To prevent faults of language, the press should have more efficient workers and those who write for Navajivan should be studious of their language.
('35', 429, 1, 9, 798390) I am not well equipped in regard to any of these, but despite these handicaps the desire to continue Navajivan is strong.
('35', 429, 1, 10, 798512) Those readers of the paper, therefore, who love it have no option but to bear for the present with the errors which occur.
('35', 429, 1, 11, 798635) The correspondent is certainly right in regard to the error in multiplication pointed out by him.
('35', 429, 1, 12, 798733) Asked about the quantity of yarn produced from 20 maunds of yarn, Shri Mohanlal Pandya explains:
('35', 429, 2, 13, 798830) The statements that 20 maunds of yarn was produced and 65 pieces of khadi were woven in [the month of] Vaishakh does not mean that all the 20 maunds of yarn was used for producing the 65 pieces.
('35', 429, 2, 14, 799025) For 65 pieces, at the most 11 maunds of yarn would be required.
('35', 429, 2, 15, 799089) The rest remained in balance.
('35', 429, 2, 16, 799119) The quantity of yarn left in balance varies from month to month, depending on the number of weavers who work during the month.
('35', 429, 2, 17, 799246) I need not suggest to friends who send reports that they should bear in mind that Navajivan has readers who read the paper with attention and, therefore, should work out their figures carefully and supply full details.

('35', 432, 1, 2, 802594) 551. LETTER TO D. N. BAHADURJI
('35', 432, 2, 3, 802625) THE ASHRAM, SABARMATI, June 27, 1926
('35', 432, 3, 4, 802662) DEAR FRIEND, I have your letter.
('35', 432, 3, 5, 802695) 50 strength means half of what it should be.
('35', 432, 3, 6, 802740) And strength means the quality of twist.
('35', 432, 3, 7, 802781) A properly twisted thread will stand the strain of a standard weight and still not break and that standard means 100 marks.
('35', 432, 3, 8, 802905) But if it stands only half of that weight, it would be 50 marks.
('35', 432, 3, 9, 802970) But 50 strength is really not good enough for the weaver.
('35', 432, 3, 10, 803028) Mill yarn too rarely attains 100 marks.
('35', 432, 3, 11, 803068) But 70 marks would be creditable and it will offer no difficulty to the weaver in weaving.
('35', 432, 3, 12, 803159) 50 is the standard mark for evenness of thread.
('35', 432, 3, 13, 803207) When a well twisted thread is not even, it snaps as it passes through the apparatus which is meant for receiving hundreds of threads called warp which give us the width of cloth.
('35', 432, 3, 14, 803386) If the thread is uneven, it breaks from time to time.
('35', 432, 3, 15, 803440) The more even the yarn, therefore, the better it is for weaving; hence the necessity for obtaining at least 45 marks for evenness.
('35', 432, 3, 16, 803571) Constant looking at the strand after the spinning is finished enables one to gauge the evenness, and the actual breaking of the yarn in order to gauge the strength enables one to arrive roughly at the possible strength.
('35', 432, 3, 17, 803791) And when you get your yarn tested from time to time, you are in a position to make the necessary improvements which come by careful progress.
('35', 432, 3, 18, 803933) I hope I am now clear.
('35', 432, 3, 19, 803956) I felt so thankful and delighted that you are taking so much interest in this poor man’s work.
('35', 432, 3, 20, 804051) What a silent revolution it would mean in our life if we could identify ourselves with the poorest of our people in a practical manner such as the spinning wheel presents!
('35', 432, 4, 21, 804223) Your sincerely, D. N. BAHADURJI, ESQ.
('35', 432, 5, 22, 804261) From a microfilm: S.N. 19643

('35', 439, 9, 20, 814008) The complaint is not about seasonal khadi.
('35', 439, 9, 21, 814051) The comparison has been set up between last year’s and this year’s production.
('35', 439, 9, 22, 814130) And the correspondent, who was himself a lover of khadi and an admirer of Tirupur khadi, contends that it has been progressively deteriorating.
('35', 439, 9, 23, 814274) And as you see, Jerajani endorses the verdict up to a point.
('35', 439, 9, 24, 814335) Whether a public statement is made or not, I think a more thorough investigation is necessary.
('35', 439, 9, 25, 814430) If the hot season causes deterioration, we must either find out ways and means of combating the evils of heat or we must frankly tell the public that they must expect two qualities according to the seasons and, therefore, also two prices.

('35', 440, 1, 2, 814709) With reference to your tour, I have well nigh despaired of any tour coming forth during the year through no fault of anybody.
('35', 440, 1, 3, 814835) It is difficult to get you all ready at the same time.
('35', 440, 1, 4, 814890) And you will insist upon having some unavoidable thing at the last moment and postpone your departure which is the conjuction of your stars.
('35', 440, 1, 5, 815031) I would suggest complete cancellation of touring unless you have courage enough to go out even single.
('35', 440, 1, 6, 815134) Manilal is not available till the first of September.
('35', 440, 1, 7, 815188) He has been postponing the work of his Railway Association from time to time and I cannot put any pressure upon him when he pleads the cause of his association.
('35', 440, 1, 8, 815349) Jamnalalji never cancels a programme, he accepts, but it is unjust to him and unjust to the cause to bind him to a programme which is not irrevocable.
('35', 440, 1, 9, 815500) I have therefore freed him from all obligations.
('35', 440, 1, 10, 815549) He will join you when you are ready if he at all can.
('35', 440, 1, 11, 815603) Nobody wants to tour without you.
('35', 440, 1, 12, 815637) You are therefore the central figure.
