('35', 442, 4, 7, 818794) 565. COLOUR BAR v.
('35', 442, 4, 8, 818813) SWADESHI
('35', 442, 5, 9, 818822) Thus writes Mr. Spender:
('35', 442, 6, 10, 818847) Gandhi would keep out European goods; the South Africans would go a step further and keep out the Indians.
('35', 442, 6, 11, 818954) Swadeshi and Colour Bar Bills are the obverse and reverse of the same idea; both follow from the despairing thought that East and West cannot intermingle without destroying each other’s characteristic ways of life.
('35', 442, 6, 12, 819169) Gandhi, the saint, is full of benevolence, and I listened to him while he earnestly disclaimed all sympathy with violent or anarchical ways of changing any existing order.
('35', 442, 6, 13, 819341) Yet, as he discoursed on the ravages which Western industrialism had wrought in the Indian village, I had the feeling that, if he were Emperor of India invested with plenary powers the regulations that he would make for the admission of Europeans and their settlement in India might not greatly differ from those which the South Africans are attempting to impose on Indians in South Africa today.
('35', 442, 6, 14, 819738) I have a very real respect for Mr. Gandhi, and I am, of course, aware that the last thing that he desires is to afford excuses for either form of intolerance.
('35', 442, 6, 15, 819897) It is nevertheless true that ‘Swadeshi’ and ‘Colour Bar’ belong to the same spiritual family.
('35', 442, 7, 16, 819991) This paragraph from Mr. Spender’s article furnishes an extraordinary study in what Tolstoy would call hypnotism.
('35', 442, 7, 17, 820104) Under the hypnotic influence of the standardized thought of the English official in India, Mr. Spender is unable to see any difference between the Colour Bar Bills of South Africa and the Indian swadeshi in terms of
('35', 442, 8, 18, 820320) 1 The accounts are not reproduced here.
('35', 442, 8, 19, 820360) 2 This was only Rs. 26 and odd out of receipts totalling a little over Rs. 6,154. 3 This was evidently the portion of Spender’s article quoted by G. D. Chatterjee in his letter to Gandhiji; vide “Letter to G. D. Chatterjee”, 27 6 1926
('35', 443, 0, 1, 820595) 444 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('35', 443, 1, 2, 820637) khaddar.
('35', 443, 1, 3, 820646) Mr. Spender is an honest Liberal.
('35', 443, 1, 4, 820680) He has some sympathy for Indian aspirations.
('35', 443, 1, 5, 820725) But he cannot escape the influence of his immediate surroundings.
('35', 443, 1, 6, 820791) What is true of him is no doubt true of every one of us.
('35', 443, 1, 7, 820848) Hence the necessity for non co operation.
('35', 443, 1, 8, 820890) When the surroundings are vicious, we must cut ourselves off from contact with those surroundings, in so far at least as our contact is voluntary.
('35', 443, 1, 9, 821037) But whether Mr. Spender’s extraordinary proposition is an outcome of the hypnotic influence of his surroundings or whether it is really his own original idea, let us examine it.
('35', 443, 1, 10, 821215) The Colour Bar Bill is aimed at men, not at measures.
('35', 443, 1, 11, 821269) Swadeshi is aimed at measures only.Colour Bar is indiscriminately against a man’s race or colour.
('35', 443, 1, 12, 821367) Swadeshi knows no such distinction.
('35', 443, 1, 13, 821403) The upholders of the Colour Bar would carry out their purpose even violently, if necessary.
('35', 443, 1, 14, 821495) Swadeshi eschews all form of violence, even mental.
('35', 443, 1, 15, 821547) The Colour Bar has no reason behind it.
('35', 443, 1, 16, 821587) Swadeshi, in the form of khaddar, is a scientific formula supported by reason all along the line.
('35', 443, 1, 17, 821685) Under the Colour Bar every Indian, no matter what educational qualifications he may possess, even though he may be thoroughly Westernized, is an undesirable person in the estimation of the Europeans of South Africa.
('35', 443, 1, 18, 821901) The Colour Bar Bills are violent in purpose, for, they would keep the natives of the soil and the Asiatic settlers for ever as unskilled labourers and will not allow them to rise above that status.
('35', 443, 1, 19, 822099) The Colour Bar Bills are intended to do, under the name of civilization and for its protection, perhaps, in a more virulent form, what has been done in the name of Hinduism by Hindus to the so called untouchables.
('35', 443, 1, 20, 822313) But it is worthy of note that untouchability, whatever may be said to the contrary, is fast dying in India.
('35', 443, 1, 21, 822421) Those who are devoting themselves to the removal of untouchability are also those who are enthusiastically advocating the universalization of the spinning wheel.
('35', 443, 1, 22, 822583) Untouchability is admitted to be an evil.
('35', 443, 1, 23, 822625) The Colour Bar is being raised almost to the status of a religion in South Africa.
('35', 443, 1, 24, 822708) The Colour Bar Bills would harm, and deprive of their possessions innocent men and women without any just cause.
('35', 443, 1, 25, 822821) Whereas swadeshi is intended to harm not one single soul, it seeks to return to the poorest of the land what has been taken away from them almost by force.
('35', 443, 1, 26, 822977) The Colour Bar Bills are exclusive.
('35', 443, 1, 27, 823013) Swadeshi is never exclusive in the sense in which the colour Bar Bills are.
('35', 443, 1, 28, 823089) Swadeshi has no sympathy with the formula that East and West can never intermingle.
('35', 443, 1, 29, 823173) Swadeshi does not banish all foreign or European goods, nor all machine made goods, nor for that matter does swadeshi tolerate all home made goods.
('35', 443, 1, 30, 823321) Swadeshi admits of and
('35', 444, 0, 1, 823344) VOL.35 : 2 APRIL, 1926 7 JULY, 1926 445
('35', 444, 1, 2, 823384) welcomes the introduction of all foreign goods that cannot or need not be manufactured in India and that would benefit her people.
('35', 444, 1, 3, 823515) Thus swadeshi admits all foreign books containing pure literature, all foreign watches, foreign needles, foreign sewing machines, foreign pins.
('35', 444, 1, 4, 823659) But swadeshi excludes all intoxicating drinks and drugs even though they may be manufactured in India.
('35', 444, 1, 5, 823762) Swadeshi concentrates itself upon the spinning wheel and khaddar, to the exclusion of all foreign cloth and even cloth manufactured in the mills of India, for the very simple, sufficient, satisfying and moral reason that the destruction of the spinning wheel has meant the destruction of the only supplementary industry of India for the millions of its peasants without furnishing any substitute.
('35', 444, 1, 6, 824159) Thus, swadeshi in the form of khaddar and the spinning wheel is a paramount necessity for the very existence of the millions of her paupers.
('35', 444, 1, 7, 824300) Whereas the Colour Bar Bills are a response to the greed of a handful of Europeans who are, after all, exploiting the resources of a land which belongs not to them, but to the original inhabitants of South Africa.
('35', 444, 1, 8, 824514) The Colour Bar Bills have, therefore, no moral foundation whatsoever so far as I can see.
('35', 444, 1, 9, 824604) The exclusion or the extinction of the Asiatic settlers of South Africa is in no way required, can in no way be proved to be necessary, for the existence of the South African Europeans.
('35', 444, 1, 10, 824790) Still less can the suppression of the original inhabitants of South Africa be defended on any single moral ground.
('35', 444, 1, 11, 824905) It is, therefore, painfully surprising to find a person of Mr. Spender’s experience and attainments putting the highly moral swadeshi in the form of khaddar in the same category as the Colour Bar Bills.
('35', 444, 1, 12, 825108) They do not belong to one family, let alone spiritual, but they belong to absolutely different families as different as the North Pole is from the South.
('35', 444, 1, 13, 825262) Mr. Spender speculates upon what I would do if I were ‘Emperor of India invested with plenary powers’.
('35', 444, 1, 14, 825365) Perhaps I can speculate with greater authority.
('35', 444, 1, 15, 825413) If I were Emperor of India, I would extend the hand of fellowship to the whole of the world irrespective of caste, colour or creed, for, I claim the whole of mankind to be the children of one God, having absolutely the same capacity for self realization as the tallest amongst them.
('35', 444, 1, 16, 825696) I would disband practically the whole of the army of occupation in India, retaining only such police as may be necessary for the protection of her citizens against thieves and robbers.
('35', 444, 1, 17, 825881) I would not bribe the Frontier tribes as they are being bribed today.
('35', 444, 1, 18, 825951) But I would cultivate the friendliest relations with them and to that end send out reformers amongst them
('35', 445, 0, 1, 826057) 446 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('35', 445, 1, 2, 826099) in order to find out the ways or means of providing useful occupation for them.
('35', 445, 1, 3, 826179) I would guarantee the fullest protection for every European living in India and all honest European enterprises.
('35', 445, 1, 4, 826292) I would impose a prohibitive tariff on all foreign cloth so as to exclude it entirely from India and bring khaddar under State control, so as to enable every villager who chooses to spin, feel that the products of his or her spinning wheel would be taken up.
('35', 445, 1, 5, 826551) I would prohibit the importation of intoxicating liquors and close down every distillery, confining the manufacture of alcohol and opium for proved medical necessity.
('35', 445, 1, 6, 826718) I would guarantee full protection to all forms of religious worship, save what is repugnant to the moral sense of mankind.
('35', 445, 1, 7, 826841) I would throw open to the so called untouchables every public temple and public school to which all other Hindus have right of admission.
('35', 445, 1, 8, 826979) I would summon the representative of both the Hindus and Mussalmans, search their pockets and deprive them of all eatables and of all lethal weapons, if they have any, and lock them together in one room and open it only after they have settled their quarrels.
('35', 445, 1, 9, 827239) There are of course many other things that I would do if I were Emperor of India.
('35', 445, 1, 10, 827321) But since there is little chance of my being one, the foregoing is enough as a fair sample of what one who is mis called a visionary, but whoconsiders himself a practical man, understanding the wants of the poorest people, would do if he had the power.
('35', 445, 1, 11, 827574) Young India, 1 7 1926
('35', 445, 2, 12, 827596) 566. ‘TOWARDS MORAL BANKRUPTCY’ I
('35', 445, 3, 13, 827630) Kind friends continue to send me cuttings from Indian newspapers approvingly dealing with the question of birth control by the use of contraceptives.
('35', 445, 3, 14, 827780) My correspondence with young men on their private conduct is increasing.
('35', 445, 3, 15, 827853) I am able to discuss in these pages only an infinitesimal portion of the questions raised by my correspondents.
('35', 445, 3, 16, 827965) American friends send me literature on the subject and some are even angry with me for having expressed an opinion against the use of contraceptives.
('35', 445, 3, 17, 828115) They deplore that, an advanced reformer in many ways, I should be medieval in my views about birth control.
('35', 445, 3, 18, 828223) I find too that the advocates of the use of contraceptives number among them some of the soberest of men and women of all lands.
('35', 445, 3, 19, 828352) I therefore thought that there must be something very decisive
('35', 446, 0, 1, 828415) VOL.35 : 2 APRIL, 1926 7 JULY, 1926 447
('35', 446, 1, 2, 828455) in favour of the methods advocated and felt too that I should say on the subject more than I have done.
('35', 446, 1, 3, 828559) Whilst I was thinking of the problem and of the question of reading the literature on the subject, a book called Towards Moral Bankruptcy was placed in my hands for reading.
('35', 446, 1, 4, 828733) It deals with this very subject and, as it appears to me, in a perfectly scientific manner.
('35', 446, 1, 5, 828825) The original is in French by M. Paul Bureau and is entitled L’ Indiscipline des Moeurs 1 which literally means “the indiscipline of morals”.
('35', 446, 1, 6, 828966) The translation is published by Constable Company and has an introduction by Dr. Mary Scharlieb, C.B.E., M.D., M.S. (Lond.).
('35', 446, 1, 7, 829091) It covers 538 pages in 15 chapters.
('35', 446, 1, 8, 829127) Having read the book, I felt that, before I summarized the author’s views, I must in justice to the cause read the standard literature in favour of the methods advocated.
('35', 446, 1, 9, 829298) I consequently borrowed from the Servants of India Society such literature as they had on the subject.
('35', 446, 1, 10, 829401) They have very kindly lent me some of the books in their possession.
('35', 446, 1, 11, 829470) Kaka Kalelkar who is studying the subject has given me Havelock Ellis’s volume specially bearing on the subject and a friend has sent me the special number of The Practitioner in which is collected some valuable medical opinion from well known practitioners.
('35', 446, 1, 12, 829729) My purpose in collecting literature on the subject was to test the accuracy, so far as a layman could, of M. Bureau’s conclusions.
('35', 446, 1, 13, 829860) One often finds that there are two sides to questions even when scientists discuss them and that there is much to be said for either side.
('35', 446, 1, 14, 829999) I was anxious, therefore, to know the viewpoints, of the advocates of contraceptives before I introduced to the reader M. Bureau’s volume.
('35', 446, 1, 15, 830138) I have come to the deliberate conclusion that so far at least as India is concerned, there is no case for the use of contraceptives.
('35', 446, 1, 16, 830271) Those who advocate their use for Indian conditions either do not know them or choose to ignore them.
('35', 446, 1, 17, 830372) But if it can be proved that the methods advocated are harmful even in the West, it would be unnecessary to examine the special Indian conditions.
('35', 446, 1, 18, 830519) Let us therefore see what M. Bureau has to say.
('35', 446, 1, 19, 830567) His studies are confined to France.
('35', 446, 1, 20, 830603) But France means much.
('35', 446, 1, 21, 830626) It is considered to be [one of] the most advanced countries in the world and, if the methods have failed in France, they are not likely to succeed elsewhere.
('35', 446, 1, 22, 830784) Opinions may differ as to the meaning of the word ‘failure’.
('35', 446, 1, 23, 830845) I must therefore define the word as it is here meant.
('35', 446, 1, 24, 830899) The methods must be proved to have failed if it can be shown that moral bonds have
('35', 447, 0, 1, 830982) 448 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('35', 447, 1, 2, 831024) loosened, licentiousness has increased, and, instead of the check having been exercised by men and women for purposes of health and economic limitation of families only, it has been used principally for feeding animal passions.
('35', 447, 1, 3, 831252) This is the moderate position.
('35', 447, 1, 4, 831283) The extreme moral position condemns the use of contraceptives under every conceivable circumstance, it being contended that it is not necessary for man or woman to satisfy the sexual instinct except when the act is meant for race reproduction, even as it is not necessary for man or woman to eat except for sustaining the body.
('35', 447, 1, 5, 831611) There is also the third position.
('35', 447, 1, 6, 831645) There is a class of men who contend that there is no such thing as morality or that if there is, it consists not in exercising restraint but in indulgence of every form of animal appetite, so long as it does not so impair the constitution as to render it unfit for the very indulgence which is its object.
('35', 447, 1, 7, 831951) For this extreme position, I do not suppose, M. Bureau has written his volume.
('35', 447, 1, 8, 832030) For, M. Bureau concludes his books by quoting Tom Mann’s saying: ‘The future is for the nations who are chaste’.
('35', 447, 1, 9, 832143) In the first part of his book, M. Bureau has collected facts which make most dismal reading.
('35', 447, 1, 10, 832236) It shows how vast organizations have sprung up in France which merely pander to man’s basest tastes.
('35', 447, 1, 11, 832337) Even the one claim of advocates of contraceptives that abortions must disappear with the use of these methods cannot be sustained.
('35', 447, 1, 12, 832468) ‘It is certain’, says M. Bureau, ‘that during the twenty five years that have especially seen the increase in France of anti conceptionist methods, the number of criminal abortions has not become less.’ M. Bureau is of opinion that abortions are on the increase.
('35', 447, 1, 13, 832731) He puts down the figure at anything between 2,75,000 and 3,25,000 per year.
('35', 447, 1, 14, 832807) Public opinion does not look upon them with the horror that it did years ago.
('35', 447, 1, 15, 832885) Young India, 1 7 1926
('35', 447, 2, 16, 832907) 567. NOTES
('35', 447, 3, 17, 832918) KHADDAR EXHIBITIONS IN BIHAR
('35', 447, 4, 18, 832947) I have before me a fairly long report of the Khaddar Exhibitions that have been recently held in Bihar.
('35', 447, 4, 19, 833051) The inspiration to hold these exhibitions was derived by Babu Rajendra Prasad from such an exhibition held by the All India Agrawala Maha Sabha at Delhi during the year.
('35', 447, 4, 20, 833221) The first such exhibition in Bihar was opened by Babu Satis Chandra Das Gupta of Khadi Pratishthan, Calcutta.
('35', 448, 0, 1, 833331) VOL.35 : 2 APRIL, 1926 7 JULY, 1926 449
('35', 448, 1, 2, 833371) as it proved successful, similar exhibitions were continued to be held in various parts of Bihar.
('35', 448, 1, 3, 833469) The first exhibition was held on the grounds of Bihar Vidyapith on the banks of the Ganges, some three miles from Patna.
('35', 448, 1, 4, 833590) The second was held in the Bihar Young Men’s Institute and it was opened by Sadhu Vaswani of Sind.
('35', 448, 1, 5, 833689) The third was held at Arrah and the fourth at Muzaffarpur and was opened by Maulvi Saheb Muhammad Shaffee.
('35', 448, 1, 6, 833796) The fifth was held at Chupra 1 and was opened by Maulana Mazhar ul Haque.
('35', 448, 1, 7, 833870) The sixth was held at Mairnea, a small village in the district of Chupra and the seventh and the last mentioned in the report was held at Gaya on the 11th instant.
('35', 448, 1, 8, 834034) The highest attendance was at Gaya, in spite of terrible heat.
('35', 448, 1, 9, 834097) It totalled 7,000. There was a large number of ladies included in the number.
('35', 448, 1, 10, 834175) The least attendance was 2,000. The report goes on to state:
('35', 448, 2, 11, 834236) These exhibitions are being visited by Congressmen, non Congressmen, Government officials, Zamindars, lawyers, big and small merchants, and in some cases even Europeans.
('35', 448, 2, 12, 834406) The exhibition at Mairnea was visited by crowds of simple villagers, rather than middle class men.
('35', 448, 2, 13, 834505) The khadi sales averaged over a thousand each, the lowest being Rs. 400 at Mairnea, and the highest being Rs. 2,000 at Gaya.
('35', 448, 2, 14, 834630) The report says:
('35', 448, 3, 15, 834647) In these exhibitions all discord and disunion between Hindus and
('35', 448, 4, 16, 834712) Mussalmans or political leaders holding different views was absent.
('35', 448, 4, 17, 834780) The methods adopted are:
('35', 448, 5, 18, 834805) We approach at every place some prominent person and request him to organize a khadi exhibition.
('35', 448, 5, 19, 834902) We secure an influential man to open it.
('35', 448, 5, 20, 834943) Invitation cards are issued to prominent people.
('35', 448, 5, 21, 834992) The exhibition is advertised by means of notices, placards, etc.
('35', 448, 5, 22, 835057) In the evenings, during the exhibition time, magic lantern lectures are given illustrating the khadi movement.
('35', 448, 5, 23, 835168) Crowds are attracted to these lectures.
('35', 448, 5, 24, 835208) After the exhibition is over, khadi is hawked in the places where it is held.
('35', 448, 5, 25, 835286) We propose to continue to hold these exhibitions and expect to clear off our stock which amounts to Rs. 80,000. I observe from this report that noted men conducted the sales and hawking at these exhibitions.
('35', 448, 6, 26, 835494) PROFESSOR PRESENTED WITH KHADDAR
('35', 448, 7, 27, 835527) Quite recently, the students of the economic department of the Patna College presented Professor Hamilton on his retirement with a
('35', 448, 8, 28, 835658) 1 Also spelt as ‘Chapra’
('35', 449, 0, 1, 835683) 450 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('35', 449, 1, 2, 835725) piece of khaddar of local manufacture with the following remarks by their spokesman as quoted in The Searchlight:
('35', 449, 2, 3, 835839) Sir, I know you to be a devout follower of the late Prof.
('35', 449, 2, 4, 835897) Marshall who lays down the basic concept of all his works on economics: ‘It is on the one side a study of wealth, on the other and more important side, a part of the study of man.’ And for you we cannot choose a better present than a piece of khadi, from start to finish, a Bihar product, made of the indigenous Kukti cotton.

('35', 449, 3, 8, 836812) KHADDAR IN MYSORE
('35', 449, 4, 9, 836830) A correspondent writes:
('35', 449, 5, 10, 836854) Some khaddar lovers of Mysore have started a co operative society in Mysore town since July 1925. Not much khaddar is yet locally produced.
('35', 449, 5, 11, 836994) The organizers therefore secure khaddar from Andhra, Tamil Nadu and Karnatak.
('35', 449, 5, 12, 837072) The Society intends to increase its capital.
('35', 449, 5, 13, 837117) At present they have 365 shares of Rs. 10 each.
('35', 449, 5, 14, 837165) The shareholders are required to pay Re.
('35', 449, 5, 15, 837206) 1 per month on each allotted share.
('35', 449, 5, 16, 837242) But some have paid the whole amount.
('35', 449, 5, 17, 837279) There are 103 members of the society.
('35', 449, 5, 18, 837317) The shop purchases locally spun yarn at the rate of Rs. 12 per pound.
('35', 449, 5, 19, 837387) It is then locally woven.
('35', 449, 5, 20, 837413) The society is spending only Rs. 32 per month for the establishment and other charges.
('35', 449, 5, 21, 837500) The paid up capital between July 1925 and May last was Rs. 2,036. Khaddar purchased was Rs. 8,365. Khaddar sold was Rs. 8,088. This is no doubt an unpretentious beginning for a town like Mysore.
('35', 449, 5, 22, 837695) But if the example is copied by other towns and if the management is able and honest there is no doubt that there is a great future for khaddar in Mysore.

('35', 449, 7, 25, 837983) No rules have yet been passed by the Committee.

('35', 450, 0, 1, 838130) VOL.35 : 2 APRIL, 1926 7 JULY, 1926 451
('35', 450, 1, 2, 838170) the society seeking affiliation.
('35', 450, 1, 3, 838203) Full particulars should be supplied at the time of affiliation and the applicant society should be prepared to endorse the objects of the Association and submit to inspection and audit by the Association.
('35', 450, 1, 4, 838408) The affiliated institution or society shall have the right to have the advice of the experts of the Association and free use of the literature at its disposal and such other guidance as may be in its power to render.
('35', 450, 1, 5, 838625) These rules will naturally be subject to the sanction of the Committee of the A. I. Cow Protection Association.
('35', 450, 1, 6, 838737) I would welcome suggestions before the rules are placed before the Committee.

('35', 450, 2, 8, 838837) 568. ALL INDIA DESHBANDHU MEMORIAL
('35', 450, 3, 9, 838872) A correspondent draws my attention to the fact that the acknowledgments of amounts received on behalf of the All India Deshbandhu Memorial Fund have been loosely dealt with in Young India in that there has been no continuity.
('35', 450, 3, 10, 839098) This is true because as intimations were received either from the Secretary or the Treasurer I passed on the memoranda without checking and without examining the last totals.
('35', 450, 3, 11, 839273) The correspondent is therefore unable to know whether the monies paid by himself have been actually credited to the All India Deshbandhu Memorial Fund or not.
('35', 450, 3, 12, 839432) Upon receipt of this letter, I corresponded 1 with the Treasurer and secured a copy of the full list of subscribers to date.
('35', 450, 3, 13, 839557) In order to avoid any confusion and error and so as to enable every subscriber to find out for himself whether his subscription has or has not been received, I am publishing the full list 2. I am unable to give the whole list in one issue, if only because the second part of the list is still under examination.
('35', 450, 3, 14, 839869) I need hardly assure the reader that the funds at the Treasurer’s office are most jealously kept and they are banked as soon as they are received.
('35', 450, 3, 15, 840016) The confusion has arisen not owing to faulty or careless book keeping, but owing to omission to publish all lists received at the Young India office.
('35', 450, 3, 16, 840166) I shall be thankful if subscribers will look up the list that is being now published and call my attention to any omission they may discover.

('35', 457, 5, 10, 850576) 576. KHADI WORK IN GARIADHAR
('35', 457, 6, 11, 850605) Shri Shambhushanker has been working in Gariadhar on behalf of the Conference 1. His record of work is noteworthy.
('35', 457, 6, 12, 850720) He persuaded 1,l00 families in 41 villages around Gariadhar to stock cotton and helped them with all facilities up to the stage of weaving.
('35', 457, 6, 13, 850860) Approximately 3,000 maunds of cotton has been stocked, out of which 800 maunds was ginned on hand wheels.
('35', 457, 6, 14, 850966) There is a cess on carding in this region, but those who carded this cotton for being turned into slivers were exempted from this cess.
('35', 457, 6, 15, 851102) Out of all these families, only 112 families availed themselves of the assistance offered by the conference in terms of its resolutions on the subject, namely, one half the expenditure incurred oncarding and weaving.
('35', 457, 6, 16, 851319) Till now, only Rs. 164 have been spent on this account.
('35', 457, 6, 17, 851375) As near famine conditions prevailed in this area, cheap slivers were also supplied.
('35', 457, 6, 18, 851459) About 8 maunds of slivers were sold to nearly 50 families, at the rate of 6 annas a pound, and most of this was used for making women’s garments.
('35', 457, 6, 19, 851605) It is estimated that no more than Rs. 50 would have to be set aside for this purpose.
('35', 457, 6, 20, 851691) In addition to this, because of the famine conditions, cotton was also purchased from the market and got spun
('35', 457, 7, 21, 851801) 1 Kathiawar Political Conference
('35', 458, 0, 1, 851834) VOL.35 : 2 APRIL, 1926 7 JULY, 1926 459
('35', 458, 1, 2, 851874) into yarn on payment, with a view to having it woven into cloth.
('35', 458, 1, 3, 851939) So far, 295 maunds of cotton have been ginned, and made into slivers in the Centre itself.
('35', 458, 1, 4, 852030) The quantity is in the process of being spun and woven into cloth.
('35', 458, 1, 5, 852097) The cost of ginning came to Rs. 110. The cotton pods yielded 93_ maunds of cottonwool and 190 maunds of cotton seeds.
('35', 458, 1, 6, 852215) The yarn being spun is of 4 to 8 counts.
('35', 458, 1, 7, 852256) The rate of payment for spinning is five pies per count.
('35', 458, 1, 8, 852313) The rate for carding and making slivers is Rs. 2 12 0 per pound, and for weaving it is Rs. 8. The khadi woven is of 24 inches to 27 inches width, and one maund of khadi measures between 110 and 115 yards in length.
('35', 458, 1, 9, 852528) Shri Shambhushanker tries to get all the khadi produced sold locally.
('35', 458, 1, 10, 852598) He has so far sold 962 yards of khadi at the rate of 17 annas for 3_ yards, which comes nearly to 5 annas a yard.
('35', 458, 1, 11, 852712) A maund of yarn is woven into cloth every day.
('35', 458, 1, 12, 852759) Moreover khadi is woven in this area for the Amreli Khadi Centre too.
('35', 458, 1, 13, 852829) This khadi measures 30 inches in width.
('35', 458, 1, 14, 852869) The work in this centre is being done efficiently and economically, and the chief reason for this seems to be that Shri Shambhushankerbhai mixes with and maintains close contacts with each spinner, carder and weaver.
('35', 458, 1, 15, 853086) My object in publishing the figures which I receive from the various centres is that they may learn and derive inspiration from one another.
('35', 458, 1, 16, 853227) Healthy and pleasant competition amongst the various centres should be welcome.
('35', 458, 1, 17, 853307) The field of work is so large that it offers scope for sacrifice for thousands of voluntary workers and can help thousands of others to make a living.
('35', 458, 1, 18, 853458) Those, moreover, who become interested in this work and realize that village life can have the beauty of poetry can derive the utmost happiness from it.
('35', 458, 2, 19, 853611) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 4 7 1926
('35', 458, 3, 20, 853647) 577. RESTRICTIONS ON WOMEN IN MENSES
('35', 458, 4, 21, 853684) A widow writes as follows:
('35', 458, 5, 22, 853711) I am told that a woman in menses should not touch books, paper, pencil, slate and such other things connected with learning.
('35', 458, 5, 23, 853836) Do you also believe in this?
('35', 458, 5, 24, 853865) Such a question can be asked only in a wretched country like India which is disgraced by foolish notions about touching and not touching things.
('35', 458, 5, 25, 854010) Some of the rules forbidding such a woman to touch a particular thing can be justified on grounds of health and morality.
('35', 458, 5, 26, 854132) During that period, the woman is unfit to do hard work.
('35', 458, 5, 27, 854188) It is very
('35', 459, 0, 1, 854199) 460 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('35', 459, 1, 2, 854241) necessary that she should remain undisturbed by sex desire.
('35', 459, 1, 3, 854301) A married woman should altogether avoid the company of her husband, and rest is very necessary for her, but it is not only not improper for her to read good books or to study but, on the contrary, I believe that it is desirable and necessary that she should do so.
('35', 459, 1, 4, 854566) We can think of a number of household chores which such a woman can do with comfort and with little exertion.

('35', 459, 4, 7, 854712) 578. GUJARAT KHADI PRACHARAK MANDAL
('35', 459, 5, 8, 854748) According to the accounts for the second Chaitra 1 received from the Gujarat Khadi Mandal, 3,854 square yards of khadi was woven in fifteen different centres out of yarn spun personally by people who got it woven.
('35', 459, 5, 9, 854962) One of the centres wove 410 square yards of khadi from ready yarn and 3,348 sq.
('35', 459, 5, 10, 855042) yards of khadi for sale was woven in ten centres.
('35', 459, 5, 11, 855092) A subsidy of Rs. 1,433 at the rate of _ an anna a vishi 2 per yard was given to fifteen centres.
('35', 459, 5, 12, 855189) Khadi worth Rs. 7,580 was sold through eleven stores.
('35', 459, 5, 13, 855243) The total number of workers in the various centres was 41. Besides, there were 15 carders, 117 weavers, 172 persons spinning for themselves and 683 spinning for wages.
('35', 459, 5, 14, 855411) The figures of work for a period of eleven months are as follows: Khadi woven out of yarn spun by the persons who had it woven, 35,033 sq.
('35', 459, 5, 15, 855550) yards; khadi made from ready made yarn, 7,756 sq.
('35', 459, 5, 16, 855600) yards; khadi for sale, both spinning and weaving done through the centres, 20,595 sq.
('35', 459, 5, 17, 855686) yards; a subsidy of Rs. 10,584 at the rate of half an anna; the sale of khadi through the various stores, Rs. 80,063. These figures do not include those relating to centres in Kathiawar.
('35', 459, 5, 18, 855873) During the second Chaitra, the Mandal sold 19 spinning wheels, 50 taklis 3, 32 spindles, 105 Ib.
('35', 459, 5, 19, 855970) of slivers, 40 lb.
('35', 459, 5, 20, 855989) of yarn, 60 bows for carding, 29 charkhas and 56 aterans 4. In the figures above, annas and fractions have been left out.
('35', 459, 5, 21, 856111) These statistic may seem ludicrous in the context of our aim of bringing about boycott of foreign cloth, but, as a
('35', 459, 6, 22, 856226) 1 A month in the Hindu calendar, roughly corresponding to March April; in this year there was an extra, i.e., second Chaitra.
('35', 459, 7, 23, 856352) 2 A unit of a warp comprising twenty threads 3 Spindles worked with hand 4 Wooden gadgets on which yarn is wound off a spindle
('35', 460, 0, 1, 856479) VOL.35 : 2 APRIL, 1926 7 JULY, 1926 461
('35', 460, 1, 2, 856519) measure of the progress of khadi itself, of the help given to the poor and from the standpoint of middle class men and women who wish to earn their living through voluntary service, they are not ludicrous but heartening.
('35', 460, 1, 3, 856740) As our capacity for work improves and workers acquire self confidence, khadi will make even faster progress.
('35', 460, 1, 4, 856849) Anyone who takes the trouble to think cannot but see that, if there is any work which can become universal in the country, it is that connected with the production of khadi.

('35', 468, 2, 3, 867044) APPENDIX I VITHALBHAI PATEL’S LETTER TO GANDHIJI
('35', 468, 3, 4, 867093) BOMBAY,
('35', 468, 4, 5, 867101) May 10, 1926
('35', 468, 5, 6, 867114) DEAR MAHATMAJI,
('35', 468, 6, 7, 867130) When I accepted the office of President of the Legislative Assembly I had made a resolution within myself that I would devote the savings from my salary towards the furtherance of some object calculated to promote the national welfare.
('35', 468, 6, 8, 867366) It was not possible for me for various reasons to save anything worth the name within the first six months.
('35', 468, 6, 9, 867474) Since the last month, however, I am glad to say that I am quite out of the woods, and can, and do, save a substantial amount.
('35', 468, 6, 10, 867600) I find that, on an average, I require Rs. 2,000 per month for my expenses.
('35', 468, 6, 11, 867675) The amount of my net salary, excluding income tax, is Rs. 3,625. I propose, therefore, to set apart Rs. 1,625 per month, beginning from the last month, to be utilized hereafter in such manner and for such purpose as you may approve.
('35', 468, 6, 12, 867908) I have, of course, some ideas in the matter, and I will in due course discuss them with you.
('35', 468, 6, 13, 868001) But whether you agree with me in those ideas or not, the amount is at your disposal.
('35', 468, 7, 14, 868086) I enclose herewith a cheque for Rs. 1,625 for the month of April.
('35', 468, 8, 15, 868152) I trust you will not decline to take this responsibility.
('35', 468, 10, 16, 868210) Yours sincerely,
('35', 468, 11, 17, 868227) V. J. PATEL
('35', 468, 12, 18, 868239) Vithalbhai Patel—Life and Times—II.
('35', 468, 13, 19, 868275) APPENDIX II I. THE SABARMATI PACT1
('35', 468, 14, 20, 868310) The conference convened at the instance of Pandit Motilal Nehru was held at Sabarmati Ashram, Ahmedabad, on the 20th and 21st.
('35', 468, 14, 21, 868437) Telegrams and letters were received.
('35', 468, 14, 22, 868474) including one from Pandit Madan Mohan Malaviya which contained suggestions about bringing all Indian political parties on a common platform in a united Congress.
('35', 468, 15, 23, 868636) The conference adopted the following agreement, as embodying its decision on points specifically discussed :
('35', 468, 16, 24, 868745) 1 This appeared under the title “Swarajists and Responsivists : The Ahmedabad Compromise”.
('35', 469, 0, 1, 868836) 470 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('35', 469, 1, 2, 868878) It is hereby agreed between the undersigned, subject to the confirmation of the All India Congress Committee, that the response made by the Government shall for purposes of Clauses (a) and (b) of the resolution II B (4) of the All India Congress Committee, dated March 6 and 7, 1926, be considered satisfactory in the provinces, if the power, responsibility and initiative necessary for the effective discharge of their duties are secured to ministers and the sufficiency of such power, responsibility and initiative, in each province, shall be decided in the first instance by Congress members of the Legislative Council of the Province, subject to confirmation by a Committee consisting of Pandit Motilal Nehru and Mr. M. R. Jayakar.
('35', 469, 2, 3, 869614) It is further agreed that the said Committee will decide all disputes in the Congress provinces of the Bombay Maharashtra, Bihar and the C.P. Marathi.
('35', 469, 2, 4, 869765) This agreement has been subscribed to by the undersigned in their individual capacities, and it will be submitted for ratification to the executive of the Swaraj and Responsive Co operation Parties.
('35', 469, 2, 5, 869964) It will be placed for ratification before the All India Congress Committee at a meeting which is being convened on May 5 and 6 next, at Sabarmati.
('35', 469, 3, 6, 870111) The compormise is signed by Sarojini Naidu, Motilal Nehru, Lajpat Rai, M. R. Jayakar, N. C. Kelkar, B. S. Moonje, M. S. Aney, D. V. Gokhale, G. A. Ogale at Sabarmati, April 21, 1926. II.
('35', 469, 3, 7, 870298) A. I. C. C.’S DELHI RESOLUTION
('35', 469, 4, 8, 870329) The Clauses of Resolution II B(4) of the A.I.C.C. meeting at Delhi referred to in the agreement state that Congressmen shall
('35', 469, 5, 9, 870454) (a) refuse to accept offices in the gift of the Government until, in the opinion of the Congress, a satisfactory response is made by the Government;
('35', 469, 6, 10, 870603) (b) refuse supplies and throw out budgets until such response is made by the Government, except when the Working Committee instructs otherwise.
('35', 469, 6, 11, 870747) RESPONSIVISTS’ AKOLA MANIFESTO
('35', 469, 7, 12, 870778) The Responsive Co operationist Party manifesto, issued at the Akola Conference in February last, declared regarding their Council programme :
('35', 469, 8, 13, 870920) We believe that no programme of bringing about constitutional dead lock by resorting to the policy of uniform, continuous and consistent obstruction can be successful unless tried on a large scale, and backed by some sanctions behind the same.
('35', 469, 9, 14, 871164) We believe that the best course under the present circumstances is that
('35', 469, 10, 15, 871236) of Responsive Co operation, which means working the Reforms, unsatisfactory,
('35', 469, 11, 16, 871313) disappointing and inadequate as they are, for all they are worth; and using
('35', 469, 12, 17, 871389) the same for accelerating the grant of full responsible Government and also
('35', 469, 13, 18, 871465) for creating, in the meanwhile, opportunities for the people for advancing their
('35', 469, 14, 19, 871546) interests and strenghtening their power and resistance to injustice and misrule.
('35', 470, 0, 1, 871627) VOL.35 : 2 APRIL, 1926 7 JULY, 192 471
('35', 470, 1, 2, 871666) The policy of working the Reforms necessarily includes the capture of all places of power, responsibility and initative which are open to election by, or are otherwise responsible to, the party within the legislature, subject to such conditions with regard to policy, programme and kindred matters as may seem desirable to impose from time to time.1 IV.
('35', 470, 1, 3, 872020) THE BREAKDOWN OF THE PACT
('35', 470, 2, 4, 872046) At the meeting of the All India Congress Committee at Ahmedabad on the 4th May, Pandit Motilal announced that, owing to irreconcilable differences between the signatories of the Sabarmati Pact regarding the interpretation of its terms, the negotiations that he had been for the past few days carrying on with the Responsivists had broken down, and the Pact had, therefore, fallen through and was non existent.
('35', 470, 2, 5, 872456) A letter from the Responsivists was read by the Secretary confirming in the main Pandit Motilal’s statement.
('35', 470, 2, 6, 872565) V. MOTILAL’S SUBSTITUTE FORMULA
('35', 470, 3, 7, 872597) The following is the text of the substitute formula which was handed to the Responsivists leaders on the 4th morning :
('35', 470, 4, 8, 872716) Having regard to the fact that doubts and differences have arisen as to the true interpretation of the agreement arrived at between Mrs. Sarojini Naidu, Messrs Lajpat Rai, M. S. Aney, M. R. Jayakar, N. C. Kelkar, G. A. Ogale and Pandit Motilal Nehru at Sabarmati on the 21st April, 1926, this meeting of the All India Congress Committee, while fully agreeing with the principles, policy and programme laid down in resolution 7 of the Cawnpore Congress and resolution 2(b) of the All India Congress Committee passed at Delhi on 6th and 7th March, 1926, and fully believing that dyarchy in any form or shape is wholly unworkable in the best of conditions, is of opinion that with a view to remove all doubts and differences and to put the true issue before the country, it is expedient to state clearly what shall constitute the statisfactory response referred to in the said resolution.
('35', 470, 5, 9, 873602) It is, therefore, hereby resolved :
('35', 470, 6, 10, 873638) That the acceptance by the Government of the principle underlying the resolution passed by the Assembly on the 8th February, 1925, shall constitute a satisfactory response by the Government to the national demand for full responsible Government, and the immediate adoption by the Government of the various steps mentioned in the resolution of the Assembly passed on the 8th September, 1925, shall for the present be taken to be a sufficient compliance with the said principle.
('35', 470, 7, 11, 874115) (2) That if Responsible Government in the fullest sense is guaranteed by the Government to come automatically in the near future by the adoption of steps other
('35', 470, 8, 12, 874275) 1 Parts I, II and III are reproduced from the Indian Review, April, 1926, and Parts IV, V and VI from the issue of May, 1926.
('35', 471, 0, 1, 874401) 472 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('35', 471, 1, 2, 874443) than those mentioned in the resolution of the Assembly passed on the 8th September, 1925, and if, in the meantime, substantially full Responsible Government in the provinces is granted, the response so made by the Government shall be considered sufficient in the provinces for the purpose of accepting ministerships and considering the provincial budgets on their merits, provided that no such response shall be considered adequate unless it includes :
('35', 471, 2, 3, 874896) (a) The release or trial according to law of all political prisoners who are at present datained without being convicted by a duly constituted court.
('35', 471, 3, 4, 875046) (b) The repeal of all repressive laws.
('35', 471, 4, 5, 875085) (c) The removal of all disqualifications now imposed on persons who have served the sentences passed on them, from standing for election to elected bodies in the country.
('35', 471, 5, 6, 875256) (d) The abolition of non official nominations to membership of Council and throwing open the seats of nominated non official members to election by the general electorate.
('35', 471, 6, 7, 875428) (3) That the adequacy of any action by the Government in any province as is referred to in resolution 2 shall on the recommendation of the Congress members of the Legislative Council of that province be decided by the Working Committee.
('35', 471, 6, 8, 875665) RESPONSIVISTS’ DISAPPROVAL
('35', 471, 7, 9, 875692) In their reply, Mr. Jayakar and his colleagues pointed out :
('35', 471, 8, 10, 875753) We have carefully considered the draft which we regarded as a travesty of the Pact and a complete repudiation of the same.
('35', 471, 8, 11, 875876) We think that the draft furnishes no common ground on which we could profitably meet and discuss.
('35', 471, 8, 12, 875974) Under the circumstances, we are of opinion that no useful purpose will be served by our attending the Working Committee’s meeting this morning, and we have, therefore, decided not to attend the same.
('35', 471, 8, 13, 876174) We feel that we need not have been dragged all the way to Ahmedabad from our distant homes to be made sport of in the manner the draft proposes to do.
('35', 471, 9, 14, 876325) The Indian Review, April and May, 1926
